If you're used to other racers you might find the overly tight controls a little limiting -- drifting isn't really a THING here -- but then you discover the jumping, and the boosting, and the FLYING, and you realize that the controls are so tight because your car needs to be nimble to overcome the obstacles in your way, and then you realize that there's a fan community making amazing new tracks all the time, and if that's not enough there's a RANDOM TRACK GENERATOR which causes the game to have INFINITE CONTENT, and everything just pulses in time with the EDM in the background and it FEELS SO RIGHT and now I need a new pair of pants.

39355156.review:
Мне эту игру подарили. Я присмотрел её давно, но своих средств на неё не хватало.

До установки мне казалось это аналог NFS и подобных гоночек но более красочный, в футуристическом стиле и элементами выживания на дороге (не попасть под огромные пилы или внезапные столбы и шипы). Однако я ошибался.

Это не гонки с виживанием, о нет. Это гонки для задротов-пианистов. Вся суть не в красоте самой гонки, а в цифрах кто быстрее пройдет и многие хитрят, например сразу долетая до выхода, а не проезжая по трассе. Да, большую часть времени можно даже не ехать, а именно лететь, на "пузике", ломая пальцы для контроля доп.турбин и двигателей. Именно это на мой взгляд и ломает всю красоту игры. Люди не хотят проходить трассу как задумали разработчики или создатели карты. Но тем не менее игра найдет своего любителя.

К плюсам можно отнести неплохую оптимизацию, хорошие саундтреки (хотя и надоедают т.к. их мало и слушаешь одно и тоже) и красочную графику (огни, переходы между мирами, даже космос..). А к минусам увы можно отнести своеобразный мультиплеер (вдвоем не поездить на одной трассе, только в режиме призрака) и отсутствие сюжета, хотя и были намеки в Adventure mode. 

Однако меня игра не зацепила. Наверно потому что вся сложность не в логике как пройти трассу, а чисто в моторике пальцев. Для быстрого прохождения надо мастерски уметь использовать двигатели по бокам, внизу, сверху и .... и просто не хватает кнопок удобно это использовать на клавиатуре. Возможно я бы и играл с другом, но как я писал выше - вместе на одной трассе без режима призрака не поиграть.

39275087.review:
Distance is a great game. It's kind of like a platformer but with cars and the ability to go pretty much anywhere there isn't a killgrid. At the moment it's still in development but there's still enough content to keep you interested in the game.
 Easily the best part of the game has to be the workshop. Levels are pumped out almost every day, and some of them are as good as the dev's levels, and a lot harder too. But if you're planning to buy it for a console you'll have to do without that, and it would probably not be worth it.
 Lastly, the game can be pretty laggy if you have an old or just average computer, so you might not have a chance to see all the visuals in all of their awesome glory if you don't have a good computer, but the fun, fast-paced gameplay makes up for any of that. If you like arcade racers and platforming fast-paced goodness with a friendly community that makes a ton of levels, then this is a game you'll love.

39192400.review:
This game is f*****g amazing!

If you've watched the new Tron movie and enjoyed the racing scenes this game is for you. While it may not be Tron it perfectly captures the exitement and intensity of racing in that kind of environment. The strong soundtrack mixes perfectly with the exiting visuals to create a racing experience unlike anything else on the gaming market to date.

Distance does have a learning curve and starts slow but by the end game it's an absolute joy to play. It gets so many things right and feels like it's a game designed by gamers for gamers. 

- It runs silky smoothe on my gtx 970 at a consistent 60 fps.
- SPLITSCREEN MULTIPLAYER!
- If you're racing solo it will put you up against the ghosts of other players.
- The community is fantastic and many player made levels are just as good if not better than default levels.
- The car handles very well.
- This game can challenge even the most hardcore racing fans and still be fun for beginners. 

I only have three critisms of this game.
1- The music is great but there's not that many songs, give us more.
2- There's only one vehicle. A bike would be a perfect addition to this game.
3- The only customization available is for changinging the colors. Let us change the model, let us change our stats, let us design our cars to look and handle like we want it to.

Finally, I have to say thank you to the devs. Thank you for making such an incredible and unique game and I hope you make it better so it can be as popular as it deserves to be.

38999639.review: I thoroughly enjoyed this game. All the tools are there for an advanced racing experience. Even failure was fun - stuffing up a jump to lose the top half of my car, still sticking the landing; attempting a jump just to realise you were actually upside down, falling off the track; forgetting you can't fly in a zone and smacking the platform because you mistimed your jump. Difficult sections were rewarding no matter how you approached them - whether you fluke through them the first time on a miracle or brute force your way around with an abuse of mechanics. With more familiarity you can trick out the most difficult segments on record times. I look forward to seeing more updates.

38269032.review:
Distance is probably one of my favorite arcade racers of all time. Well, technically it's not a racer, it's more of a survival time attack, similar to games like Trackmania. 

Distance's objective is to avoid obstacles and navigate towards the finish as fast as possible, which isn't entirely unique. What DOES make Distance unique, however, is the abilities the car (called the Refractor in-game) has for the player to take advantage of. The Refractor can jump, fly, and use thrusters on it's top to spin in air, help with turning sharp turns, and grip the track. Because of this, levels can have you jumping from wall to wall, performing tricks to regain boost, and finding shortcuts to jump/fly to. The best part about this though, as advertised on Distance's store page, is that you don't even need to stick to the intended path. If you find a shortcut by flying between two buildings or cutting off an entire section of the level, then you're free to do so. So many players have gotten incredible times on various levels by going off the path and finding possible shortcuts to use. These shortcuts can be easy to do sometimes, but most of the time it takes skill to pull them off, making it that much more rewarding when you get a better time because of it.

The levels are the best part of Distance. There aren't many official levels to choose from, but the real content comes from the players. Because of how much you can do with the level editor, there's a huge amount of player-made content to play through and experience. You can have levels that are story-based, horror-themed or just fun and challenging. The game's developers have even said themselves that they simply cannot do better than the community at creating levels. That isn't to say they won't still make levels, but the user-made levels are what most people are going to be playing at this point because of it.

Here are my pros and cons for this game:

Pros:
- Tight controls
- Gorgeous visuals
- Very high replayability
- Nice soundtrack
- One of the best level editors out there
- An endless stream of community levels that are often better than the official levels
- An active and friendly Discord community that holds events for the game on Saturdays (called "Speedy Saturday")
- high skill ceiling

Cons:
- No dedicated servers so port forwarding is needed if you want to host one
- Little activity outside of the Discord community
- Can be hard to get better at (I still have trouble with advance techniques like grip flying and I play this fairly frequently)
- Controls can become hard to use on harder levels (I recommend either using a keyboard or a controller with flipper buttons like the Xbox One Elite controller. Otherwise you'll have to look for a guide for the best way to setup a normal 360/Xbox One controller to get the most out of the controls)

TL;DR If you like arcade racers, then get this game and join the Discord community. Maybe find a controller with flipper buttons or stick to the keyboard if you really want to get good at it.

37891667.review:
Distance is part arcade racer and part platformer and is the spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush (both games share some developers). The basic premise is that you are a futuristic rocket car that needs to traverse a glowing cyberpunk city filled with deadly traps and obstacles. You must utilize your car's unique abilities like flying to cross large gaps, and boost jumping to vault over obstacles or even leave the road completely. You can even drive on walls and ceilings!

There's a short story mode that drops hints at the city's myterious past; as of this writing, it's really just an extended tutorial, but the developers are working hard on a much longer and improved version. Thankfully, this isn't all there is to do; there is a robust level editor that allows things like animated scenery and importing custom models and a Workshop with thousands of player made levels already availiable or you can leave things to chance and use the procedural track generator. There are leaderboards for every track (even the fan made ones), so you can always go back and try to get the best time. The game also has both online and local multiplayer for racing and special modes like Stunt (perform tricks to earn the most points) and Reverse Tag (one player is "it" and has to avoid everyone else).

Visually the game is [i] amazing. [/i] Having most of the graphical settings on high makes almost everything look like it came straight out of a big budget sci-fi movie, but you can keep things on lower settings and the game will still look really nice. The soundtrack is another high point with pulsing electronic beats that fit the setting well and sync up with the visuals with flashing lights, but if it somehow isn't to your liking you can use your own music during regular gameplay and the visuals will sync with that as well.

There's really not any bad things I can say about this game. The developers have done a good job of updating the game since release and have been very engaged with the community. Though there isn't a lot of "official" content avaliable right now, there's definitley enough to get your money's worth. If you want a loud, flashy, and intense stunt driving game then Distance is for you.

37852570.review:
There isn't a whole lot to the game, but that is kind of the point. It's a driving game with pleasing visuals and upbeat music. There is a short story which gradually introduces you to track mechanics and the goal is to just make it to the end. Free play includes sprint/race and stunt modes, which can be played alone or online. The workshop is full of additional tracks and the game itself features a procedural track generator.

For being quick to start and light to run and non-aggressive in nature, this is my goto game when I need something relaxing to play for a few minutes. Personally I prefer playing with a controller as well.

I look forward to future development, but I would be happy with the game even if it recieved no further updates.

37836217.review:
Pros+

1. Spectacle: This is a very stylish game.  Reminiscent of the movie Tron, it has appealing geometric designs as well as neon lights that come together to form a sleek and eye-catching look.  This combined with the blur as you hit the boosters on your car gives you a good sense of speed, which is a must in a racing game.  Though under some circumstances the flashy lights can be a little overwhelming, that’s something more limited to some questionably designed custom maps, and I didn’t find that to be the case for the default tracks.
2. Variety: As mentioned before, there are custom tracks shared through the workshop, meaning that there’s a ton of free content beyond what you get from just downloading the game.  From my experience, if there’s a kind of track you want, it more than likely exists in some form on the workshop.  Worst comes to worst, you can make it yourself through the editor.
3. Complexity: Complexity is tough.  Too much, and a game can implode by overly dividing the player’s attention.  Too little, a game becomes simplistic enough not to warrant more than a few playthroughs. Distance does a pretty good job using its complexity to add variety to its gameplay.  You drive a car.  Though unlike your traditional car, it can boost, jump, wall ride, and fly.  These abilities all lead to  an array of possibilities for drivers to tackle obstacles and hazards, making Distance an interesting platformer-racing hybrid.

Cons-

1. Keyboard Controls: Distance can require you to go pretty fast.  Add to that the fact that obstacles can spawn out of nowhere and tracks can have crazy turns, a higher steering sensitivity is necessary at times.  However, due to the nature of keys, being either on or off, any precision steering can be extremely difficult.  So, either you have low steering sensitivity, where you’ll crash into objects you can’t dodge effectively, or you have high steering sensitivity where you overcorrect and crash into something else.  Perhaps there could be a key that you could hold for a lower steering sensitivity and release to return to high?  Sure, you could buy a controler, but for those of us short on cash, it'd be nice.

37690479.review:
This isn't a traditional racing game. There's no opponents to beat, there's no timer you're against, you can die as much as you want and the only penalty is a longer end time. 

That being said, this game is incredibly fun bar a few issues with the community (Not that is a valid critique against the game, more of a heads up). It's bright, neon graphics are reminiscent of Tron and the gameplay is fast and addrenaline pumping. 

The courses in the game are creative and interesting, sections usually include long straights of dodging pop-up walls or laser beams that cut your car in various pieces depending on the impact (A very fun feature to play with), flight segments in which one must fly through hoops to cool the engine down and ensure you don't detonate mid flight and tight turns.

This game isn't a race game against the game itself, it's a race against your reflexes. Are /you/ fast enough?

£15 may seem a little pricey for what it is, but given the community support (currently some ~2,700 community levels) and built in map editor, the game has good replayability and frequent updates, so this game is far from abandoned.

36688510.review:
I'm still not sure what to think of this game after playing it for a little over 40 minutes.  It was a long, strange trip.  It's very shocking playing a racer like this in first person mode, behind the steering wheel where the track can lead in any direction.  At times it's frustratingly difficult to even see the track.  There are traps everywhere.  Your vehicle disobeys the laws of physics.

At times it feels like you're skating.  It surely doesn't handle like any earthly vehicle would.  It's a good thing you're in a neon-cyber world with it's own rules.  The more you drive, the more you learn what the game wants from you.  How to best attack the different puzzles around you.  In the end, time is your only enemy and your mind is your only friend.   At least in single player.  

This definitely is a very unique game for VR.  And it works surprisingly well.  I would imagine if you're prone to nausea then this isn't the game for you.  Just get ready to experience something your eyes will probably not forgive you for.  

Rate 7/10 must get if you love challenging racers, where half the challenge is to your eyes

36544167.review:
*Pros and Cons below my short thoughts*

In short, Distance is great for what it is. Currently it has maybe a few hours of actual content, if hurtling through neon sci-fi tracks in your car to a pounding retro-techno-minimal beat is your thing, not including workshop map content (this is massive for the game to have, a great addition). I don't personally think it's currently worth the $20 asking price ($10 would be the maximum I'd pay for something like this) especially since I can complete the whole game in under the refund limit, and refund it, coming back to it when it's more fleshed-out. But for what it CAN be, it's worth every dollar. If they add some solid AI, extend some of the levels to make them longer, and flesh out the game some more while it's still in beta and before a final release, it's going to be a hell of a game. But for what it is, in early access, it's still a solid pickup. Perhaps when on sale.
Gameplay: 9/10
(Non-workshop) Content: 6/10
Soundtrack: 9.5/10
Replayability: 8/10 (this would be improved with the addition of AI, and a more lively MP scene)

Pros:
- Soundtrack (every track is great, and the ability for the game to work with existing songs I already have is icing on the cake)
- Level design
- Core gameplay is down pat, as it should be for a beta
- Soundtrack (yes it's that good)
- Low system requirements

Cons:
- Content (this needs to be massively expanded in the beta phase. Not just for the "Campaign" mode, but in general)
- No AI (this should also be added before final release. At the moment, the best part of each level is the bouncing visuals, and the soundtrack. The game needs to feel more lively. They should also be present for workshop maps, using things like upcoming collision detection, proper navigation, etc. to ensure they can work on any track.)
- (some) Levels are overly short. I finished the Campaign in just over 30 minutes, and a lot of them would be improved just by adding AI to them in the arcade alone.

36165577.review:
Insgesamt kann man das Spiel jedem Rennspielfan empfehlen... Allerdings nur im Sale!
Es wirkt schon so in sich geschlossen und abgestimmt, dass man den early access daran lediglich im noch etwas geringen Umfang des Spiels merkt. Es ist kein single player in dem Sinn, als dass man eine Kampagne durchspielt. Das Spiel ist darauf ausgelegt online gegen andere, bzw. deren Bestzeit, anzutreten. Darüber sollte man sich klar sein, wenn man den Titel kauft.

Positiv:
- Die Spielmechanik. Das Auto lässt sich wunderbar direkt steuern, auch bei hohen Geschwindigkeiten.
- Das Leveldesign. Die Strecken sehen wirklich unfassabr gut aus
- Der Soundtrack. Die elektronischen Beats passen perfekt ins Spiel
- Die Lichteffekte. Wenn der Beat richtig drückt und die Lichter der Strecke im Takt pulsieren, dann ist die Atmosphäre der 
Wahnsinn und es hyped einen ungemein!

Neutral:
Die Bestzeiten sind nicht mal ansatzweise zu knacken, da solche Zeiten nicht auf der Strecke gefahren/erreicht werden, sondern durch skipping der Streckenumgebung. (Wen das interessiert kann mal bei youtube nach "distance track skips" schauen). Das führt meiner Meinung nach das Spielprinzip ad absurdum... aber ist ja noch early access ;)  

Negativ:
Die Entwickler spielen stark mit Gravitation: Man muss regelmäßig an Wände und Decken springen, streckenweise auch fliegen. An sich ist die Idee echt super und passt auch in die Spielwelt! Aber die Steuerung in der Luft und bei Sprüngen ist dermaßen schwammig, dass sie für häufige Frustmomente sorgt. Dadurch wird bei manchen Strecken der Schwierigkeitsgrad automatisch angehoben, und zwar nicht durch ihr Design (das wäre ja absolut in Ordnung und auch gewollt), sondern durch die Steuerung. Echt ärgerlich dieser Mechanismus, aber auch der einzige Kritikpunkt, der mir aufgefallen ist.

Es überwiegt somit eindeutig das Positive an dem Spiel und deshalb kann ich es auch getrost weiter empfehlen!
Grüße

The Hot Wheels game i never played!

The moment i saw this game in the discount section it immidiately reminded me of my childhood game called Space haste 2, it was a game about futuristic hover cars racing and these 2 games share a few things here and there, they both have a boost button and both are set in the neon/futuristic kind of world. and this game is what i wanted in that old game just more and better! 
oh yeah and if you loved hotwheels as a kid, this game is definitely for you!

Pros:
- The game is challenging, in a right way. i mean upside down, i mean sideways.... i mean... you get the drift ;)

Cons:

Un excellent jeu.
Les graphismes sont bien fait et la soundtrack de base (car on peut aussi mettre nos propres musiques) est sympathique et colle à l'ambience de jeu.
Mais le plus important dans un jeu de course (dans cela ce n'est clairement pas le réalisme), c'est le gameplay, qui est extrèmement bien réalisé, une difficulté élevée mais sans être un Dark Souls, un mélange de passages aériens/terrestres, à une vitesse décoiffante.
Dommage que les updates se font rares car du coup il n'y a que peu de circuits officiels mais l'éditeur de niveaux permet de voir un contenu workshop de très haute qualité.
Il y a aussi la présence d'un mode multijoueur local/online, que je n'ai pas encore testé mais qui semble prometteur
Bref pour résumé, je ne peux que conseillé ce jeu, c'est le meilleur jeu de courses indépendant que je connaisse, et l'un de mes meilleurs jeux indépendants.
Il mérite un 9/10 !

36137075.review:
Distance is an awesome game! It perfectly brings high speed, gravity, obstacles, atmosphere, sounds and graphics together!! This game just looks awesome, especially the blurry effects, the high speed concept uses this advantage perfectly and one of the best things is that you never get bored! The adventure mode is, sadly, pretty short, but it's been so much fun to play it! But this game is still a beta game, and more content is to come.
This is one of the best high speed racers I've ever seen, and when you, even just a bit, like racers, get this shit, you'll love it!
Trackmogrify isn't that precise and doesn't know them all ( it didn't manage to return me love or hearts, just red ). But this doesn't make the game any worse since it still knows enough keywords that there are thousands of possibilities, even though these tracks are really short.
I'm playing with a keyboard and my problem at first was to get a keybinding that makes sense. I'm still not too happy about it, but maybe it's just the amount of car abilities that makes it.
What I really have to mention here are the gameplay elements... You're not dead when you drive through a laser. You're not dead when you fall of the track. You may lose some time, but that's the awesome thing about this game, you can just play and drive, jump and fly around and all this, and this is really really fun. You fall off the track, activate your wings and fly up to the track right in Batman-style. This is just epic! When you run through a laser, you'll lose a part of your vehicle, but at long as you don't lose wheels, you're just fine! This differs this game from others, because they are really frustrating by punishing EVERYTHING with a total failure. This game doesn't.
( > Beta! )
Graphics: 9/10
The best thing to mention is the blurring effect and the powerful neon colors. Some parts of the HUD overlap others, for example the replay controllers in the finish screen. The on-car info-screen just looks awesome and is very innovative.
Sounds: 9/10
Awesome beats which perfectly support the atmosphere of the game. Still, not everyone has to like this genre. Sound effects are awesome.
Controls: 8/10
Awesome on the gamepad, not really nice on the keyboard. Since you can't use your mouse during a race, please let it vanish.
Gameplay: 10/10
The perfect combination of gravity, saws, stompers, boost and everything, awesome potential!
Single-Player: 8/10
Cool gamemodes, which may not motivate you to play too long though. Trackmogrify is a nice thing, but longer tracks would be nice.
Multi-Player: 9/10
That's actually the strenght of this game. The bad thing is that nobody plays this game.
CONCLUSION: 9/10
Awesome game which could use some improvements to simply get "perfect".

36134223.review:
Distance is a mix of platforming and driving, and it works perfectly.
It's fast paced, the soundtrack is great, the visuals are stunning (and the optimisation is really well done, running everything at max settings & getting 60 fps!)

Most importantly, there is no RNG, everything is a result of player's input, be that a death or a bump into something, which really got me hooked up since it aids speedrunning, routing and all that stuff.

Even though the Adventure Mode is quite short, there is still a lot of room for trying to improve your times, do stunts, competing with other players online and, perhaps most importantly, playing custom maps or even auto-generated ones!
Didn't regret buying the game, waiting for more updates on story mode & full controller support.

35214514.review:
TLDR::  Distance: Nitronic Rush 2.0

Well, after you root around through the settings menu a bit.  Keyboard controls are sorta mushy until you turn off digital input smoothing and ramp up control sensitivity, menu animations just need to stay turned off for everything ever made at all times THANK YOU, and for whatever reason they changed the key for wing deployment.  While we're at it let's just turn off "Flight Landing Assist" because autopilot is for the weak.  After that, you're back in control, and the game becomes super fun.  

The game is still fun with all of this stuff stuck at default, but it WILL screw you over in tight, technical strings of precise maneuvers.

It is an indisputable step forward for the franchise.  Everything is more polished.  Everything is smoother.  Meaningful features have been added and implemented thoughtfully.  Meaningless features are nowhere to be found.  This is how sequels are DONE.

So what if you haven't played Nitronic Rush?  The music and sound design are superb, and it has very good, and fairly challenging track layouts.  The tracks are a good deal denser and more furious than just about any racing game I've played, F-Zero GX notwithstanding.

It falls squarely into a difficulty I like to call meditative.  Nitronic rush was similar in this regard.  It's not insufferably boring everywhere but the corners like Gran Turismo, and it isn't way up there in the unbridled and unrelenting insanity that F-Zero GX revels in.  It chooses a path where you must always remain focused, but never trespasses into mental fatigue.

The best advice I can give for you to determine whether or not you like it is for you to play Nitronic Rush all the way through, once, then peruse the hardcore levels a few times.  If you like those, and you like how it feels as you watch yourself progressively improve, you'll like Distance.

34772988.review:
[i]Distance[/i] is a fun arcade title that you can waste 5-10 minutes on in a single sitting before you're ready to do something else.

I have some gripes with Distance, ranging from mechanical problems to visual design, to track layouts and more:

1. [i]Distance[/i] requires that the player holds the boost button at all times. The only time the player ever lets go of the boost button is when the car is about to blow up. This only ever occurs in the short moments before reaching the next checkpoint.
Very little thought goes into using boost, the player rarely has to manage the mechanic in a smart way and it's mandatory to use boost at all times. It also feels boring to drive without boost. Furthermore, you're only ever going to drive around without boost if you've collided and had to restart at the most recent checkpoint, as the game doesn't refill boost completely after a reset. Boost feels mostly meaningless and really only serves to make the player hold down another button.

2. [i]Distance[/i] does a poor job of indicating when certain mechanics are not available for use. There are segments where you might like to fly, only to discover that flying is disabled for that segment. Not being able to fly when you think you are usually leads to crashing the car, which leads to having to reset which gives you a good reason to just restart the entire race. The only time you're not going to restart a race is when you're initially learning the layout of a track.

3. The single player levels do a great job of making you play with all of the various mechanics that the game offers, such as wall riding, driving upside down, jumping over obstacles and so on. However, the developer created levels are mostly completely linear and don't really offer a very exciting racing experience. [i]Distance[/i] does a great job of challenging the player from a mechanical standpoint, but the level design never branches out beyond the linear design of straight-forward on-rails driving. In [i]Distance[/i] the variety in levels comes from rearranging the mechanics that [i]Distance[/i] offers such as flying, jumping, riding walls and so on rather than offering track layouts and design that vary greatly. It's like the levels are a deck of cards that are endlessly shuffled around. But it's still the same deck of cards.

4. Visibility issues place emphasis on memorizing certain track segments. The roads are see through and often end in such a way that you're caught unaware and drive straight off a ledge. The first time you drive off a ledge you reset and push through to plot out the rest of the level. Now that you know the layout you restart the entire race for the gold medal.

[i]Distance[/i] is a pretty game, but also suffers from poor visibility. When you can't see what's coming up ahead you often crash. On the first playthrough of a level you spend your time memorizing the layout. Once that's done you then go back to get the gold medal. I didn't find much challenge in this. Rather I felt like a rat in a maze.


There are some pros to [i]Distance[/i].
The controls are highly precise and the game runs well. The game handles well and at no times did the game feel unresponsive or sluggish. The racing elements are well done but end up being restricted by other elements of the game's design.
[i]Distance[/i] did succeed in entertaining me for about an hour, but ultimately feels like a high end usermade modification that I'd expect to play for free inside another title rather than a standalone title going for the current asking price of US $20.

Distance is much more of a platformer/flight simulator than it is a racing game. It's not really about getting to the finish line as fast as possible, it's more often than not about getting there _at all_.

The narrative of the game alludes to the game world being a virtual one, being corrupted by the virus, and our car, being an antivirus algorithm of sorts, has to get to the core of it to restore it (or at least, it was this way in its Nitronic Rush days). The virus, naturally, tries to prevent itself from being deleted, and sends obstacles our way which just so happen to look like lasers, saws and other pointy things capable of slicing our car in half. Literally. And the best thing is, this doesn't mean "game over" - you still can control what's left of your car and, if you're lucky enough to make it to the checkpoint, your car will be restored. Good luck with it while airborne though - cars with one wing sliced off usually don't make it very far...

Apart from official maps and ones made by fans in Workshop (which are great as usual) there is a cool feature named Trackmogrify, where you can ask for a specific track (e.g. "long tricky green track with lasers"), and the game will generate such a track for you. No kidding. 

Overall it's a great one-of-a-kind game vith awesome visuals and soundtrack, and I can't recommend it enough. Try it, chances are you won't regret it.

I can't remember the last time I was this enamored by a video game. One of my favorite features is Trackmorgify which generates semi-random tracks based on the seed you enter. Later I discovered that unlike most games which just hash an entire string and stuff it into a random number generator this one seems to break up your seed into parts and looks for certain keywords to guide the generator. I definately recommend this game!

33819882.review:
Few racing games can ever hope to become as good as Distance is, even at the beta stage.


This games utterly nails all the things one of these hyperactive racers needs:

Handling - The car feels great, expect nearly limitless grip and blistering speed at all times on the road. The flying is simple and you won't take more than a few seconds to adapt to the transition. The in-air thruster corrections are a bit more fiddely but that is largely due to the 12+ hours spent playing on the old model versus the newer version in the game.

Music - Dark, heavy, electronic, syncs well with enviroment, what more could you ask for?

Looks - Running at max settings this game is a cyperpunk's wet dream. The vibrant contrast of colors in the accents against the industrial/sci-fi backdrop really make you feel like you are the only thing alive in the universe-until you aren't.

Story - A story mode in a racing game? Sounds odd, and given the recent games with garbage stories [spoiler] like The Crew [/spoiler] I can't blame you for being hesitant. But don't even let that sway you, this one is fantastic. I've always been a fan of storytelling through enviroments and this is among the best in that regard. You can comletely ignore it or for the more eagle-eyed you can see the story woven into each and every level.

Customization - Change the colors of your car or start making a level from the in-game editor. Too lazy to build a level? There are tons of workshop levels that are on-par or even better than the in-game ones. Still to lazy to download? Use the Trackmogrifier to make a level from a seed word or number and enjoy a randomly generated level that you can race on.

Multiplayer - Fast matchmaking and good stability. Play against others and show off how good (or bad) you are.


Distance is a blast. Hardcore racers will enjoy the effort put into the game and the satisfaction of mastering it, and even the non-hardcores will find their fun in the arcade styled handling. I wish I had a VR headset to experince this game afresh and relive the hours on end of enjoyment.

Completely recommened at the full price, a no-brainer at any kind of sale.

33746565.review:
"Distance" is an arcade-style futuristic racing game, developed by the same team of DigiPen students behind "Nitronic Rush" as a spiritual successor, although it could also be compared, at least in terms of gameplay, to the "TrackMania" series. Despite being under the dreaded Early Access label, what we have here is already a consistent and comprehensive enough experience that should give you a fairly clear image of what to expect from the final release, whenever that is supposed to come out.

The game consists in surviving several gauntlets by jumping, flying and weaving around obstacles such as laser beams, rotating saw blades, walls that pop out of the ground, among other traps, as well as maneuvering your way through the gravity-defying twists and turns of the track itself. The car handles pretty well, with just the right amount of oversteering you'd expect from an arcade racer to support last-second reactions. Maneuvering on vertical surfaces and transfering from wall to wall may feel very awkward (frustrating even) to a certain extent, which will make some of the stages look very intimidating. Once you get the hang of the controls, however, it all should come through fairly naturally.

Among the game modes at your disposal, you have: Adventure, which is (for now) still pretty short and puts you through a series of increasingly difficult tracks and also gives you a rundown on the game's mechanics; Arcade, which includes Sprint (racing to the end as fast as possible), Stunt (scoring as many points as possible within a set amount of time by tricking your way around a "rink"), Challenge (very brief but intense obstacle courses), and Trackmogrify (where the game randomly generates a track based on the provided seed); and Multiplayer, which still boasts a small yet dedicated online playerbase.

You're also given a very flexible level editor that allows you to come up with complex tracks that can include triggered events and custom props, among other things. The creative community for this game is great, regularly submitting new tracks to the Workshop. Most of their levels are pretty clever and elaborate, and can range from races with emphasis on speed to insane hair-pulling trial-and-error challenges, encompassing most if not all skill levels and play styles.

Presentation is somewhat reminiscent to that of "Tron" and "Neon Drive" in its neo-futuristic approach. The game makes extensive use of HDR and bloom, along with shiny, reflective surfaces and stark contrasts of color put against a predominantly black background, achieving this atmospheric, sort-of night drive feel — that is, if the whole city was a huge nightclub with all the lights pulsating to the blasting house music. Generally, the game is very upbeat, but it can also get pretty dark and moody, eerie even.

In conclusion, it's safe to say that "Distance" is going in the right way. Of course, there's still a lot of room for improvement that hopefully the developers will wisely make use of with the next updates. Right now, however, we have a product that does what it sets out to do pretty decently, which is to offer a fun, laid-back racing experience that, even though it won't change your life or the way you think about arcade racers, is surely to keep you entertained, even if just for a while.

The average Distance race:
-Playing splitscreen with your friend, you start a randomized(trackmorgified) level.
-As you start, you realize that the finish line is way below the start line
-Your friend follows the course, while you jump off the side of the track and start driving down the side of a building.
-You hop between the walls of tron-like neon buildings, expertly transitioning from normal driving to the flight mode. In between jumps you pull of crazy tricks to regenerate your boost/jet fuel.
-You are right above the track before the finish line, boosting yourself straight down, but you see your friend approaching quickly.
-Last second, with only inches to spare, you pull up and land right ahead of your friend! Victory is close!
-In your excitement, you didn't see the final saw on the track. You ram it, and it splits your car in two.
-You keep pushing forward with the remaining left side of your car, your friend perfectly neck and neck with you!
-You hit the finish line and don't even check who won, because the game is so unbelievably cool and you need to write a  positive steam review immediately

Seriously must reccommend, plus the graphics are stunning with a decent gaming build.

33287080.review:
This felt like the game Cloudbuilt met TEC met HotWheels (for PS1) except with better graphics. In other words, this game is a speed-based trick game that will have you flying and parkour-ing (is that a word) off walls. For early-access it feels like its on the right path, but checking some comments, users have been mentioning this game hasn't been fully released for a few years. I would say make sure to do your homework on this one before you decide to buy it.

Distance can be considered a racing game. It takes a lot of elements not traditionally found in racing games and really uses the environment to amplify the danger of racing. I'm not talking about taking tight corners or overtaking on a turn, I'm talking about avoiding lasers, random blocks that will appear, flying objects that will plant themselves in front of you and tracks that will assemble as you drive. The game feels familiar as the driving scheme is effective and simple, but the abilities the car used in conjunction with the amazing environment makes for some solid [b]gameplay[/b]. The control scheme of the car is more tight than loose. For the theme of the game it works really well - otherwise I would be complaining if this was Dirt 3 or Shift 2. I like the rigid turning style only in certain games that rely on tricks. The car has a visual bar at the back to notify the player if they are over-using boost. If you over use boost, your car will blow up. Jump is another feature in the game that can be used at any time. This feature will be needed when you need to wall or roof ride. The car can also fly when required. Flying is relatively easy and the player can literally go anywhere when they are in the air. Be careful though, the flying scheme uses boost as well and can heat up the car pretty quick. 

The [b]visuals[/b] are pretty rock solid and follow a neon sort of Tron glow. The effects in the level are pretty intense especially at high speeds. The scene is sort of like a picture when you're speeding along dodging lasers shooting from the sky and giant saws ripping through the floor back and forth. The graphics are sharp and the levels feel decently full of effects and animations. The [b]sounds[/b] were done pretty well. There are levels where you will be rocking out to the music and other times where you will be a little afraid because the level, the animations and sounds are all eery. The game does a decent job immersing the player in this random neon-Tron universe. 

Overall, the game is good - but there is still a lot of work to be done. The adventure mode, arcade mode and split screen is fun, but I feel more needs to be added to make it a well rounded game. I see potential for mini-games and other online/local modes. One can only hope as an early access back-er. Again, I liked it - I felt like I paid a little too much - so definitely wait for a good sale and definitely do your homework. My advice to the dev would be to continue to add different environmental effects (track appearing as you drive sort of stuff) and maybe battle elements the car can do against other cars ? 


RATING : 6.9/10

33253512.review: This game has a lot going for it. First off by itself I'd say it's an above average racing game. It has enough base mechanics with the thrusters and jump. Which by themselves are simple concepts but the creativity put into the dev made maps make all the levels feel unique and fresh. But creative is a word that needs to be saved for the community made maps. This game has easily the best set of available community features since forge in halo. Most of the time you spend in this game will be constantly trying out new community made maps that range from recreations of iconic race tracks from other games to things seen in film and tv series. Not to mention this games soundtrack is stellar. While not effecting gameplay to an extreme it adds an atmosphere not felt in many other racing games. There are not a ton of games that impress me with their score ad this is definitely one of them. Only downside to this game that I see is the the graphics aren't very clear at points and the gameplay can be a little repetitive if your only playing on similar dev maps or player made maps. This game is decently more of a game to sit a relax to. The intense hard levels can be interesting but a lot of times it can just feel frustrating due to the sheer amount of controls for your vehicle which makes deaths unsatisfying a lot of the time. This game has a rhythm to it that I like in the well made levels, but you will definitely waste your time on some bad levels. This is an above average racing game with excellent community features for me this is a 7/10 for the amount of things you can do with the community features which is what holds it up.

33221790.review:
Do you like FUN? Do you enjoy going FAST?
Do you fancy bright neon colors, and cybertronic sci-fi visuals reminiscent of TRON?
Do you love a good CHALLENGE? Then this game will have you HOOKED.
Everything in this game just gears perfectly into each other, the entire race track oscillates and flashes to the soundtrack, the soundtrack changes with the pace of the track, the entire game world is the digital embodiment of the word RADICAL.

Speaking of which, you gain access to an infinite amount of race tracks generated by typing random words in TRANSMOGRIFY and to top it all off you get customosable cars and 4 player split screen.

This game is well worth it's price and very close to the finished product, i am very happy with my purchase, good job Refract Studios!

33098856.review:
This is an amazing game. It's not a racing game, but an obstacle course/run type experience with incredible ambience and graphics.....feels like a young Kubrick if he took the end-movie aesthetics of 2001 and then did Tron.

The game's official levels are about 2 hours' worth of gaming but the level editor and the community workshop make this game almost infinitely replayable. The general ambience and neon aesthetic makes this potentially both exhilirating and relaxing at the same time....it's really an addictive experience.

About the only negative I can imagine is that there are some later official levels which require a lot of tricks and dexterity. If you don't play for a bit, it can be easy to forget how to pull some of the stunts off, which ultimately requires replaying some official levels to requaint yourself with how to jump from one wall to the next while spinning and hanging upside down....stuff like that.....which if you're in the mood for "relaxed techno cruise mode" may not be what you want to deal with. Fortunately there are a ton of workshop levels that cover every possible style and experience the game has to offer.

I remain impressed....this may be one of the only Early Access titles I have picked up to date that was both well worth it and which I really frickin' love.

32789415.review:
Achja, Distance. Ein lange bei mir beliebäugeltes Spiel, welches ich jetzt im Sale erworben habe. Da ich total kein PC-Snob bin, habe ich dieses Spiel getestet, angespielt und gebe meinen Senf dazu. Ich will noch anmerken, das diese Review sich in 2 Teile teilt: Das normale Gameplay und einmal das Gameplay mit einem VR Headset (in diesem Fall eine Oculus Rift CV1).

Kommen wir zum Speck der Geschichte.

Part 1: Das normale Gameplay

Gameplay: Das Gameplay in diesem Spiel ist echt in Ordnung, gerade für einen Early Access Titel. Das Spiel lässt viele Manöver zu, man ist nicht auf die Strecke an sich beschränkt, es ist sehr schnell und hektisch. Das Spiel ist fordernd, belohnt einen aber auch für so manch eine riskante Aktion. Die Checkpoints sind sehr fair gesetzt, sodass man permanent boosten kann und so ein sehr schönes Gefühl von Geschwindigkeit aufkommt. Das Gimmick, dass die Strecke einen versucht aktiv zu behindern, ist mit Nitronic Rush und ähnlichen jetzt nichts neues, aber immer noch sehr willkommen.

Steuerung: Die Steuerung ist zweischneidig. Für jeden, der ernsthaft spielen möchte, würde ich empfehlen einen Controller zu benutzen, da dies die beste Art der Steuerung ist. Auch nur auf diese will ich ier eingehen. Die Steuerung ist sehr Arcade-lastig, da man Kurven sehr haftig annimmt, Aktionen sofort eine Reaktion erzeugen. Die Steuerung ist aber sehr solide, und die Buttonbelegung ist jetzt nichts schlechtes. Das einzig gewöhnungsbedürftige wäre hier das ausrichten in der Luft, welches ein wenig Übung erfordert.

Grafik: Ja, das ist für manche auch ein Punkt, also erwähne ich diese hier. Die Grafik in diesem Spiel ist recht gut, Modelle sehen sehr schön aus, die Effekte, vor allem die Lichteffekte, sehen super aus und passen perfekt zu diesem Spiel. Die Lampen des Levels blinken im Takt der Musik, die Sägen sehen immer noch bedrohlich aus und man hat eine schöne Weitsicht, welche in diesem Spiel auch vonnöten ist. Das ganze läuft bei mir in höchten Einstellungen extrem flüssig und ruckelt auch nicht. Aber dies kommt auf das jeweilige System an.

Musik: Ja, dies Musik ist auch was. Es gibt Songs welche eher in die Richtung "Naja" gehen, während andere einen sehr schönen Takt haben und auch einen dazu antreiben, noch schneller zu sein. Die Musik passt sich aber nicht um den Spieler herum an wie z.B. in Nitronic Rush, sondern sind an das Level gebunden. Wem die Musik nicht gefällt, der kann auch eigene Tracks in das Spiel einbauen.

So, kommen wir zur Königsklasse.

Part 2: VR Gameplay

In diesem Part liste ich nur das reine Gameplay auf, da Steuerung und Musik gleich sind. Okay, ich hab gelogen, ein wenig zu Grafik werde ich auch sagen. Fangen wir an.

Gameplay: Das Kern-Gameplay ist identisch mit dem des Normalen, nur das man anstatt außerhalb des Wagens in dem Wagen sitzt. Dadurch hat man dann einen First Person Racer. An sich ist die Idee super, nur kommt hier der größte Kritikpunkt: Das Spiel ist extrem unangenehm zu spielen in VR. Es ist viel zu viel an plötzlicher Bewegung, viel zu viele Dimensionen und extrem unübersichtlich, da man extrem schwer was voraussehen kann. 
Ich bin kein unerfahrener VR Spieler, und spiele EVE Valkyrie im PvP, ja ab und an sogar War Thunder in VR. Bei diesen Spielen merkt man aber weniger, dass man in einen solchem Gefährt sitzt, noch haben Aktionen wie Loopings etc. größere Auswirkungen auf einen. Distance hat aber zu viele feste Punkte welche an einem Vorbeirrauchen, man sich aber selbst nicht bewegt. Dies führt zu einem ähnlichen Effekt als wenn man rückwärtig in einem Auto sitzt. Es wird einem extrem übel. Also, wer sich dieses Spiel für den VR Teil holt, sollte einen sehr sturmfesten Magen mitbringen oder am besten gleich kein Gleichgewichtsorgan haben. Auch hier wird ein Controller empfohlen.

Grafik: Die Grafik ist größtenteils die selbe, nur hier ist der Cockpit Part wichtig. Dieser sieht relativ gut aus, auch wenn ich bei einem EVE doch was besseres kenne. Dies ist aber Geschmack, und es ist ja noch ein Early Access Spiel. Aber das HUD an sich ist sehr nett und übersichtlich in das Fahrzeug integriert, und bei mir lief es auch extrem flüssig.


Alles in allem ist Distance ein sehr gutes Rennspiel gegen die Strecke, welches viel Spaß macht und eines der besten Early Access Spiele ist, im Gameplay, in der Grafik und der Musik. VR Spieler sollten sich eine wenig zurückhalten, aber jeder, der solche Spiele mag, sollte zugreifen.

32771498.review:
Distance is an arcade racing game(duh).
Pros
The game looks good, and the graphics are good.
There's a lot of things you can do in this game
The grip of the cars

Cons
The adventure mode; you get in and play, thinking it's supposed to be a good and fun activity, the first maybe two levels were actually enjoyable.
The controls was confusing, the side thrusters was annoying and the air control felt dumb; basically, when you get in the air you have to stop controlling your car, because it'll react to every movement which is made. When you jump, you can't hold forwards because you will faceplant your car, if you hold backwards you do a half backflip landing on your back, it feels annoying.
The visuals. Yes I did say that the visuals were good in this game, that's because they are. But it's a trainwreck when you're driving; there's so many things happening around you that you don't know where to go. I often asked myself if I was about to drive into a wall or not. There's also no useful visual assist in the game. Whenever you learn to do a new shiny thing in the adventure mode, it tells you that you can do that thing, but that's also the only thing it really tells you. It doesn't show where you have to go, there was a point where the track split in two and of course, I drove in one of the directions (they connected at the end), but it told me I was driving the wrong direction. Apparently you had to jump up, and fly upwards, in the middle of where the track split.


I asked myself "What the -profanity- is going on in this game" about every 30 seconds, because it felt like that.
Will I recommend it to a friend? No, I won't. Unless they fix some of the issues I won't be picking this game up again.
I came into this game with an open mind, but I am disappointed.

32713651.review:
Before we start, if you're reading these reviews and are still trying to make your mind up, go play the predecessor of this game for free to get an idea of what Distance is all about: http://nitronic-rush.com/

The good: 
[list]
[*] Very active and friendly community which has created over 2000 levels already and most of them are really good
[*] Interesting car features: jump, boost, full air control, wings
[*] Different gamemodes: A story-based single player campaign [NOT YET FINISHED], Time Attack, Challenge [tricky tracks which are hard to navigate], stunt mode [do tricks and earn points], tag match and trackmogrify, a mode that generates levels according to words you feed into it!
[*] The tracks are visually great and interesting from a game mechanics standpoint: You'll drive on the walls, on the ceiling, do corkscrews and loopings and evade obstacles.
[*] Great soundtrack which enhances the cyber-retro feeling of the game. And you can implement your own music very easily in the options.
[*] The game is very much in active development, no worries that this will stick in Early Access forever. Apart from the missing campaign this game does feel quite polished and finished already, if development would cease right now I'd still be happy with the game I got.
[/list]
The meh:
[list]
[*] The sense of speed is there but sometimes the game doesn't feel very fast. This varies greatly from level to level and some community tracks can feel really fast, others really slow. 
[*] Can be a bit hard to find online matches, even though there is a community racing event every saturday and you can play this game solo.
[*] Solo Campaign is not yet finished and will be released when the game is done. For an idea of what to maybe expect from the story mode, try Nitronic Rush linked above.
[*] Performance is mostly good but can be a bit shaky, especially as some community levels are not optimised. The offical levels run perfectly.
[/list]
The ugly:
[list]
[*] Even with 2000 community levels, it can sometimes feel like there is only a limited amount of content because you only have one car model and the obstacles on the tracks tend to repeat.
[*] I am not a fan of the motor sound of the car, which is a repeating low wubwub sound. It is not aggravating but it is anything but interesting either. I guess it doesn't matter if you turn up the soundtrack.
[/list]

32691218.review:
Daaaaaaamn this one is good ! If, like me, you like the design and atmosphere, and sound design of Thumper but you don't have the reflexes of a robot, this might be the game you were looking for. Not that it has no challenge - it actually gets pretty hardcore on the latest track now available - but its driving game mechanics is by nature more forgiving than Drool's core gameplay based on pure rythm.

The game's motto and description describe it quite well : it's a survival racing game. All you have to do is get from point A to point B, but many traps will be laying around on your path. Lazers, saws, grinders and walls popping up 10 meters from you are the most obvious, but the track itself gets pretty tricky. The road suddenly stops ? Well, might as well ride a wall or even the ceiling, the gameplay allowing jumps and various methods for controlling the car mid-air and even flying on some portions.

But what impressed me most is how deeply the music fits what happens on screen. Unlike Thumper, Distance is not a rythm game and as such music doesn't directly come from your actions - though sound effects are really well integrated. But it is still highly dynamic with music dynamically changing to fit the atmosphere of the track, getting more violent as things get tricky or more minimalistic and strange when the track allows for contemplation.

Note : the game is currently in early access, but the gameplay is already perfectly balanced and probably matches the final product. Developpers are now adding tracks to make the campaign slightly longer, but a track editor is available as well as steam workshop, meaning the content is already almost infinite. Which means there is no reason not to jump in already !

32240990.review:
Distance is a racing arcade type game with all sorts of possibilities within it sense the creators allowed a workshop to bring players together. 

You could be playing on a map that is nice an easy ride to something like the map called "Jelly" with parkour style brought into racing. Create a few different playlists from the workshop maps and have fun playing wiht friends online or make a public lobby so other random players can join in on the racing/parkour fun. 

Side note: some people might say Distance's MP is nonexistent, but those people would be wrong. What is true; is that you have to be on at the right time zone to be able to find people hosting a server or have a group come in to play with you. 

ALSO!!! Do the tutorial!!! I know lots of people might hate or would want to skip it, but it'll help largely in the long run. You might fail a lot your first few tries, but trust me. You'll get better. (Tutorial is basically the campaign.)

32202889.review: Distance is a challenging yet fun racing game with elements not often seen in other games. You have your car, track, and all the elements of a normal racing game, but Distance adds obstacles, jumps, flight, and other mechanics that make the game truly unique, which they created a name for: Survival Racing. The graphics of the game are amazing, and compliment the futuristic feel of the game with a theme reminiscent of the movie Tron Legacy (2010), with the lights popping out against the darkness of much of the game's environments. All in all, Distance is a uniquely fun game, and I'd reccoment it to anybody who likes racing games.

Distance is a nice game, with a cool concept, fitting music and well-optimized graphics.

Pros:
Concept is unique, something you dont see everyday
Graphics are great
Great optimization
Music fits the game perfectly, just what you'd listen to if you were racing like this

Cons:

but if you want to play with others then you should skip this.

31638433.review:
早在 2011 年就曾接触过 Nitronic Rush（氮气冲刺），这款游戏的前身。对本作感兴趣的朋友可以考虑试玩前作，它是免费的。

Distance 作为后续的商业版本，除了画面变得更细腻之外，可玩的赛道地图也多了起来：不同的赛道及玩法让它变得更有可玩性，再加上支持创意工坊里的自制赛道，或是自行设计赛道（一开始应该会很麻烦吧，打开编辑器感觉无从下手，毕竟是三维空间的赛道地图）……闲暇之余邀上朋友一起，1P 用手柄，2P 用键盘一块玩，岂不是美滋滋。（游戏的赛道基本上都是单程（One-shot）的，不知道有没有跑圈类型的赛道，没试过）

赛车类型的游戏剧情一般略显空乏，与前作剧情类似：一座虚拟的城市受到病毒感染，玩家操纵着载具，通过层层通关，抵达核心，净化邪恶。本作中游戏仍以一处科幻空间为背景，通过驾驶高度智能化的载具进行通关。

需要注意的是剧情模式还没制作完成，但游戏中行进到这一关的时候是相当耐人寻味的，这一点，玩到这一关的人应该会会心一笑：它通过模拟的“黑屏”进行了一些提示，然后让载具重启回到标题界面。随着开发商的投入，我们也先期待一下完整的剧情模式上线。

在操作上，与常规、诙谐、硬核类赛车游戏皆不同，游戏中的载具除了能做出常规机动之外，还有跳跃、飞翔、吸附、翻滚等等动作。这也是一开始我就不将它称为赛车（Racing Car）而称其为载具（Vehicle）的原因。前作中硬核模式才出现的，以贴墙跑（需要从地面赛道通过技术手段翻滚到左侧墙面或右侧墙面）或是垂直翻滚（从地面赛道弹起以吸附到头顶侧的赛道）为核心操作的种种技巧在剧情模式中就需要用上了。好在，剧情模式一开始的新手指引（英文）很充分，玩家也能循序渐进地解锁并掌握这些操作，实现通关的目的。

游戏中的音画也相当出色，无论是绚丽的光影效果，还是光效随着音乐的律动而响应明暗变化、亦或是载具被毁时音乐瞬间加上低通效果，每一处细节都增强了反馈。音乐方面大多是 House 类型的曲风，它们稳重但富于变化，让人在刺激的竞速过程中稍微能静得下心来。

要点总评：

- 支持双人同屏游戏（未尝试，孤独的单身狗）
- 沉浸式的科幻载具竞速体验（让人想起了立体机动）
- 完美、富有挑战性的各类赛道地图
- 绚丽的画面及实时同步的音乐
- 支持创意工坊，丰富的自定义赛道地图

先玩玩免费版的前作，如果觉得很符合自己的口味，那就入手吧！

附 1：iPlaySoft 对前作的简评 http://www.iplaysoft.com/nitronic-rush.html
附 2：多年之前本人初代 HARDCORE 模式试玩录屏 http://v.youku.com/v_show/id_XNDUwMDI2ODg0.html?from=s1.8-1-1.2&spm=a2h0k.8191407.0.0

31100543.review:
[h1]Distance je špičková závodní arkádovka úchvatného vizuálu, která tepe v rytmu elektronické hudby![/h1]

Tepe ... a to doslova, mezi vizualizační efekty autoři zařadili i světelné efekty určitých prvků, které pak tepají dle beatů a uživatel si navíc může míru efektů či třesení obrazu upravit dle libosti ... a přiblížit se tak kýžené blaženosti z epileptického záchvatu!

Během beta fáze jsem s volantem projel kompletní kampaň, která velmi příjemně narůstala na obtížnosti. Veškeré nové prvky jsou představeny a vysvětleny za běhu, reps. při jízdě a po tom, kdy byla aktivována celá škála, začala obtížnost velmi přituhovat.

I když je hra nedodělaná, nesetkal jsem se s jedinou chybou a i současný obsah hry je dostatečný na několik hodin zábavy, zvláště když je podpora split-screen či online hry. Pro tvořivé hráče autoři v menu hry zpřístupnili editor levelů s podporou Steam Workshop.

Jednoznačně doporučuji.

2. Next, the game would NOT release the camera look mode for the right stick.

Suggestions:

TL;DR:
Pro:

- Spaßige Physik und anspruchsvolle 3 dimensionale Steuerung
- Guter Soundtrack
- Schöner Grafikstyle
- Große Workshopauswahl an Strecken, von gutem Flow, bis zu extrem Anspruchsvoll
- Hilfreiche und angenehme Community


Contra:

- Etwas hoher Preis für das gebotene
- Zu wenige Online Spieler (hoffentlich ändert sich das in Zukunft)



Ich habe mir das Spiel ursprünglich rein zum anschauen gekauft und wollte es dann wieder zurückgeben, aber ich wurde sehr positiv überrascht. Distance überzeugt durch exzellent passenden Soundtrack und guter Physik und ist sehr vielfältig, aus dem Workshop kann man eine ganze Masse von Strecken aussuchen, die vom guten Flow, zum herunterkommen nach einem langen Tag, bis zu extrem schwierigen und anfordernten Strecken reicht.


Mein einziger Kritikpunkt ist, dass das Spiel durch seinen Onlinemodus erst richtig Spaß macht, allerdings viel zu wenig Spieler online sind. Lediglich abends findet man 3-4 Server, wobei positiv anzumerken ist dass die Spieler, wenn auch wenige, allesamt sehr nett und hilfreich sind und einem dabei helfen schwere Stecken zu meistern

30432693.review:
Distance is a combination racer and platforming game. The vehicle you race in is massively maneuverable, with jump jets and extendable wings, that allow you to race on tracks that break appart, shatter, do 360 loops, go upside down and back up again, demand clinging to walls and ceilings, barrel rolls, and all sorts of other intense maneuvers that slowly become second nature as you play the game. The tracks also boast lasers and traps dedicated to shredding your car apart - and interestingly, if a laser cuts your car in half, you're free to keep zooming along with half a car, hoping to make it to a checkpoint which will put you back tgether. The game's frantic pacing and trap layout means this happens more often than not, and you can actually be rewarded for cutting it altogether too close - a great and satisfying feeling.

The music is pulse pounding and goes along with the game great. Big dropping beats keep yoyu in the action and on the edge of your seat. Not much else to say here.

A level editor and a seed generator give you procedural tracks to race on, and levels made by other players to grab on and take, with a system for voting for your favorite ones, so the cream of the crop rises to th top. This ensures that new content is constantly being created and found for you to do. you can also always Time Attack your favorite tracks, trying to get better and better times and breaking the tracks with new shortcuts.

Finally, the game boasts multiplayer in various game modes, allowing you to play with friends, race with friends, blow friends up, and maybe (?) cooperate with them but you'll probably be too busy leaving them in your dust to bother with that.

The game is still Early Access, but there's plenty of content here for people who like to go real fast and fly real fast and dodge lasers. Don't be put off by the Early Access.  (Disclaimer: I got the game on a steep sale. Did not pay full price for it.)

30350855.review:
"Car Platformer"

That's the term I'd use to describe this game.  It's a car platformer.  It's everything great about video game car physics, plus more.  You can jump, you can spin, you can fly, and for the most part you have the freedom to do so whenever you want.

One of the greatest things about this game is definitely the freedom.  I don't like when racing games are just a track you have to go fast on.  In this game, though, if you get bored of the normal drive you can jump off the side and drive over all of the buildings and props alongside the track.  Granted, in the game world there aren't going to be a lot of extra places to go, but still.  Navigable scenery is a plus.

There's also the unnecessarily entertaining aspect of it where you can continue to drive after having your car sliced in half lengthwise.  That's a bit of an oddball feature that makes for some fun.

30201194.review:
[b]The good[/b]
- Track editor offers huge flexibility and spawned hundreds of excellent user made tracks.
- Cars can drive upside down, fly and jump, opening up more gameplay options.
- A high skill cap for an arcade racing game and leaderboards to show off your skills.

[b]The bad[/b]
- Tough initial learning curve due to complex control scheme.
- Game encourages taking shortcuts, increasing skill cap but restricting track designs.
- Very low active playerbase.

Tl;dr A spiritual successor of Trackmania but better in many technical respects and with much more depth to it. Its main drawback is that its active community may be dedicated but is also tiny due to a lack of advertising.

30180217.review:
Instead of telling people what I do and do not like about Distance, I would rather let everyone know what they need to expect from this game.

Distance is a fast paced racing game with incredibly unique mechanics.  It is the spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush, a game that you can download for free on the Digipen website.  Distance was designed to continue where Nitronic Rush left off.  Unfortunately, Nitronic Rush was so amazing that Distance had little room to improve on the mechanics of gameplay.  This is offputting for some people because Distance only adds a small amount of depth of play compared to Nitronic Rush.

Some people might expect a long campaign from this game.  Don't.  This game is very community oriented.  If you are not willing to play other people's tracks or to make your own, then this game is probably not for you.  However, because of the reasonably easy to use editor, you may be inclined to make tracks more than play them.  

Personally, I have spent most of my time on Distance making tracks.  Were they all good?  No.  Were they fun to make? Yes.  Track making is the main reason I play Distance, and it is something that I will always enjoy doing.  If you want a community oriented game or just want to make crazy tracks, then this game is probably for you.

I hope this review helps you!

Distance feels like an early access for a $60 game. It's polished, it plays great, it's unique, it's a work of art to be honest. It already has a lot of content even in this stage. I spent almost 3 hours finishing the single player and trying to get silver on each of the tracks and there were quite a few, I can't remember exactly but in the 15-20 range, plenty of tracks and they are all unique.

This doesn't even take into account that the game comes with a level editor and has a bustling community of users making tracks and thousands of users trying them out.

Here is a video of me playing one of the earlier tracks and only crashing twice:
https://youtu.be/WoSWVl7H714

I played on my HTC Vive which was what really made this a must buy for me. There aren't very many good racing games for VR and so when I heard Distance added VR support, it went from my wishlist to my library that day.

Later on the levels get hard but I didn't mind crashing a few times in order to figure out the tracks, and they all have different paths you can take and discover by replaying and exploring. Some levels encourage you to turn into a 'jet' and fly, and others take that ability away and force you to jump, wall ride, and barrel roll your way around obstacles. 

Check our the video, if you aren't convinced, come back after EA and hope they don't up the price too much. This is a steal at $20 in it's current state in my opinion.

30038577.review:
Really fun, good artstyle (reminds me of TRON), good music. Has a sort of "WipEout" vibe to it. It'll be interesting to see where this game goes when more is added to it, but as early access/beta/whatever games go, this is a solid one.

Only slight annoyances are the flying controls and the WASD booster things, they just feel a bit wonky (you have to operate and think about too many things at once, also the camera points itself in unhelpful directions while this is happening) and interrupt the smooth speed of the ground segments.

The Steam workshop functionality is well-integrated, meaning it's easy to play new community-created maps all the time, and even create your own. There's also online multiplayer which is pretty fun.

EDIT: It seems as though the most popular online maps are "parkour" ones which involve awkward mid-air maneuvering and tricky jumps, as opposed to speedy racing. I can't say I like these parkour tracks very much - they usually involve repeatedly failing a certain segment before moving on to the next one and repeating that process until the end, but even so, the online is still fun, and the community maps can be quite creative.

Overall if you like racing games, futuristic stuff and DnB, this is probably a game for you.

29678151.review:
Distance is pretty cool, I guess.

You play as Robot Car on your journey through a strange city like landscape who's roads just so happen to make a sick race trap. Robot Car was speed through the city, avoiding danger, harrowing death traps, hostile defense systems, and a strange alien entity hell bent on destroying Robot Car.
So it's basically Brave Little Toaster, only faster. 

Distance is a driving game where your main objective is to reach the end of the map as fast as possible without crashing or slowing down, the faster you go, the better your time ends up being. There is also a story mode where you have to go through a long gauntlet of tracks, but as of writing this review, the story mode isn't 100% completed.

Each track takes the form of a long street filled with twists, turns, loops, and traps, and your car has all of the abilities necessary to reach the finish line without turning into that strange red substance I find on my mattress. You have turbo, jump, flight mode, the ability to descend quicker, and wall/ceiling riding. 

Much like the clothing I steal from the back of goodwill trucks, the controls in this game are tight. Taking corners, drifting, flight, and jumps all feel satisfying and easy to pull off. There's nothing more satisfying than going full speed from wall to cieling to floor to wall to floor without slipping or crashing into the wall like a drunk suburban girl who can totally hold on to that mechanical bull. 

Distance's biggest bonus is it's multiplayer. Not only can you race others for best time, but there's a workshop in place where other players can upload the maps they made. These maps range from stinky maps that suck to maps that put all the tracks in the main game to shame. Some times you're tested to the limits of your skill as the creator throws everything he can think of at you without making it impossible. 

Should you play Distance?

Yeah, probably, do what you want, I'm not your dad. Distance is fun, fast, thrilling, and basically everything I want in my outrageous action games. Refract Studios, the developers of Distance also made another survival racing game called Nitronic Rush, which you can get for free off their website if you want a taste as to what you might get in Distance. I'd check that out too, because it's also pretty rad.

Length gets 8 walls popping out of nowhere and you're going too fast to react on time out of 10. 

According to JK Rowling, wizards are constantly crapping in their pants. Multibillion dollar franchise here, folks. 

The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

Link to Nitronic Rush: http://nitronic-rush.com/

29346961.review:
One of the best Racing games of this generation, It's like and extreme version of hot wheels with an emphasis on skill and surviving the track. 

If you get anything from this review take these first 2 paragraphs into account. The game is absolutely insane, never in game have i had so many moments that make you want to clutch your heart after a near miss of a saw blade or the gut wrenching feeling of taking a jump to just to realize you didn't take gravity into account and are now falling from the track. Even better yet tho is the feeling of making these mistakes and then through quick and crafty maneuvers recovering from your mess up without simply resetting to the last checkpoint. 

Now it seems that 3 of the main reasons people down rate this game are as follows. either they think the story is far to short and not worth the money, the online community is to small and have little servers running, or that they cant stand the music. Well let me explain why these should not effect your opinion. Firstly the story mode, Obviously its still incomplete. what they have is nice and when i first got the game a played it a bit and only did the story mode. after about 2 or 3 hours i finished it up and i to had the feeling that it was ok but may not of really been worth the money. However the Story mode is essentially just a tutorial to get you ready for the really great stuff. You see distance has and absolutely insane editor and some of the maps you play will feel worlds different from anything you've play previously. Many of the community levels have a higher difficulty level than the story mode the process of learning and attempting to play these levels are the best. What you play from the community levels will make your opinion of the game jump exponentially high. Now yes the community is small but its a strong community. I've rarely got to the server list and not had 2 to 3 games to join. Its not the kind of game that needs tons of servers. sure it could be a bonus if they had more but everyone is just playing a bunch of maps generally ranging from 5 to 15 mins levels and then rotating to a new level. Finally the music, personally i like it but more then a few people complain that they just cant stand it. Thing is the dev has an option to point the game to your own music library to play in game. With this enabled you'll get all the flashy effects of having the background lights of certain levels sync to your music or if you chose to enable it you can have music bars on your car window that move to the beat of the music. All In all its a great game, keep in mind theres a reason most of the bad reviews have such low gamplay hours. They didn't play the community levels, they didn't bother to learn how to play the game, or they didn't bother play online after seeing so little servers etc. Theres a reason the fanbase of this game while small is so strong and a reason for its 94% positive rating. 

The developers continually update it and what they have currently is just amazing. I believe the story mode is the last major thing that they will be adding to the game although i could be wrong as they my have even more up they're sleeve. They have many modes Sprint being the most prominent. 

The Sprint mode is Simply get from point A to point B. generally they'res a clear path and checkpoints to take however if you have the skill, knowledge, or luck you can take your car off track in an attempt to find a shortcut. 

trackmogrify - This mode lets you input any seed and it will randomly generate a track using it. It actually works surprisingly well

Challenge - a mode where you have nor resets, checkpoints and only one life on small tracks

Stunt - do tons of tricks to get the most points

tag - get the tag for as long as possible

speed and style - do the track as quickly as possible with lots of trick points 


All in all its a great game with tons of replay ability and i highly recommend it to anyone who wants a new racing experience unlike any they've had before.
