17231274.review:
Distance is an experimental survival racing game made by Refract, who previously released Nitronic Rush during their time at Digi Pen.  Nitronic Rush can be downloaded for free at http://nitronic-rush.com/.  If you are at all interested in Distance, play Nitronic Rush first, as they are very similar.

In Distance, you control a kickass sci fi car with thrusters, wings and a giant rocket booster.  You race through digital, TRON Legacy styled cities filled with lasers, buzzsaws and angry computer viruses.  While the new art style is very pretty, some clarity is lost behind all the bloom and neon lines.  In Nitronic Rush, obstacles and hazards were always a very bright red, while in Distance they can and often will be a similar color to the rest of the track, making it somewhat harder to see them at a Distance (heh). In addition, the world seems more lifeless compared to the 70's TRON world of Nitronic Rush.  While this seems to be a deliberate choice on Refract's part, given that Story Mode seems to focus on an abandoned world, this doesn't change the fact that the levels are rather sterile and samey.  With the exception of one song, most of the soundtrack, while great, is also very similar which is an odd change after Rush's varied beats.    

While the game is still in beta, it does have a slight lack of content when compared to Rush.  There are more Story levels, but fewer Challenge levels, and no Hardcore levels.  The overall level design is a bit more tame and safe than Rush's was.  There is both a track editor and a random track generator to make up for this, however, and many of the community tracks are incredible (and a good deal tougher than the rather easy official levels).

There are a few other game modes besides the races.  Stunt has you doing mad tricks in an arena to score big points, Speed and Style is a mix of Stunt and Sprint, Reverse Tag is a game of keep away/king of the hill, and Soccer is, well, soccer.  Stunt is rather boring due to the lack of an announcer, another feature missing from Nitronic Rush.  In addition, several stunts possible in Rush are missing in DIstance.  Speed and Style is good fun, as you have to win the race AND pull of tricks to win.  Reverse Tag is a fun game of wits, though the official arenas are all either too big or too small.  I recommend the community level "Pipe Plaza" for this mode.  Soccer is a mess, the ball is nearly impossible to control and  the levels are a cluttered nightmare.  It might be good for some couch laughs with 4 players (Distance features Split Screen for all modes) but should be avoided in smaller groups.

Now, despite these complaints, I still highly recommend this game.  It's the most fun I've had with a racing game in quite some time, and is beautifully creative.  Even if you don't like traditional racing games, give Distance (or Nitronic Rush) a shot.  They're very different from the competetion.

To finish this review up, I'll make a list of little things that you probably don't care about

-Default control scheme on controllers is flawed, thange LB to boost like it was in Rush
-Bring back the announcer
-Bring back wheelies and side wheelies
-While you're at it, just port all of Nitronic Rush's levels into Distance

Die Steuerung ist ... für den Ars**
Sorry aber wenn man Need for Speed gewohnt ist, dann ist das hier absoluter Müll!
Ja ich weiß, dass man die Steuerung selbst belegen kann, das problem dabei ist nur, dass die Tasten, die ich ändern will, schon mit anderen Dingen belegt sind. 
Dazu kommt noch, dass das Auto IMMER nach vorne fährt. egal ob du eine taste drückst oder nicht! und ich hab noch keine Möglichkeit gefunden rückwärts zu fahren.

16850322.review:
I'd honestly say this is one of the most entertaining racing games I've ever played. There's definitely not many games that require you to jump from wall to wall at high speeds while avoiding traps like lasers and saws while listening to fitting music before you've even completed the tutorial. Also the visuals look awesome, but it's not so overdone that you can't figure out what's going on.
It's one of those rare games where you can join a server, find one of the best players in the entire game, and still enjoy yourself.

To get the most out of it you'll need to play the community levels, since there's not many official levels. It's not a problem though, since a lot of community levels are on par with the official ones, and some are even better (plus the files are usually less than 1mb, so having hundreds of levels downloaded barely takes up any space).



Anyway, here's a quick summary:

+Looks and feels awesome
+Challenging but not frustrating
+Music fits perfectly
+Hundreds of quality community levels
+Procedural track generation (very early stages so will get a lot better)
+Doesn't get annoying if you keep failing
+Gravity doesn't even matter as long as you're going fast enough
+Improved enough from Nitronic Rush to justify buying

-Still no AI/ghosts (they'll probably be coming soon, but offline is a little lonely currently)
-Some of the dynamic obsticles can feel luck based, which gets annoying if you're going for a fast time
-Possibly a little harder to get good at if you have no controller

16804027.review:
This is shaping up to be a very fun little game. The art design and music are great so far, the city has a distinctly Tron-like aesthetic and the music in each stage really brings out the atmosphere. Despite having no story to speak of it's stages string together a visual narrative that not only keeps you from getting bored but brings out a modicum of emotion as well. The tracks are well composed, nothing is unfairly unforgiving and one is rarely left scratching his head while stuck somewhere wondering what he's supposed to do. All in all I'm excited to see the final product.

My only major complaint is the controls, or rather the way the game introduces you to them. Early on if you are using an XBOX controller it instructs you to use A to boost and X to jump. And early on this is fine, later you also need to quickly use the right stick which proves difficult. What the game doesn't tell you is that you can also use the shoulder buttons for boost and jump freeing your right thumb to do the tricky bits. But relearning the controls half way through the main game is kind of annoying. (As the game is in development this may all change)

Also, it plays your music for you, and since the devs have expressed an interest in increasing mod support (the way I understood it, at least), this is only gonna get better. This Distance is a fast and intense action survival racing game, where you drive agens other unique players in advanced atmospheric worlds.

Have you ever wanted to be in that Tron legacy world with laser, future and amazing cool music? Well, here is your chance to live it in a car and do alot of driving, jumping, spinning, flying, avoiding insane traps and tracks. 

The game has a unique design of it's own, where the Tron legacy atmospheric world makes your hearth beat faster. Overall controlls with either keyboard or controller is simple to use, where you get a decent movement of your car. The game allows you to spin, jump, fly and drive with a health bar that might overheat to destroy you. Every map or custom map through workshop has checkpoints that resets/cooling it down.

The music is fantastic, and makes you play all day, unfortunately the game has not unlocked the rest of the singleplayer, since it's in progress. The singleplayer campagin on the other hand throws you straight to basic's and into a interesting world of escape.

16612614.review:
Distance is everything I hoped for an more in a racing game. This game has brought the joy of racing back to me for the first time since Burnout 2-4, and it has a lot to do with the similar philosophy of expecting player to crash (that's part of the fun!) and letting them get right back to the challenge at hand as soon as possible.

The adventure mode, even in its current limited form is a non-stop ride of thrills, stunning visuals, and creative expression through racing. The first time I opened my car's wings and took flight I sat slack-jawed for much of the rest of the level and only stopped to laugh with pure un-fettered joy.

This game wants to challenge you, but it does not demand perfection. It wants to teach you, but it won't always hold your hand either. It wants to engage your curiousity and your creativity, in an activity that is so often highly regimented and finely tuned.

The community levels (so far) make more of a return to the familiar 'hard for hardness sake' design and don't always have such well placed checkpoints, but with the mechanics present in the game and the tools available I expect to find plenty of maps like the developer's who balance out elements of free running in a car (carkour?) and the already present intense eye-bleeding gauntlet runs.

16589074.review:
One of the few instances where I actually agree with the "Overwhelmingly Positive" average user review! A fast-paced, electronic-music fueled, somewhat story-based, flying, hopping, boosting, interdimensional, tricking, warping, and overall insane racing game of the future! The adventure mode campaign at the time of writing is pretty short, and they don't promise any kind of long drawn-out campaign but the official tracks that are in now are pretty high quality handcrafted and themed. There's also procedural tracks which I haven't tried out yet, seeing as currently there are over 700 community made tracks in the steam workshop - there's definitely no shortage of quality content. Add to it the ability to play your own music that the tracks' lighting and certain elements will sync to, and you've got an overwhelmingly positive game here.

My only complaints are the difficulty of adding your own music, you have to manually type in the path of the folder you want to play, and being that I use itunes for my ipod - some of my music are m4a files which are not supported by the game. It would be much nicer if there were a simple folder browser and some other formats were supported but it's not a huge deal. Could always make a separate folder just for this game and convert my files with dbpoweramp to mp3.

I've never really been too much into techno but the music in the game is pretty good atmospheric semi-psychadelic. Music that I like that I think goes really well with the game is Infected Mushroom (I'm the supervisor and Vicious Delicious) , Shpongle (Nothing Lasts... But Nothing Is Lost), those are the few good psychadelic artists I know of from a much trippier time in my life.

16549005.review:
Saludos

Introduccion: Bienvenidos, este es mi primer analizis de videojuego en steam, y decidi dedicarlselo a este gran titulo que me emociono antes y despues de adquirirlo.

Resumen: Un juego atractivo pero repetitivo, con mucho contendio por explorar y tambien por explotar.

Preguntas:

¿Por que lo recomiendo?: Por que con solo el contenido que nos da este acceso anticipado he quedado conforme, su comoda jugabilidad, su variedad de obstaculos, el ambiente dinamico-sofisticado, la agradable comunidad (...).

Tan solo la idea de que se viene mucho contenido por delante, y que ademas hay un apoyo constante tanto de fans como de los mismos creadores me da a entender que puedo recomendar tranquilamente este juego.

Este titulo me genero una muy buena primera impresíon, razon por la cual desde sus inicios estuvo en mi lista de deseados hasta conseguirlo, y aun sabiendo que no esta terminado, apenas tuve mi oportunidad (Ofertas Veraniegas Steam) compre y jugue feliz.

¿Que espero del juego?: Que mucha gente lo compre, que se motiven los creadores a aumentar el personal de trabajo para que aumenten la produccion de contenido (y que sea mucho!), y por ultimo, darle un final epico al modo historia, la cual tiene un concepto sumamente explorable y explotable.

¿Que aspectos no me agradaron?: Independiente de ser solo un acceso anticipado, tal como mencione anteriormente, el juego es repetitivo, un error tipico en juegos de conduccion, que aun cuando la variedad de obstaculos es amplia, no logra apalear el problema a largo plazo.

Parte de la comunidad dedicada al workshop a creado pistas sumamente copadas en detalles in-necesarios que, por ende, disminuyen considerablemente mi grata experiencia de juego (Escuche de jugadores que les iva a 2 FPs el juego en algunas pistas).

La falta de orientacion, independiente de sus aspectos positivos, me ha dado malos ratos en mas de una ocacion, ya que si bien al momento de jugar solo tengo todo el tiempo del mundo para explorar, en el modo online, donde la competitividad por el mejor tiempo es lo mas importante, esto genera desde luego un contraste en la ideologia de las carreras de autos.

Conclusión: Un titulo sumamente interesante para mi, me encantara ayudar en todo lo posible a que su desarrollo concluya positivamente.

Saludos Cordiales

Interesting concept and good sense of speed. Problem is the game is horribly optimized. I have a 970 and have to turn the settings down somewhat, and even then the framerate is all over the place. Even worse my friend has and i7 4790k oc'd with SLI 970s and he sees frequent frame drops. With a measly and laughable 8% - 38% usage of his gpus. The highest usage I've seen my 970 get is 47%. The fact that I have to struggle to get 60fps when I'm very far and beyond the recommended requirements is absolutely unnacceptable. It's crude to charge money for something so unfinished. For perspective; Crysis 3 on Very High runs better than this game on Medium. It's insulting.

Also, this game is not so much a racer as it is a driving platformer. The difficulty seems to be more centered around avoiding obstacles rather then driving skill and track design, so don't go in expecting it to be like Trackmania with obstacles.

Really there is a great game in here wanting to get out, but it's held back by lack of content and very poor optimization.

16515371.review:
I haven't taken the time to review that many games in the past, however, this game was too good to pass up giving attention.

Its been awhile since arcade racers were in their prime. People are lost to the unrealistic stupid fun genre that is arcade racers, Distance by Refract Studios didn't only remind me of that same rediculous fun I used to have in arcades, but grew on it in so many wonderful ways.

in 2011 the small indie studio released Nitronic Rush, a fun experiment using a physics engine built entirely by them in C++, and it was awesome. I got my friends to download it and they all loved it, it was such a refresher from the generic races that have been coming out in years past, the ammount of insanity involved is something I hadn't dealt with in a long time.

Then came Distance, made by the same studio under the name Refract, and it gave me that same rush as the first game. The game has cars going at a rediculous speed, set in a world similar to that of Tron, with flying cars, stunts, an amazing multiplayer and one of the most challenging but entertaining single player's i've been offered in a long time.

If you're on the edge about this game, just know you wont be dissapointed, Distance is one of the most refreshing experiences i've had in a long time, and im confident Refract Studios can only make it better.

Current Edit:  Having put a few hours into Distance, I can safely say my money was worth it, but for reasons many others may not benefit from, but hopefully a few may.   I suffer pretty severly from panic attacks (often leading to mild seizures) from time to time, mostly at night after dreaming about situations more fucked up than Im willing to describe.  I wake up sweating, my chest in a vice, diaphram contorted demonically, mind racing, heart about to explode...  I stumble out of bed, into my chair and manage to flick on my audio interface, boot up my computer and log in to steam.   Distance only takes a few moments to start and the music is soothing.  I always start with the first track, I forget the name... Broken Symmetry?  Regardless, the slow build up of piano, filter-modulated white/pink noise and easy curves wittle away at my stress.  Upon finding a sense of calm, meditative trance begins to set in.  The beat kicks up and I find myself no longer panicking, but positively charged, ready for challenge. My adrenaline flips polarity to positive and I am back to being ME.  No worries, no stress, no job, no lonliness.  Just pretty lights and sounds, a simple goal, and a sense of peace.  

I have not tried any workshop tracks, but I would love to see something in the form of straightaway tracks like the first few, with little challenge and more empahsis on cinematic thrill.

Initial Review-------

Playing this game is what I imagine driving a Tesla might feel like.

Sexiest sight/sound match in a racing game since Extreme G

Adventure needs to be more.. erm, adventerous... I loved the build up intro but it was the same as arcade otherwise.  Maybe there could be some enemy responsible for the obstacles, cliche but it would be cool to have some depth. I would also love to see some sort of upgrade system or at least some aesthetic customization, it would make 20 dollars seem acceptable.  I got it on sale at 15 and it's still a stretch of money at this point in the development, that being said I do not regret the purchase at all.

Will update.

16500364.review:
Ever since I was little, I was a huge fan of the Burnout racing game series. I played those games a lot over the course of a few years. Those games, however, made me create a standard for all racing games. If I felt a certain racing game did not meet that standard, I wouldn't buy it. In fact, In the past 7 years, I have only bought and played 2 other racing games besides Burnout. One of those, I didn't like, the other one is decent. 

When I saw this game, I was intriqued. It looked unique, but I still went by my standard. I decided that 10 dollars (on sale) was a fair price and purchased it. When I started playing, I realized this game did not meet any of the standards I had set. That was because this game was truly [i]unique.[/i] It's nothing I have experienced before. I've only played this game for a few hours so far, and haven't even scratched the surface of what you can do in this game.

The graphics in this game are stunning and it is well optimized as well. I can run everything on ultra and get 50+ fps. Even though it says Early Access, I have not encountered any bugs. It's labeled Early Access mostly because they have more content to add. If you enjoy using a controller like myself, they have good controller support as well. It has a level editor, allowing you to make custom levels and then share them on the Steam Workshop. It has nearly unlimited levels, just type in a phrase, and it will generate a random level. It has multiplayer, allowing you to play with others on any map you want. It also has a singleplayer and split-screen mode. And to top it all off, it's only 20 bucks (not on sale), which makes it even better.

To be honest, I can't really think of any bad things to say about this game. If I encounter anything, I will update this review.

In conclusion, this game is a unique racing experience unlike anything I've played before. There are so many good things about this game, and the developers are continuing to add more content. I highly recommend this game to support it as it develops.

16473442.review:
As a 'Nitronic Rush' player there are lots of things I like about this game, but there are also a few points which I'd like to adress (note that this is a beta).

Let's start with the good stuff:

*Amazing style & graphics
*Intense music
*Great athmosphere
*Smooth gameplay
*Lots of different areas and modes to play in (race, challenge, stunt etc).
*A multiplayer (both online and splitscreen, which Nitronic Rush didn't include, not in real time that is).
*A level editor
*Good gamepad support


And the less good things (along with thoughts):


*I have an up to date and strong computer, yet this game sometimes has major framerate issues! Especially during the multiplayer (I'm not the first one complaining).

*This game would benefit if it featured a 'drift' system. As it is now the breaks feel a bit off and stiff. I think drifting would make this game extra intense (maybe even awarding the player with points/small nitro bonuses for a good drift?)

*The engine/nitro sounds were a bit soft and dissapointing, especially in comparison with Nitronic Rush, which felt much more faster.

*In Nitronic Rush there were big spinning blades on which you could drift/slide. Why not make those without the teeth as a drifting platform in a few areas? (as an extra).



Still this game is extremely cool and well made thus far, and don't forget it's still in it's beta state!

16472945.review:
Когда я покупал эту игру на распродаже я ожидал просто Tarckmania но со стилем а-ля TRON, но в итоге я получил одну из лучших гонок в которые я когда либо играл!

В этой игре нужно доехать из точки А в точку Б по эдакой гоночной полосе препятсвий с циркулярными пилами, шипастыми давилками и лазерами. У нас есть волшебный автомобиль который может передаигаться по стенам и потолку, прыгать и даже летать (причем летать можно почти везде!). Уровни в этой игре зубодробительные и очень веселые, вам нужно использовать свой автомобиль на все 100% чтобы пройти их.

А если вдруг вам надоест играть на стандартных уровнях (которых пока-что маловато) вы всегда сможете скачать их из мастерской или построить свой в местном (весьма мощном) редакторе,  если же вам лениво то можно воспользоваться генератором случайных уровней. Если ехать из точки А в точку Б это не для вас то можно играть в режим трюков, где вам нужно делать различные сальто и катания по потолку чтобы зарабатывать очки.

Даже в раннем доступе эта игра полностью оправдывает свою цену особенно если вам не хватаает переполненных адреналином аркадных гонок.

Distance очень схожа с Trackmania, т.е. в основе игры - битва с таймером. Правда трассы здесь больше похожи на смертельные полосы препятствий с циркулярными пилами и лазерами и выскакивающими заграждениями, чем на обычные гоночные треки. Но и наша машина не из простых - потеряв часть корпуса она продолжает ехать вперёд "на своих двоих" до ближайшего чекпоинта, умеет перепрыгивать препятствия, ездить по стенам... Да чего там, даже летает, расправив крылья! Игра запоминается футуристическим дизайном в стиле "Tron", бешеной скоростью и динамичным саундтреком.

На данный момент игра позволяет пройти часть немногословной, но чертовски красивой кампании, а также сразиться с таймером как в одиночку, так и в режиме split-creen и по сети. Есть менее популярные режимы вроде игры в "салочки". В игру встроена человеческая поддержка пользовательских карт из Steam Workshop, которые загружаются на лету.

Последнее обновление добавило в игру генератор трасс и поддержку кастомной музыки. Причём неспроста - элементы трассы, неон на машине и даже окружение теперь ненавязчиво подыгрывают в ритм вашей мелодии. Как по мне, так результат затмевает AudioSurf, особенно если включить "Boombox mode".

Настоятельно рекомендую, перспективная игра.

Distance is a really fun game and has you dodging and diving between objects to reach your final goel. the adventure mode has a great experiance that will push you and challenge you to start with, once you have mastered that, sadly there is not musch else to challenge you besides the workshop. This does not mean there is no more content because oh boy is there more content. there are random geniration maps so that is infinate fun and also challenge mode and user maps, so yeah there is a lot.

BUT the game really leaves me craving more speed and more split secound decisions. i really feel that they should make the tracks a tiny bit wider and add more speed and faster handeling later on in the game. i love the game and i love the small challenges it offeres but at the moment after playing it for a little while i feel i have mastered it and i just really want more speed and variation.

TLDR
Game is fun with a lot of content
fun to get good at, can bore when mastered
needs more speed with better handeling (only add better handeling if more speed is added)
limited variation
short tracks

Im going to give this game a thumbs up, because i really enjoy it and its great fun to play, i just feel that it has the possibility to be a great deal better if it was made harder with longer tracks and more speed.

16462390.review:
The prototype was just splendid, and the real deal is very worth it. I love that this game does so many new things for a racing game, or at least things that you don't usually see together: hazards that can slice dynamic portions off your car, wallriding, ceilingriding, seamless manual transition from car to plane mode, right-stick-controlled manual rotation for midair orientation and tricks, a level with some pretty legit horror elements, well executed Tron aesthetic, track editor with workshop support, random track generation, and a friggin' JUMP BUTTON.

It would take far too long to extoll the virtues of everything I think this game does awesomely, so instead I'll list my peeves: there's a relatively meager list of preassembled tracks insofar, the randomly generated tracks (while pretty dang neat) are way too short, and the process of jumping and rotating to cling to a wall where the track abruptly ends is a bit more awkward than it should be.

A laser sheared my front wheels off and I drove my sparking front half to the next checkpoint to repair and keep going. 10/10 would inflict self-harm with lasers again.

16461938.review:
Distance is what Aperture Science would have created if they had watched Tron Legacy. This game is absolutely gorgeous! I had to buy it the moment i played it in my friends PC. The visual, the gameplay, even the credits is a masterpiece! If i had to choose the top 3 racing games i've played this decade, i'm sure Distance would have made it second or even first position.
Enough with the compliments, let's talk more about the game.
Distance is a futuristic racing game like nothing else. You are in control of a car that can boost, jump and fly (yeah, it's a transform). The game has a storyline that feels a bit artistic. It has no narrative, just you, the stages and the musics (that i have to say, it fits just perfect with the game). Since it is still Early Access, it isn't complete yet, but i can already see it developing really good!
The arcade mode seems to be really good, even better when played with a friend or in online mode. And now with custom tracks made by the community, i can't even describe how big is the potential of this game.
BUT, it has it cons (for now, it might change in the future). In current stages, there is no bots in arcade mode. I feel like this is needed in every racing game, mainly in this game! I want to play the arcade mode when my friends aren't avaliable and online mode isn't quiet what i'm looking for everytime.
The storyline NEEDS a narrative. Sometimes you feel a little lonely when traveling through the stages and the music is low. The storyline of this game shows potential and a narrative like the one in Portal games would fit just perfectly.
If i would recommend this game to everyone in this planet? OF COURSE! This game needs more attention! I would easily pay 60 bucks for this game when it gets out of early access. It really looks like a AAA game.

Plus, spin my car in the air and land it like a boss IS SO DAMN COOL! 10/10

16456105.review:
This game is very interesting, none the less. Even if your taste is not in racing games, it is a good pass time if you're overwhelmed from playing that Multiplayer game you typically play when you wake up in the morning. God knows when I am annoyed after playing Rust or Counter Strike: Global Offensive that it's these games I like to turn to. Overall, Distance has very many wonderful mechanisms to it. Gravity being a very affected party of this game; you need to understand how the physics of this game works if you want to play it properly. Once you get the hang of everything, however, you start to receive a lot of enjoyment out of playing the maps that are preset in the game, and even custom ones made by the community. Not only does Distance have wonderful mechanics to it, but it also has a nice developmental structure to it, and what I mean by that is it includes its own level editor, and you can make maps, such as a Rainbow Road and a Mario Kart map I've already took the liberty of playing on. I can say that this game is very enjoyable as a "I have spare time and I'm not doing too much," type of game. Almost like listening to music or watching Netflix while you're idling in your game server trying to get rid of that TF2 item you don't like.

The only problem I have with this game is the Multiplayer. You have to set up your own server and typically invite people to your game, because there are not a lot of random public servers to play on. They are all typically private for friends or a group of people. If they had a matchmaking feature like Left 4 Dead 2 does, then that would make Multiplayer a bit more appealing in my eyes.

Overall, I do enjoy this game, and hope that it's carried out in development further than what it is now.
Wonderful potential here, just don't end up like a lot of other Early Access games that are, very unfortunately, "In early access" for two and a half years and never actually goes anywhere often. Yes, that was a shot at DayZ. Sorry!

16453609.review:
A much simpler and less gripping Nitronic Rush for the weak of will and poor of heart. I've been playing arcade racers since the dawn of time, and this game is an utter joke compared to anything from its predecessor, Nitronic Rush, to F-Zero. Tracks offer low complexity obstacles, no need for boost management, and long stretches of road that give you nice eye candy but a severe reduction in challenge overall. If you've never played an arcade racing game before, or if you self identify as a casual gamer with a love for being held by the hand in your games, I would recommend this game to you. Otherwise, look elsewhere.

Just because a game is in Early Access doesn't mean it should follow such a dull design philosophy, as is the case with Distance. The game's track design is completely devoid of challenge, and if you're lucky you [i]might[/i] find one decent track in a half-hour of scrounging through the Steam Workshop.

Worst of all is the "Trackmogrify" feature. Even though the game's pre-constructed track design is already insultingly dull and unchallenging, the developers have added a track creator that spawns fresh tracks that are just as dreadful as, if not worse than, what's already built into the game. Just like the first time you are called a "donkeyball hosedick" or "bullcock hobgoblin", you will laugh a bit at how poorly you've been insulted but also feel a little stung at the same time.

tl;dr If you really need to spend $20 and don't know what to do with it, do something more productive like flush it down the toilet

16451878.review:
Call me a dork, but I would never buy this game on sale. It is worth every penny the developers have put on it's price tag, and here's a lazy amateur breakdown of why:

[b]• It looks amazing.[/b] The game really is very atmospheric, with great sense of speed, and every level feels unique. It's arcade with personality, and pretty great graphics. Honestly, I don't need to say much when there's beautiful screenshots up there.

[b]• It sounds amazing.[/b] As with Nitronic Rush, the music is one of the greatest things about this game. Even if you don't like the genre as much, you'll find it fitting and very well crafted. Not to mention it interacts with the level, making lights blink to the beat and things like that.

[b]• It plays amazing.[/b] When we talk about controls in this game, it's important to note that you actually feel you're in control. Which is very important, considering this is survival racing. You often need to act fast, and everything is as responsive as you'd expect. Oh, and the delirious stunts you can pull make you feel awesome. And when you successfully recover from a mistake instead of resetting? That's the stuff.

[b]• The developers are extremely passionate[/b], and very good at what they do. That combo means a handful of things: They are very thorough, listen to the community feedback with great care, and in fact get really involved with the player base. A chance to play with one (or more!) of the devs online is barely difficult.

[b]• It's got a powerful level editor.[/b] And people make the most amazing things with it. It's got primitives, which means you can basically create anything you think of, if you have the time. As a matter of fact, most of my play time was spent in the editor. Creating is fun, and sharing is easy.

[b]• Failing is often surprisingly fun to watch.[/b] Being suddenly flung out of the track, spinning ferociously, crashing into a nearby building, and exploding into many pieces, all in a matter of seconds... It can be a good laugh. Why be frustrated? It looks great even when you suck.

This is one early access game you can trust. It's the most polished and feature complete beta of a game I've seen, and yet it seems to only grow and improve further. 

Buy this game, buy this game, [b]buy this game[/b]. Sorry, that's a bit pushy.

16430833.review:
This game is super good.

There's not much of a story of to it yet, so to speak. In a nutshell: You're a car, and shit got fucked up somehow, so you have to unfuck it by driving really fast. And that's about it because early access.

Gameplay wise, it's solid. You have two sticks, two triggers, and two buttons. Fairly simple, but then you learn you can drive on walls by jumping onto them, and it's really rather good. You can also fly, and that opens up a whole world of opportunity for track skips.

Graphically it's pretty good as well, so yeah.

The soundtrack is exactly what you'd expect from this sort of game: Lots of EDM and dubstep. And surprisingly, it works. However, if that's not your thing, then you can play your own music so that's good too.

But what's really, really, super good about this game, is that the developers put in a random track function, which generates fairly short tracks to race around based on a seed you put in. This essentially turns the game into the video game equivalent of potato chips: You start with just one, and then you do another, and then next thing you know it's two hours down the line and you've eaten the whole bag.

And the workshop's pretty good too I guess.

Overall 9/10. Like skyrim, but with cars and laser grids.

16429944.review:
Hätten Tron und Trackmania ein Kind, das im All aufwächst, dann wäre das Distance. Trotz "Early Access" steht es schon heraus als ungewöhnlich geiles Rennspiel.

Gameplay:
Am Anfang ist es noch einfach. Einfach der Strecke nach, die sich ein wenig durch den Raum windet und dann auch allmählich mal überkopf steht. Dann kommen noch Brüche, Sprünge, Flugeinlagen und tödliche Kreissägen und Laser, und das alles bei rasender Geschwindigkeit.
Trotzdem werden einige Stellen auf den Strecken frustrierend, da die Fehlerspielräume zunehmend kleiner werden.
8/10

Atmosphäre:
Die ist bei diesem Spiel ein Gesamtkunstwerk, allerdings muss man das Genre mögen. Der Tron Grafikstil ist wie erwartet gekuppelt mit Electro Musik, wobei Beleuchtungen der Umgebung im Takt der Musik blinken. Wenn man Unfälle baut oder in schwerelose Räume gerät, ändert sich auch die Musik, wird ruhiger, und sobald man wieder zwischen Laser und Kreissägen gerät, wummert der Bass wieder fröhlich weiter.
Die Grafik an sich ist schön detailliert, es fliegen munter Funken, das Auto wird durch Aufprälle deformiert und Laser zerschnitten. Ebenso der Sound passt super zum Stil, einzig der Nachbrenner verursacht auf Dauer Tinitus.
9/10

Story/Setting:
Das Auto, das man durch die Story steuert, die nicht von Erzählung begleitet ist, ist nach einem langen Schlaf erwacht. Es hat eine Störung in einem überwachten Sektor gegeben und man macht sich auf, um dort nach dem Rechten zu sehen.
Über mehrere Sektoren, wie hier die Strecken genannt werden, gelangt man in gut zwei Stunden zum Ende der momentanen Storyline.
7/10

Bedienbarkeit:
Das Tutorial ist in der Story inbegriffen, anfangs wird man noch sehr an die Hand genommen, jedoch wird man schon schnell mit Rotation, während man in der Luft ist, und dem Flugmodus konfrontiert. Es ist einfach zu lernen, aber schwer zu meistern.
Controller werden unterstützt, Lenkrad ist obwohl dies ein Rennspiel ist, nicht zu empfehlen. Ich habe selber auf Tastatur gezockt und bin damit nach etwa 3 Stunden gut zurecht gekommen.
8/10

Leistung:
Für den angemessenen Preis von knapp 20€ bekommt man ein super aussehendes und klingendes Spiel, das seine kurze Story und wenig Eigeninhalt mit einem Zufallsgenerator und Steam-Workshopintegration sehr gut ausgleichen kann.
Ansprüche an die GraKa sind dementsprechend hoch, mein Bolide mit mittlerweile 2 Jahren Alter kann aber das Spiel auf FullHD mit 60+FPS darstellen. Hier sollte man schon etwas Leistung mitbringen.
8/10

-----------------------------------
Gameplay: 8
Atmosphäre: 9
Story/Setting: 7
Bedienbarkeit: 8
Leistung: 8

Summe: 40/50

Fazit:
Wer bei Early Access lieber die Finger weglässt, sollte dieses Spiel trotzdem auf seiner Beobachtungsliste behalten, da es noch in Entwicklung ist.
Aber jetzt schon spielt es in einer hohen Liga mit, die auch für Casuals gut geeignet ist.

Spielzeit beim Verfassen: ~7h

16315272.review:
I bought this game very early and was acutally quiet happy with it. The graphics were astonishing.there were a few intense and awesome maps and a creative Community so we could use  the workshop. I saw the latest update and started to play it again and saw all those changes. To ability to put in your own music, the boombox mode which turns your car and the world around you in a music synchronicing beatvisualizer, the option to customize the car a little bit , the little detail like the star screen on your car when you are staying at the same spot for a short time... i love all of these ! I realy love such details and i am very very happy that you can see that this game is still evolving, i swear, this is gonna be one hell of a game when it is finished.
But the best thing about this new update is the Trackmogrify mode. You just type in some random words, number , sentences , whatever you want and the game creates a racetrack. Type in stuff like "rainbow road" and fell free to have a nice journey on a colourful , rainbowcolored track... type in "lightning storm" to get yourself into an intense storm full of lightningstrikes. 
This mode got rid of a big problem Distance had. After a while you had yourself through all levels and there wasnt much to do. This new mode gives you an incredible, endless amount of new tracks you can generate in less than a few seconds and can be quiet funny. Now Distance isnt just a good game anymore. It turned into a very good game, full of potential. If the designers behind this gem are still updating it in the future and bring even more content out this game will be on my top games of all time, it has so much potential and i can see that the creators have some neat ideas and i am excited for the future.

Graphic: 10/10 , very beatiful and unique

Gameplay : 8.5/10 , unique and awesome gameplay, but i feel like there is potential for more and different modes, the new Trackmogrify mode is a good start!

Sound: 10/10 , nice futuristic sounds, clear and good quality 

Music: 9/10 , very fitting, has a electronic style and sums up the level you are playing but not much variety of soundtracks BUT you can bring your own music into the game now which is absolutly awesome. The game even responds to your music in very different ways , like visualizers.

Variety: 8/10 , thanks to the new gamemode , the workshop and some implemented level you have a nice variety of different tracks, but i have the feeling the game could use some more "Items" to put into the world. New traps or stuff like that ;)

Story: 4/10 , the game has a short adventure mode but its more like a longer tutorial. There are some interesting scenes , levels and more in it but there isnt realy a good or long story, but this game doesnt realy need one, because it isnt a game which is designed for an overwhelming story but for the pure amount of fun you can have whilst playing it.

16260385.review:
Would I recommend Distance?
WOULD. I. RECOMMEND. DISTANCE?

In a word, yes.
But let me tell you why.

I should start with the fact that I've been playing Distance since the later stages of alpha. I've put almost two-hundred hours into the game and more into building the community, from starting a weekly event (Speedy Saturday!), doing weekly community track showcases (with over 600 tracks at the time of writing this, there's a lot of tracks to go through!), and doing a 24-hour charity livestream called Distathon to raise over $2,000 with the help of the amazing Distance community and the developers!

Not only are the devs some of the coolest people, but the community is boss and just keeps growing.

The game itself features tight controls, a solid learning curve, a sick soundtrack, intense level design and so much more. All wrapped up in a nice little burrito of tron-hotwheels-mashup goodness.

One of the VERY few games that's able to keep me coming back, I believe if you're at all interested in a game that's the lovechild of tron and hotwheels, you'll enjoy this.

:)

16250180.review:
Ok, so I spent like 10$ on this game, and believe me, last game I've bought for more than 5$ was probably [spoiler]gta4[/spoiler] around 3 years ago. Why did I do that? Simply because I've fallen in love with its prequel, nitronic rush. You can check it out, i think it's 100% free to download.

Imo, compared to NR, Distance still lacks these perfectly designed, not-so-trivial campaign levels. In return we get unlimited amount of tracks from the community, and some of them are really beautiful, some quite surprising, some surprisingly creative.

Multiplayer works and it's pretty fun, haven't checked splitscreen yet (but it is there).

Also, I can't really imagine playing this game without gamepad. My friend played on keyboard and, while he still had really good time with the game, he couldn't micro his movement while freefalling (or in 0G) that well.

So, my recomendation: Download NR, try it for yourself if you like it, and then throw some money at these guys, because I think they really deserve it.

Reluctantly crouched at the starting line,
Engines pumping and thumping in time.
The green light flashes, the flags go up.
Churning and burning, they yearn for the cup.
They deftly maneuver and muscle for rank,
Fuel burning fast on an empty tank.
Reckless and wild, they pour through the turns.
Their prowess is potent and secretly stearn.
As they speed through the finish, the flags go down.
The fans get up and they get out of town.
The arena is empty except for one man,
Still driving and striving as fast as he can.
The sun has gone down and the moon has come up,
And long ago somebody left with the cup.
But he's driving and striving and hugging the turns.
And thinking of someone for whom he still burns. 
He's going the distance.
He's going for speed.
She's all alone
In her time of need.
Because he's racing and pacing and plotting the course,
He's fighting and biting and riding on his horse,
He's going the DISTANCE!!!.

15877951.review:
Up until recently one of the most original racing games I've ever played. If you like games like f-zero, track mania and Wipeout then you will probably also like this one.

Distance primarly focuses on survival through stunting up, over and under things as you make your way through countless of haphazard areas full of razors and spiked steamrollers. At a certain moment the track starts to rotate horizontally and you even get to drive upside down, straight up and every other angle you can imagine. After a certain while you don't even really know what up and down is anymore, was it not for the arrow on the back of your car that indicates which way down actually is. I do however find myself never really looking at the thing as most community made tracks are so fast and require your full attention. 

After a while you will be constantly propelling yourself forward with the turbo, jump and angle your car 45 degrees with the thrusters and as soon as you land things might start popping up left and right trying to slice your car in half. You jump on the straight orientated road again and go through a portal which then suddenly leaves you hanging in mid air. The upbeat music has stopped and been replaced for the muffled sounds of you trying to maneuver your car in zero-g. 

There is also a story, which is something about you being inside of a computer-thingy which is infected by a virus. Which will become apparent in the storyline mode, but not so much right now. This game mainly thrives from the steam workshop integration as there are a lot of custom maps which can leave you playing this game for a long time.

15832828.review:
Distance ist ein ziemlich gutes Rennspiel mit leichten Platformer Ansätzen. Es fühlt sich an wie ein Trackmania gepaart mit einem Fahrzeug das aus Tron: Legacy stammen könnte. Man kann springen, fliegen, das Fahrzeug mit Schubdüsen in der Luft Kontrollieren und an Wänden und Decken fahren.

 Allerdings muss ich sagen das derzeit in der Early Access Phase etwas zu wenig Content zum austesten geboten wird. Es gibt nur eine Hand voll Levels und einen kleinen Adventure Modus.  
Zudem den recht guten Level-Editor welcher ähnlich wie ein 3D-Programm aufgebaut ist. Für das Spiel ist zudem eine kleine Kampagne bzw. Story angekündigt, aber wenn man das Spiel derzeit anständig Spielen möchte muss man sich früher oder später Content aus dem Workshop holen, welcher aber meist ziemlich gut ist! 

Für die Grafikfetischisten ist hier auf jedenfall auch ausgesorgt! Vor allem die Lichteffekte sehen sehr geil aus, allerdings fehlt es mir noch ein wenig an Details bei den Texturen, was bei den hohen Geschwindigkeiten aber ziemlich irrelevant ist. 

Im Großen und Ganzen ist das Konzept und das ganze Spiel ziemlich gut, allerdings finde ich das man für die 20€ etwas mehr Content bekommen könnte, was hoffentlich der Fall sein wird. 

Kaufen kann hier eigentlich nicht schaden, und viel versauen können die Entwickler eigentlich auch nicht mehr.

15618463.review:
5 is an average game to me.
So I give this game a 7/10
Two things can make it better

Points

1: Throwing in a patch where players don't have to go out of their way to forward a net-code through their router just two get a public game.  That seriously needs to be fixed.  Even if the game is in beta form, most players might not stick around just for that reason.  I would add 2 points if that problem was fixed.

2 Find something definitive to seperate Adventure from Arcade. I'd add one point if something that would make us actually want to play adventure, is patched in.  Some reason for why we are where we are and why our cars can do what they do would be nice.  In my opinion, to know more about my car would make me feel more investested in its usage. Every flip, or bounce, or sky manuever would give me higher levels of phychological investment, if I only knew, why these cars could do this.  Sure the game is still exciting.

Reasoning

Not asking for anything extravagent, but even inputted dialouge to help explain these things seems nice, whatever is done, if anything is done, I'd trust Refract to execute it well. If explaining the car seems like a bit much maybe only give details to us in layers like in the loading screen, not just the car blueprint but the script for what it does in more detail and why it is there with arrows pointing to that specific part. I don't know what those things are marked "A" "B" and "C" for because nothing explains them. Everything else about this game looks and plays excellent.

Other than those two things.  This game is awesome.  Keep up the good work, and I would'nt deduct anything from this, but if Refract could maybe dumb down track editing to like a Halo style map creation, or Trials Evolution.  That would be great as well.  I'm not to tech swavey when it comes to this game's level editing format.

:::EDIT:::

Actual Gameplay

I forgot to add this in but its about the actual gameplay.  It runs very smooth and with all the good reviews pointing out how great the car you control handles I considered whether my input on that matter was needed.  But I'll do it anyway.

I've never played an arcade racer with a car that handles with such precision WITHOUT making you feel like the track controls the car.  This game makes me feel like I control my car at extreme high levels of speed on the tracks riddled with death traps.  There are portals that warp you to another location, or verticalitty.  It took me awhile to figure out I was racing upside down because everything looks right-side up.  And that is pretty cool.  As long as you have speed, you will never fall off the track if you arn't most likely defying the laws of physics.  If you do lose speed, better hope you can open you car doors and use them like gliders.  Not all tracks offer the feature, and on some tracks you can only open the doors at certain parts.  It is executed nicely. There is also a bounce menuever where you spring yourself off the surface to jump over a death trap or get yourself to a higher seperate plane. The tracks can split, or sometimes you can just flyoff completely and find a new path.  This game offers space.  And that is my favorite thing in any racer.  Great handling, and outrageously fun and spacious tracks.


:: EDIT, AGAIN ::

TLDR:  

In short now, I did give this games a thumbs up.  The port-forwarding lobby creating situation still isn't fixed at all, which should be the priority.  As I said above, this game wont last long while porting ourselves to make it work is just a nusaince most people wont bother with.  It's still fun to play even solo, but for new comers looking at online play, if you want a good arcade racing game and dont care about playing cool tracks alone, I'll say get it, for $5.  Other than that, I can't recommend.

I say repeatedly the game is awesome, that's because it is a good arcade racer.  But I'm a multiplayer guy having me portforward a code for a game that is on it's online lifeline (probably because other people don't want to bother to port-forward as well) is just not worth it. The online on this game will be dead before it gets out of the beta stage.  I'm willing to bet.

Save your money.

15578887.review:
Certainly looks like it could be very good. But I feel it has a way to go.
I've got >2.5k hours on TM2 stadium, so anything which is likened to that I'm naturally interested in.

And I've probably not spent long enough on it to really judge, but the things that immediately occured to me (comparing it to TMS, as that's my prime reason for being here) are;
 + Great graphics; yeah - dig that Tron %$!
 - Dark graphics - can't see where to go == skill? Rly?
 + Interface is pretty slick
 - But this *is* TM I'm comparing it too..
 - Controls (using XBox like controller) seem bad; more digial, less analogue. TM is designed for KB, yet it manages to support analogue input sublimely, too.
 - Physics seem a bit light. This is tenuous, as I admit I've not really played enough to really get the feel of things.
 + Flying - Oh yeah; there's a whole shedload of distance to be got from that, if it's used right.
 - Speed - No; I don't agree so far. Unless you hold boost down all the time (which you can't) it seems a tad pedestrian. Maybe I've just not got far enough into it yet.
 + Soundtrack - I really don't like this kind of music. But I found myself leaving it on, anyway. So that's good, right?

Overall, I'm glad I supported this, and hope it delivers what I'm looking for. But I doubt this'll ever be the eSport game that TM2s is.

15458451.review:
This game does everything right. I usually don't play racing games (I have none on my steam account), but I decided to pick this one up. The atmosphere, the colour, the mystery, and the overall mind-bending aspects of this game make it my favourite game that I've gotten so far. 

At first glance, it will just seem like a colourful driving game, but seriously, I have found EVERYTHING that I've wanted in a racing game here, it's fast paced, challenging (but not too difficult once you get into it), and certain aspects like spinning around to jump on upside-down surfaces, or suddenly having the gravity turn off and learning to adjust your playstyle make it super addictive

This game is also packed with lore, but it's never explicitly shoved in your face. The story mode seems to be about some kind of society that released... something, but that's all I've been able to figure out so far. I don't want to spoil anything either, but every detail of the adventure mode is packed with information about what happened. The adventure mode makes me feel like I'm delving into the past, trying to uncover what happened to this society. I've actually played the adventure mode three times now just because of how awesome it feels, it's so fun, and there are a lot of parts that feel so ominous, like I'm watching the end of the world but I don't entirely understand how it happened. The starting cut scene, that just shows the car starting, gives tons of information on the story, but you won't realize it unless you play it through again, and even the loading screens give you a glimpse into what is going on

Overall I am thoroughly impressed with this game. Every aspect of it comes together to make a masterpiece. One thing I'd recommend is making sure you have the right hardware to be able to run it, because the game is just so freaking awesome and having any sort of lag would take away from the experience (you can change the visual settings and that does help, but again the game looks so amazing on full quality)

10/10, I can't wait to see this game when it's completely finished, despite how polished it is already

15446593.review: If you've ever found yourself thinking racing games need some vertigo and trippy graphics, get Distance.

15441700.review:
The more i play distance, the more i feel like it could be THE racing game to pick up. and for an early access title it sure as heck is more polished than other games that share space there.

the gist of it is summed up by the trailer and the game's description: you drive a super cool tron car of sorts through various areas in an attempt to get from point a to point b as fast as possible, while trying not to get sliced, smashed, flung off, or nitronic crash into a wall. the latter is silly because you can also drive on walls and cielings, which counts as a stunt (more on that later). you can also fly, but later levels tend to flip flop between letting you fly and not letting you fly, and you can shave seconds off the flying areas if you know how to.

and that isn't all. you can cool down your thrusters by doing stunts. don't ask how it works, just roll with it. the controls feel buttery smooth and responsive, though some community made levels will make you think otherwise at times. the music in the game is top notch and i'd gladly toss my cash at Refract or Torcht just to get it through steam.

and while the adventure is short and sweet, the replayability comes from the workshop. seriously, go check it out. there's dozens of tracks waiting to be conquered, either alone or in competition with friends and strangers alike. there's  the Stunt mode for those who want to do flips and stuff, or if you want to put it to more use on the courses, Speed and Style is a mode about doing tricks to cut time off the clock. finally, for the ultimate in keepaway, look no further than Reverse Tag. that assumes there's folks hosting that mode, which is often rare. but when it is hosted, it's the perfect blend of sprint, stunt, and king of the hill, with the hill being a ball of sorts that you snag and take with you, but others can also easily snag off you by driving into the ball while you have it.

and if you intend to play this on multiplayer, be sure to hop on Distance on Saturdays. correct me if i'm wrong but i think that's the day when folks go outta thier way to host games of Distance multiplayer.

EDIT:
Californ1a Sep 3, 2015 @ 8:16pm  
Yup, every Saturday 2pm-4pm eastern time is our community multiplayer event: http://steamcommunity.com/app/233610/discussions/0/528398719786414266/

Pinning this comment to the review. speedy saturdays is a thing, okay?

also, figured i'd update this with some developments.

Distance now has a Grip button (think Sonic's stomp in later games, but clings to walls and cielings if your wheels are pointed toward them, and slower, and also acts as the increased handling button) and has toned down a certain bug that allowed huge level skipping to the point it could be outright unfun. the trick is still doable, but now it's not capable of skipping entire sections of track.

but the biggest improvement is the editor, which is now capable of more things than ever before. you need only look at "Uncanny Valley" for a decent start. granted, it could do that stuff before, but it was limited back then.

on a side note, community is active enough that if you DL a map or two via workshop every now and then, you could get a good amount of maps to race on.

TL:DR: Distance is a racing game all about going fast, and surviving. loads of community content keep the game fresh enough to last a while, and devs are hard workers, keeping the progress going.

EDIT: if you see this review by any chance and get the game, hop onto the discord channel.

this also applies to anybody who already owns the game. it's the best way to keep on top of Speedy Saturdays and community events, as well as the community showing off tidbits of what they are working on with the game's editor.

oh, and the main levels of the game look like they're going to get prettied up when the adventure mode gets updated content.

RIP Broken Symetry, though.

15396231.review:
This game will make you re-imagine everything you thought you knew about racing games.

It's an art game in its own right: a total genre-bender. It's like TRON meets Blade Runner
meets Black Rock City at night. It's hard not to get lost in the visuals.
Graphic are breathtaking, even at lower settings (for those of us who don't want to turn
our slow laptops into molten metal). Speaking of molten metal, the lasers are merciless,
and thoroughly awesome. You can slice your car in half down the plane of symmetry and
still recover if you can steer your glowing hunk of car thru a green regeneration hoop.

Gameplay is intense but forgiving, even for the casual gamer like me who's a novice at
racing games and flight simulators. Skills like the 90° wall jumps, mid-air rotation, coming
into and out of a glide, etc. take practice, but they won't frustrate you into rage-quitting.

My only complaint is that it has all EDM/techno-style music, which can get droning and
repetitive (in my opinion). That's part of the ambiance that the artists wished to convey,
and I respect them for it, but I leave the music turned off.

You see that curvy road twisting around itself? A bit behind the others, are we? Well, how about we friggin FLY ABOVE AND BELOW THE DAMN TRACK TO GIVE OURSELVES SOME ADVANTAGE?!

15184593.review:
The most inventive and original racing game I've played in quite some time; Distance is an Incredibly fast and highly-engaging arcade racer with stunning Tron-esque graphics and audio.

The adventure mode is truly unique as you attempt to 'survive' a series of monolithic tracks full of bizarre hazards like buzzsaw blades, laser grids, portals, spaceships and more. There's alot of mechanics to master - like boosting, jumping and flying - but Refract have managed to tie them together in a seamless/rewarding fashion. There's also arcade, multiplayer, track editor and community support so there's plenty to enjoy with Distance in its current Early Access form.

Highly recommended for fans of games like Burnout, Split Second, Need for Speed and TrackMania.

14966029.review:
I read few of the overwhelmingly positive reviews and bought the game while it was on sale, and sorry to say, am a bit disappointed.

The visuals are somewhat stylish, albeit not so good looking if you aren't into neon lights especially. The highly praised audio felt boring and distant, if you will - and I'm into electronic music. Playability is fine, although the car feels very strange, it moves almost like on rails or something. No slipping or anything at all.

All of this could be forgiven if only there was _content_. But there just simply isn't. I played through the single player "campaign", and it was probably one of the most boring hour of gaming in years. This game seriously needs AI competitors. Someone to tackle into the lasers. More speed, lots of it. Weapons. Explosions. Forget twisting in zero gravity and those stupid jumps into the ghost world or whatever it was. Bring us more action. And if guns and fire isn't the thing here, at least make it clear what is.


I'm having hard time deciding what this game tries to be. Is it trying to relax or excite? Currently, it only bores. Not recommended, although there is potential, it just needs a lot more content. A lot.

Edit:
Some more info about my gaming history. I loved Flatout: Ultimate Carnage (it had great sense of speed). Burnout Paradise, Need for Speed series, Fatal Racing, Screamer, to name a few - all of them I did enjoy more or less. Each had more speed and excitement than this one.

14962803.review: As a programmer, I can appreciate how much time, effort, and stress goes into a project of this magnitude with a team as small as Refract. As a result, the game took quite a while to be released. However, it was well worth the wait- they did an amazing job! The level editor is my favorite part. Refract's strategy of utilizing their growing fanbase really makes this game unique. There are hundreds of tracks for this game from different people and their different ideas, rather than a team of a few people making tracks for their own game. The game is also really easy to learn, even if you haven't played their first game, and it is more than a racing game. There are other exciting game modes. There is a fast-paced survival aspect to each race with tons of obstacles that you need to avoid or your car will be torn to shreds. But each race is only as hard as you want it to be! Purchase the game and you will see what I mean. I want to recommend this game to anyone and everyone, and if anyone at Refract stumbles upon this review, I want to let you know you really knocked it out of the park this time! Great game!

14928854.review:
[h1]General[/h1]
I've been waiting for the right time to post my review for Distance, and the most recent update (build 3520, the workshop discovery update) provides the perfect time for me to do so. I bought into the late alpha backer stage in June 2014, and as my playtime would suggest, I've not regretted this in the least bit. Distance was well worth the almost 3x price to buy into that stage ($55), and it has only improved it's features and content since then. This game is a steal for the current $20 it rests at, and I am confident any cons listed in this review or many of the other reviews will be ironed out before it leaves the Early Access stage.

[h1]Early Access[/h1]
Yes, this game is still in the early access stage. For many games that may means bugs, few updates, lazy devs, and etc. but Distance, and its devs, are far exceeding those predispositions people may have about early access as a concept. [url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1857884659/distance-a-next-generation-arcade-racer]It had a very successful Kickstarter campaign[/url] and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=103111305&searchtext=distance]it was also a Steam greenlight game[/url]. The game itself is in a fully working and stable state. The main reason behind staying in early access instead of going ahead and releasing is one thing - Features. The devs are very dedicated and have a laundry list of features they expect to be in their game before they consider it complete, and this is why it is in early access. The main features left to be added to the game at the point of writing this review are as follows: At least one alternative vehicle to choose from (+one other for kickstarter backers), an "announcer" similar to that of Nitronic Rush but in a different styling to fit the desolate Distance atmosphere, a full replay system with ghosts to race against, randomly generated tracks, and a full adventure story mode (part of which is currently in-game). I'd encourage whoever is considering buying this game to look past the early access tag and see the game for what it is, a very complete experience with some major new features on the way.

[h1]Developers[/h1]
The developers are not treating this (early access) as a cash cow opportunity to make a profit and run, abandoning the game - they are very active within the community and are an easy bunch to contact if need be. There is no downside I can speak of when talking about the developers in the 9 months I've participated in the community thus far - they are an amazing team and I'm glad they are the ones to be making this great game. Anyone active in the Distance community has probably talked to them at some point, whether it be about a bug report, feature suggestion, or just discussing some of the many community workshop tracks. Occasionally they will host a livestream event to show off some of the community-created tracks on [url=http://twitch.tv/refractstudios]their Twitch[/url] and we have some great fun asking questions while they host a multiplayer server. All of their contact info is in the bottom-right corner of [url=http://survivethedistance.com/]the Distance homepage[/url].

[h1]Level Editor[/h1]
The level editor is very complex, and a few reviews have listed that as a con, but I see the complexity of it as a good thing. The more complex it is, the more can be done in it. Yes, it won't be easy to do, but the complexity means that it can be done. There are a few level editor tutorials in the works, so they should help new players learn how to use it more easily. If you have the patience to sit down with it for a while and just play around, then you'll find that it is a very extensive editor that allows you to create pretty close to anything you want.

[h1]Pros List[/h1]
I'll be stealing some of my pros and cons from other reviews, but we are all talking about the same game so the lists would be fairly similar anyway. I suggest taking a look through [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/icebound777/recommended/233610/]Icebound777's review[/url] for a comprehensive pros/cons listing.
[list][*]The controls are tight, and the game supports many, many types of controllers including racing wheels and flight sticks.
[*]There is a lot of track variety and full Steam workshop support for the level editor.
[*]The agility of the vehicle makes the game handle more like a platformer than a racer, giving it a "new" feeling to the racing genre.
[*]There is no concept of "out of bounds" in Distance - any surface can be driven on and treated as a potential track. This leads to some crazy routes to get to the end of some tracks.
[*]The competition on the global leaderboards is tight, even with all the off-road routes driving on buildings.
[*]The community encourages players to use the vehicle mechanics to their full potential, and even [url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLj8tBw_zjKiS-dQI9LT5ndpJS_5hR8aC9]publishes videos of how to complete tracks faster[/url] to help any players improve their times (people don't keep "fast" routes a secret).
[*]You can watch a replay of any time on the global leaderboards and race ghosts of them.
[*]The vehicle can be recolored with completely custom colors and those colors show up in multiplayer.
[*]There is splitscreen with up to 4 players, fairly rare on pc games - as well as online multiplayer.
[*]Extensive graphics settings to be configured, including things such as "Film Noir" for a black and white look or "Stylized Outlines" for the Borderlands look.
[*]The car can be cut into pieces by lasers or saws, making for some interesting gameplay trying to control the vehicle without a couple wheels.
[*]The soundtrack. Seriously, just [url=https://soundcloud.com/torcht/sets/distance]go listen to it[/url].
[*]All audio levels can be edited separately (music, car, environment, etc.)
[*]Local custom music support to play mp3's and have the game lights react/pulse to it (Windows only currently).
[*]All official and workshop tracks are available in multiplayer. The host needs to have the tracks locally in order to play them however.
[*]Not having a workshop track in multiplayer is no big deal, say hi to automatic workshop downloading!
[*]There is the option of creating private, password-protected, servers, and a "connect via IP" to allow for offline LAN play.
[*]Comprehensive and complex level editor allowing you to run wild with whatever crazy ideas you may have.
[*]Multiple gamemodes including:
[list][*]Sprint (point a to b race/time trial)
[*]Challenge (similar to Sprint, but no checkpoints and no deaths allowed)
[*]Stunt (do stunts to get the highest score)
[*]Reverse Tag (capture the flag/king of the hill type gameplay where you try to hold onto a bubble for a cumulative 3 minutes and the bubble enlarges the longer you hold it making it harder to keep)[/list][/list]

[h1]Cons List[/h1]
[*]No option of a standard HUD apart from the back of the vehicle, making getting cut extremely annoying in some situations.
[*]Currently no dedicated servers, the host has to be playing the game and picking which tracks to play - however this has been hinted at as something the devs want to be in.
[*]No custom assets in the level editor - that means objects or music. Local custom music is supported, but no workshop support.
[*]Difficulty and skill curve could use some tweaking but if you stick with it, it is possible to learn the ropes fairly quickly.
[*]General bugs/glitches[/list]

14893473.review:
Highly recommended. Maybe the best racing game on Linux. If you ever wanted to race with a futuristic car in a very futuristic world, this game is for you! Its racing with a twist, your car can perform various new functions such as jumping, wallriding and even flying! All this makes for very interesting race courses where the quickest way sometimes requires a lot of creativity. Something like extreme-G mixed with Trackmania.

Graphics and sound are excellent, but my favourite part is the gameplay. The car really controls so well, it is even possible to play with the keyboard. Good control is important as the game requires lighting fast reactions.

Note there are no AI oponents, hopefully this is something that will be added later. I had a lot of fun playing with random people through multiplayer though. The split screen option is also a very welcome addition and this can very easily be a fun game to play when having friends over. Just make sure to find an easy level pack first as most of the default levels take a lot of practice to master.

14860728.review:
So It took me a couple days just because once you hit the nightmare stuff it gets moderately frustrating. Best advice is keep calm and pay attention. As difficult as this gets in Distance its key. Theres a way I feel that a Hotas Dualstick controller system would do a lot better with this game than a Keyboard or Xbox 360 controller would. Thats the negatives so far.

Positives are quite a few; Take Tron, a light touch of the Horror genre, and the Matrix Highways and the portals from Dystopia and you have Distance. The in game suspense gets quite affective at times. I put down the campaign a few times just to get my head clear from the in game 'stressors' but once I figured out what I was doing its quite fun. 14858165.review:
Distance is a high-octane reaction-based arcade racing game set in what I can only assume to be a computer program with a sick EDM (primarily techno) soundtrack to go with it. A spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush, you have only seconds to react to what's in front of you and sometimes not even that much time is given. While sometimes frustrating with no particular payoff other than beating your times, Distance is an exciting game with a cool setting and a great soundtrack.
 
Gameplay: 8.5/10: Distance offers a variety of game modes including a short campaign, arcade sprint, stunt and style races, versus race, and split-screen up to four players. Each gameplay mode, outside of the multiplayer, is mildly lacking in replay value (unless you're a perfectionist and want to get to the top of the leaderboards which I personally could easily see myself attempting). When you enter the multiplayer it becomes an insane race for first, style points, or who can pull off the most wicked stunt. The last time I felt a game play this smooth and fun was Split/Second and that's what this game reminds me of... only if it were set in Tron.

Graphics: 8/10: The setting is stunning and the tracks are intense to race on. Neon colours flash past you as you go from 0-250mph in just a few short seconds and the environment keeps up with the action you experience. However, upon closer inspection the environment isn't the most detailed setting, with speed of levels (no laps) and need for concentration aiding in the distractability from the environment itself. The car itself is physically stunning and fun to look at, particularly when you activate the thrusters or flight ability. When it explodes for the umpteenth time, you might be a little remorse at the fact that it constantly splits into the same fractal polygons and rains over the landscape below, but if you can get over that sort of thing you might just find yourself immersed in the reactive world around you, which brings us to our next point.

Sound: 9/10: Arguably the star of the game is the notion that the environment reacts to the pumping techno beats and seems to simulate a synesthetic experience. The developers turn sound into visuals which vastly aid in drawing you in to the overall experience. I even found myself reacting and driving to the beat, which for some reason was always perfectly timed to the rest of the level, even if you were to crash with a digitally explosive sound. The soundtrack is genuinely something I find myself coming back to the game to enjoy over and over and over again. The car sounds beautiful and is perfectly matched to its sporty design. I keep returning to the game just to hear the music again and again. I love it that much!

Last Words
Distance is a fun game for perfectionists but if you're into unlocks and specials outside of what you purchase, you'll want to look elsewhere. A visual and audible synesthetic experience that draws you in, Distance is the perfect spiritual successor to some of the most fast-paced and intense racing games on the market.

8.5/10 - Give it a go, especially if you catch it on sale!

14855888.review:
So.  Distance.  Hmm.  How to describe it?

If I were to summarise it in one sentence, it would be "It's like Dark Souls and Tron had a baby, and the baby was a game which was allegedly a racing game but was actually an adventure game where you play a car in a post-apocalyptic cyberscape".  Which is certainly an idiosyncratic description, so perhaps I'll go into more details.

Graphically, it's gorgeous.  The art design is incredibly strong and the different areas of the city feel very distinctive - and the challenges you'll encounter vary based on sector.  The audio is likewise near pitch perfect.  The controls are tight, and the game always felt fair.  Yes, I died a lot in some sections, but it always felt like it was something I'd done wrong, rather than the game punishing me for bad luck.  That's high praise and speaks well of their design ethos.

As it stands, the game is somewhat lacking in content.  I burned through Adventure mode in about an hour.  It was incredibly polished and I encountered no bugs - it's just not very long.  So if you're looking for a full game, hold off until it's out of Early Access.  However, once it's finished and if it lives up to the current high standards, I would freely recommend it.

14847519.review:
Lasers, buzz-saws and grinders, oh my! 

This game reminds me of Kinetica, a 2001 futuristic racer for the ps2 with an emphasis on deadly tracks and racer stunts. If you've played and loved Kinetica, or either of those two aspects appeal to you, this game will not disappoint. 

So far its an interesting little racing game that has a lot going for it in its early state. Overall, the racing mostly relies on quick reactions, a general understand of how fast you're moving, and boost/heat/flight energy management. The game is simple enough that its easy to learn the controls and get started, but a few tracks into single player and you'll realize just how much you have to master (especially if you want to play online or gold medal the arcade modes). 

It is currently a little light on dev created content, but the community is filling in the gaps for now. 

The single player campaign is about 40 min, and obviously incomplete, but it already has some interesting story telling methods and lore that its begging to set up. 

In short, I think this game is totally worth your money, especially if you want to help the devs bring this game to fruition.

Ce jeu est exactement ce que le trailer montre.
Un jeu de course ultra stylisé à l'ambiance TRON avec plein de mécaniques inédites comme le fait de pouvoir sauter, voler, faire pivoter le véhicule sur ses 360° selon les 2 axes histoire de survivre en évitant les pièges.
Question jouabilité ça se prend facilement en main mais on regrettera l'absence d'inertie au sol qui rend les déplacements très sensibles au stick.
La musique est très sympa du moment qu'on aime le style, les graphismes sont très agréables et le jeu est très fluide et surtout très léger.
Le mode aventure se finit très vite pour l'instant et ne propose rien de particulièrement captivant.
Le jeu repose donc sur son ambiance, son efficacité dans son game design et l'éditeur de niveau qui permet d'étoffer les mondes avec le workshop.
Une petite perle qui mérite qu'on s'y attarde.
20€ c'est beaucoup mais c'est la somme qu'il faudra mettre pour en profiter dés maintenant et soutenir l'équipe.

PS : je n'ai pas eu l'occasion de jouer en multi, soi-disant mon jeu était une version antérieur aux 2 serveurs qui m'étaient proposé, dommage. Je modifierai cette évaluation dés que j'en saurais plus.
