14592603.review:
[i]Early Access review, FEB 15.[/i]


[b]Great graphics, cool presentation (like music-bass pulsating colors), awesome !!! music. [/b]
It's a pretty fast racing game; easy to learn, hard to master. Good reflexes are a must. 4/5


[list]
[*] Official tracks are really good. From easy tutorial-like tracks to weird and fast paced ground-ceiling-wall-avoid-jump-through-hole. They look great, stuff pulsates colorful to the beaty music. They usually take about 2-4 min. so great for "just another map" feeling :D
[*] Graphis is awesome. Although some effects are pretty performance consuming (e.g. car reflections), even with a mediocre pc it still looks cool. Big screen/tv is a plus since all the effects can sometimes make orientation a bit hard, especially when playing split screen MP.
[*] Controls are fine (no mouse support though, but I don't mind). You can customize them and even put one action to 2 different buttons, but I think the default settings are just working good. Best played with controller in my opinion (worked with xbox 360 controller instantly).
[*] Sound is, as title says, fu**** awesome! Great beats, everything is responsive to the track (which works even in MP!), which really improves imersion (if you can say that for a SciFi racing game :D). Nothing to add here. Just turn up the bass + volume! (yes the music in the steam shop video is also in game music)
[*] Stuff like "gold medals" is not really necessary imho - but every player gets a profile and you can check your local player and global ranking for every track. Nice for local MP with your friends, as you can always check who's the best on which track if you'd like.
[*] Some customization is possible: you can change your cars colors, like primary, secondary, glow and sparcle color. Gets saved to the profile, so every player can make his own colored car. Design is still always the same, though.
[/list]


If you like racing games and are playing MP (and don't necessarily need weapons like Mario Cart), get this gem right now.
If you play singe player only, maybe wait a bit for more content or a sale, as currently you can "see and do everything" in a couple of hours (unless you're the type who has to lead every ranked table there is :D).


Did not use the map creator.
Did play with controller only.
Did not play online MP, just split screen.

14586908.review: A successor to Nitronic Rush, Distance is a racing game with an emphasis on dynamic movement, quick reactions and a generally good sense of speed. Although still in Early Access, i'm pretty much content with everything in the game. Although the single-player is rather short, this game allows for custom levels and multiplayer support. One of my favorite racing games, right up there with F-Zero GX and Wipeout.

14583550.review:
I enjoy Distance, because I'm a guy who loves arcade-ish racing games in general. The question whether you'd like it is depending on your taste of games. It's a racing genre that needs more explanation.
So here is my review with a comparison to the older, yet free game "Nitronic Rush".

The control of the car is great and is heavily improved upon since Nitronic Rush, where you'd fling around carelessly by accident (though this was a lot of fun). Small turns in Distance are not as easy to make though. A controller is nice to use in case you want to aim for a nice time on a track.

The story mode, despite being minimal, has an enjoyable exploration feeling; much like it's earlier version. Shame it's not finished yet, but it looks to be promising. Playing this with some friends by giving each other the controller or keyboard is a lot of fun too.

This all is nothing I was worried about when it came to purchasing Distance. What worried me and still slightly does is the replayablity of the game. As of now Distance, does not have this so much. Nitronic Rush was free and for me the joy was kinda out of it when I completed the storyline. You've kind-of seen it all by the time you're done with it. Distance's multiplayer aspect improves on this a lot, so does the custom levels and level-editor. If all this to improve it makes the game worth the price tag of 19,99 euro's; I'm not so sure.

Eventually after fully experiencing the Story Mode the game turns from survival exploration racing to precision racing. It's kind of the same thing as Trackmania actually. Although there's more control over your car and it's set in a whole different setting. If you're much into precision racing; I see you'll have a decent amount of replayability with this game. Yet if you're only in for the exploration, I think you're through the game rather quickly.

Get this game if you like precision racing, otherwise wait for a 40% discount. 33% works if you're desperate to try it.

[spoiler]:^)[spoiler]7.6*/10[spoiler]*grade improves as the game improves[/spoiler][/spoiler][/spoiler]

14573747.review:
Wer sich Disteance kauft darf ein außergeöhnliches Rennspiel erwarten.

Nicht nur ist der Stil, mit seinen offentsichtlichen Anlehnungen an TRON und das Erstlingswerk der Entwickler (nennt sich Nitronic Rush und ist kostenlos, kann man sich auch durchaus mal anschauen) sehr gelungen, sondern macht es auch vieles anders als die meisten aktuellen Rennspiele, wo der trend doch immer wieter richtung Realismus geht. Man bekömmt natürlich die arcadige Fahrphysik mit der obligatorischen Boostfunktion allerdings gibt es dazu dann auch das außergewöhnliche Bewegungssystem, welches einem dank Sprüngen, Rotationen um die eigenen Achsen und kurzzeitigen Flugeinlagen komplett neue Wege eröffnet sich durch die Level zu bewegen.
Die Level an sich sind sehr gut gestaltet und führen einen mit der richtigen Geschwindigkeit an die anfangs doch recht ungewöhnlichen Funktionen heran. 
Die Level kann man entweder im Storymode eins nach dem anderen spielen, oder im Arcademode direkt auf bestzeitenjagd gehen und sich mit seinen Freunden oder der ganzen Welt messen, dank intergrirter Bestenlisten.
Wem die offiziellen Level, von denen es momentan tatsächlich leider noch nicht so viele gibt (bei meinem ersten durchspielen war ich mit dem Storymode nach etwa 45 Minuten durch) nicht reichen, der hat Glück denn das SPiel kommt mit einem umfangreichen Streckeneditor und Steamworkshopsupport, wodurch andauernd neue gute (und auch nicht so gute) Level auftauchen, auf denen man sich mit seinen Freunden messen kann.
Im multiplayer gibt es verschiedene Modi, so kann man die normalen strecken gegeneinander fahren, oder aber in speziellen Arenen Fangen spielen oder einfach schauen wer die höchste Punktzahl mit Stunts erreichen kann. Hierzu sei noch gesagt, dass es keine Kollisionen gibt, ähnlich wie bei Trackmania, sodass es nicht vorkammen kann, dass jemand einfach nur da ist um zu trollen und andere zu behindern.

Ist das Spiel perfekt? Nein, natürlich nicht, aber sowas kann man ja wohl auch nicht von einer Beta erwarten. Hier und da gibt es noch Performanceprobleme und manchmal macht die Physik auch komische Sachen, insbesondere, wenn das eigene Auto durch Laser zerschnitten wurde und nur noch 2/3 des Wagens vorhanden sind. Aber man merkt, dass die Entwickler stetig daran weiter arbeiten und dass ihnen diese Projekt wirklich am Herzen liegt.

Kann ich distance empfehlen? Auf jedenfall es ist alles in allem ein sehr spaßiger Arcaderacer, der vieles neu macht und insbesondere die Bestzeitjagd auf einezelnen Strecken ist fantastisch (wenn man die Zeit eines Freundes um den Bruchteil einer Sekunde unterbietet ist das schon ein cooles Gefühl). Zum spielen empfehle ich jedoch einen Controller mit zwei Analogsticks, man kann zwar auch mit Keyboard spielen, aber ein Controller macht die Dinge deutlich einfacher und auch angenehmer.

14573662.review:
This game is epic. Most games nowadays go for either a realistic or a cartoonistic look. This game is one of the few race games that is futuristic, but also psychedelic. 

Pros:
- EPIC music, if you like EDM. Almost no game can compare to this. Also: lights that follow the beat.
- Graphics: epic. 
- Controller: (I have a Xbox360 controller) works great. Also trembles on the right events (like when your car explodes)

Cons:
- No other cars in adventure mode. It feels a bit.. lonely?
- No objectives except surviving. Most games have something like points, achievements or things to unlock. This game is just racing and getting to a new level.
-An arcade mode would have been really cool, with some futuristic weapons or something.

14572891.review:
I have been following this game's development since Nitronic Rush (if you don't know what that is you need to check that out). After playing a crapton of trackmania and burnout paradise years ago, i needed a new fix. 
After first seeing the trailer for Distance i thought, "wow! Trackmania and Tron had a baby, that's so cool, look at all the new shit you can do since Nitronic Rush! Im behind these devs 100% and giving them my money NOW!". 

That was years ago. Almost nothing substantial has really changed. The addition of the steam workshop is the only thing keeping the game alive at all. It's such a shame. I used to have such high hopes for Distance, but it isn't even out of Beta. There isn't even a propper campaign yet. They keep saying that they are currently working on it and thier team is small and all that. But lets be real here, this game has been in early access for over 3 years now. I fear if it ever actually got released now it wouldn't have a chance.

Im changing my review to a do not recommend because I honestly don't think Distance will ever be finished, even by the end of 2018.

14509389.review:
A very abstract-yet-addicting approach to merging both puzzle and driving genres into one new-age racing game.

rundown:
+ amazingly crisp graphics
+ an easy-to-learn level workshop editor with plenty of tutorials
+ A catchy futuristic electronic soundtrack
+ no HUD to block your view (for this kind of game, all you really need is a speed gauge and elapsed time)
+ Your car can freakin' fly/flip/rotate/glide!!!
+ Nice visual damage detailing to your vehicle. (from small dents in your fender to being sliced in half by lasers)
+ You can still continue driving, even with your car diced up in half, as long as you have more than half of your car is intact!

- Car runs somewhat slow without boost and turns/flips over on a dime
- Only one car for the whole game (although it could be a positive thing for people who dislike complicated racing games)
 

- If you're a racing fan, why are you still reading this? GO BUY IT ALREADY!

14428234.review:
TL;DR: Awesome game for a decent price with graphics that're way better than the screenshots above make them look. Buy it YESTERDAY, but don't expect a super-realistic driving game or even a MARGINALLY realistic one. I don't even think the cars have breaks--but if they do I've never used them.

A pretty unique game that feels less like a driving or racing game(due in large part to the slippery and unrealistic car) and more like a sort-of... Sonic-y runner with survival elements. Irregardless of how the game feels however it is inarguably one of the most fun experiences I've ever had. The game is challenging at times but for the most part is very fair, even in most of the workshop levels I've played, and it introduces a pretty cool universe(though one which reminds me too much of Tron to call it wholly original) that I REALLY want to learn more about, as well as some mechanics that I can't really say I've ever seen before.

You'll find yourself frequently and seamlessly switching from driving on the ceiling and on the walls, only to jump off two and a half seconds later and flying over an endless void. After a while, you'll land on solid ground again-- and if the planets align, you'll be actually horizontal on the GROUND and not on a wall or the ceiling, and nothing will be trying to kill you. At which point you'll probably make your car JUMP and do a couple flips for bonus points. This is the game's biggest asset, in my opinion. Everything just works--and works so very, very well. Jumping from a walll to the floor or vice-versa has some occasional hiccups, but otherwise the physics engine is constructed so well that the game just FLAWLESSLY and instantaneously responds to your commands in a way that I'm too illiterate to describe. The controls just feel so right... I'd even call them close to flawless. When you're a car, it drives like a car--a car that can jump, flip, and drive when half of it gets shredded by laser beams, but a car nonetheless. When you leap into the air and deploy your fucking WINGS, it feels like a plane. The game instantly transitions from a really solid(but floaty and weightless) arcade driving game into a really solid flight simulator--but it does it so well that you don't even notice most of the time.

Another huge plus is the striking art style. It feels reminiscent of Tron, but it has its own unique flare that defines it as its own, like most of the rest of the game does. It looks really overly shiny and neon and it's not something that I'm usually very fond of, but it works REALLY well. The screenshots and footage on this page seriously do not do the game credit in this respect.

The obsticles in the game are also pretty awesome, in combination with the car's damage model. Imagine Metal Gear Rising where Raiden's sword is a grid of laser beams, and you are the watermellon. Obviously your car does not like to drive as well if it is split in half, but it can take a lot of abuse as I recall.

The lore and universe in the game gives me mixed opinions. The developers have made it clear that they'll probably change a lot of the "story", but as of the time of this writing the game has a really solid universe and what seems to be the beginning of some AMAZING lore to build off of, but it doesn't really do anything with it. It attempts to almost tell the story through the tracks as you race through them, and while it translates pretty well in some ways, it doesn't really allow you to get a good idea of where you are, why you're there, and what the hell is going on around you, and it certainly leaves you drawing blanks for specific details. Story is by no means of any importance in a game like this and when the tracks are designed so well that they should make AAA publishers feel inferior, I really don't mind too much, but I simply can't help but lust for more lore. Hell, I'll sebtle for a two-issue tie-in comic for god's sake.

In conclusion, the game has its faults, but I'll be damned if I can name any of them. I'm too busy trying to beat my backflip record.

In a car.

Levels change their primary colour every few miles and can really change the mood of the track. 
As soon as the level turns red, you know you got to go fast.

This game is THE hypest shit, neon 90's computer racing, tight controls, fun to just fuck around in and jump into the scenery, riding every wall you can find, multiplayer, a great sound track which interacts with the lighting, NEON DEATH SAW BLADES/ CRUSHERS/ LASERS IT SERIOUSLY HAS IT ALL.

The only downside to this game is that the sense of speed should be somewhat higher, I don't really see this being played competitively online, and the fact that it's early access so you're short a few tracks.



TL;DR: If you like videogames, buy this. If you don't like videogames anymore, buy this.

14316281.review:
Ok so I began to get excited about this game long ago when development was first announced.  As one of the seemingly few Racing genre fans left out there, this was high on my list for arcade style shenanigans.  When I saw it up for Early Access, I just had to try it for myself.  

Firstly, let me start by saying I didn't know it, but I've been waiting my whole life for this game.  The flying mechanic is awesome and it brings a totally unique spin on survival racing genre.  The look is fitting, the soundtrack rocks, and the graphics are modest but sweet.  If you enjoyed Extreme G on the N64 or any of the F-Zero games, or games like them, you should enjoy Distance.  A big thing that's different though that I haven't seen often is what makes it a survival game.  There aren't weapons on vehicles or combat in any traditional sense.  Instead, your faced with a myriad of interesting obstacles to overcome.  Some of it is track memorization but there's plenty moving around and enough nuance that it's going to take on-the-fly skills to get a good time in this game.  Ok, so it's kind of a dream come true, but what's wrong with it?

For fairness sake, I need to talk about what I think isn't so great about the game too.  For starters, I think the multiplayer is going to be a tough sell since people have to host their own servers.  That's hard to get people to do even for games where it's expected, like FPS games.  I hope a dedicated few make a nice online scene for the playerbase, otherwise we're gonna have a hard time playing together.  Secondly, there's still something to be desired in the handling.  They've got a really solid base for how the controls feel (I'm using a game pad), but there needs to be some more precision to it.  Everything feels just a little bit soft, so hopefully they can tighten those knobs.  Finally, there needs to be better programming to handle bumping into stuff.  If you full blown crash, you're out of the race, and that seems to work fine.  It's when you ram a wall, or awkwardly get turned upside down, or stuck in a corner, or land funny from flying, that you find yourself pressing buttons that don't help.  There needs to be more protocols for what happens when X fails.  This is of course beta, so stuff like that is already on the to-do list I'm sure, but that will help a lot with the replayability of levels and it will make failure less frustrating.  

All in all, this game is a solid buy for any fan of the racing genre, particularly those older arcade style games that were focused on external stuff like survival rather than pure-racing.  I will be spending plenty of time in this title.  I think there's a lot of room for improvement but the game has a really solid foundation and so with proper support I'm excited to think we'll get an iconic title out of this one.  

PS: I'd like to add that they really did a nice job with the mechanics and how they teach them to you.  They took all the advice I see directed towards newer developers (not saying these guys are new, I don't know the company's history) and they used it to their advantage.  The overheating system in juncture with the restoration circles is beautifully simple and very well tuned.  The story mode teaches you all the crazy things you have to avoid in a perfect way.  Very non-tutorialy while at the same time being an excellent tutorial.  - Nice job on the basic mechanics.

14306869.review:
This game is such a mess and not because it's Early Access.

You want to know what made Trackmania work despite it's crazy tracks?  Because it had mandatory checkpoints you had to go through so you couldn't skip half the track using a jump or find a "weak point on the track"

In Distance, this isn't even remotely the case.  Multiplayer consists of people just jet flying to skip a good portion of the track as a "shortcut" which makes the game dull and uninteresting.

This sucks because the music and art direction are superb, but it's a complete garbage when it comes leaderboards and time trails.  In short, this is a waste of 20 dollars and I would not recommend this to anyone.  It's almost as bad as spending money on Call of Duty Advanced Warfare.

I've been fooled by quite a few games on Early Access and become quite hesitant to even purchase them anymore. But I have to say this is one of the few gems inside of this program. Distance is just plain addicting. I can just spend hours on end replaying the same levels (Or going through the library of community made tracks on the workshop! ) over and over again. The car itself is amazing allowing you to boost, jump, fly and rotate giving you many options for sick tricks that you can do. The teleporters I have to say is another one of my favorite things about this game, nothing is as  cool as doing a flip through a teleporter and dodging multiple blades and lazers before landing it or suddenly being taken to an area with Zero Gravity or where you're upside down. Did I mention that the car also lets you ride on walls and ceilings? This game is fast paced, and very awesome if you can stay up to speed and stick to your reactions as you dodge anything that blocks your path. It has multiplayer already in the game from the get go which works pretty well for an Early Access game so far. The game also lets you customize your car to a limited extent along with an easy, but deep level editor. Also if you were wondering, you can go first person as well! There's no interior just the front of the car but holy shit it's tough but cool as hell to drive in that view. Recommend this game to any of your friends if you own it, this needs a larger community to support it!

tl;dr: Game is like hotwheels, and trackmania with it's own little twists (Teleporter, and the car.) Very fun, awesome tricks. If you've been hesitant on buying it, don't hold back.

I'd give this game personally a 10/10. Can't really find anything I don't enjoy about it. It's one of those fun, addicting little games you find that you can't put down and keep coming back to. Going from highspeed races, to doing sick stunts with your friends, along with making a level or two if you have the creativity and time. This game has quite a bit of content and love put into it for only being out for just under two months. I can't wait to see where it goes.

14133263.review:
Ich persönlich habe das Spiel durch "Hau5test" (youtuber) entdeckt und muss sagen dass mich die dort gezeigten Spielszenen von der Optik her, sehr angesprochen haben. Ich war schon lange auf der Suche nach einem Rennspiel dass die perfekte Mischung aus Arcade- und Funracer bietet. Hiermit hatte die Suche endlich ein Ende gefunden :)

Zuerst sei gesagt dass sich das Spiel noch in der Early Access Phase befindet d.h. Bugs oder Glitches sind hier keine Ausnahme. Trotzdem hat mir das nicht die Lust genommen das Game für akzeptable 20€ runterzuladen.


STORY:

Das Spiel beginnt meiner Meinung nach, mit einer recht coolen Startsequenz die einfach mal auf jegliche Worte verzichtet und direkt in's Gameplay einleitet. Man hat zwar nie eine wirkliche Ahnung davon, gegen wen oder wofür man gerade fährt aber das ist man ja eigentlich heutzutage von Rennspielen gewohnt. Übrigens kann man den Story Modus locker an 1 Tag durchspielen. Zu viel soll jetzt aber auch nicht verraten werden, denn ihr sollt es ja selber erleben ;)

Zusammengefasst: Die Story ist nicht gerade die Stärke von Distance, ist aber jedem selbst überlassen.


Grafik/Optik:

Die Anforderungen an den PC um das Spiel auf Ultra spielen zu können sind nicht gerade ohne :D
Mein Mittelklasse-PC schafft es noch knapp auf "Hoch" zu spielen mehr aber nicht.
Optisch macht Distance einiges her. Nicht nur der Neon/Laser look gefällt mir sehr gut sondern auch die verschiedenen Designoptionen geben einen mehr Möglichkeiten das Spiel zu personalisieren. Mein persönlicher favorit ist der "cel shading" look bei dem alle schwarzen Linien etwas dicker dargestellt werden als sonst. Das verpasst dem ganzen eine Art Comic Stil. Doch wie fast immer gilt: Look ist Geschmackssache ;)

Zusammengefasst: Die Grafik ist alles andere als enttäuschent, da jeder selber den Look bestimmen kann, um das beste Spielerlebnis rauszuholen.


Gameplay:

Das Gameplay von Distance hat seine Vor- sowie Nachteile. Na ja... um genau zu sein gibt es nur einen Nachteil dazu aber gleich. Für alle die jetzt ein wenig skeptisch geworden sind: ES MACHT VERDAMMT NOCHMAL SPASS!
Egal ob am Boden, in der Luft oder an den Wänden, wenn man den Dreh einmal raushat, geniesst man Level für Level!
Die Steuerung ist eher simpel gehalten (Positiv) Gas geben, Nitro, Bremsen und Lenken, dass übliche.
Neu sind Drehen und Springen/Gleiter öffnen. Die zuletzt erwähnten Steuerrungsmöglichkeiten machen das Fliegen in der Luft möglich. Das Handling bzw. das Fahrgefühl ist ebenfalls untypisch. Anders als bei einer Rennsimulation, reagiert das Auto sofort auf Anschlag somit ist ein Schleudergang unmöglich. Wie schon erwähnt gibt es keine "normalen" Strecken. Statdessen startet man erst auf einer Geraden dann sind überall Hindernisse verteilt wie z.B. Sägeblätter Rampen etc. und es folgen Flug- oder Wandpassagen. Diese Variationen sind abhängig vom Schwierigkeitsgrad.

Der einzige Nachteil ist ein Bug in der Steuerrung, der dringend behoben werden muss! Ich spiele Distance für gewöhnlich mit meinem "Razer Sabertooth" Gaming Controller und das einzige Problem hierbei liegt in den Steuerrungsoptionen. Entweder wird er als eigenstänndiger Controller oder als X-Box Controller erkannt das passiert gefühlt alle 2 Sekunden und kann beim Zocken für nervige Steuerrungs-Konflikte Sorgen. Das könnte eventuell nur bei mir der Fall sein, ist aber trotzdem erwähnenswert.

Zusammengefasst: Der Grundgedanke von Distance liegt im abwechslungsreichen Gameplay dessen einzige Schwäche in der Controller-Steuerrung liegt.


Online:

Der Online-Modus spaltet sich in "Workshop" und Online rennen. Im Workshop von Distance steckt eines der größten Potenziale. Jeder kann mit dem seeehr ausführlichen Level-Editor eigene Level kreieren und online stellen. Somit bietet das Spiel jeden Tag neue Herrausvorderrungen und wird theorethisch nie langweilig. Jeden Tag kommen rund 15 neue Level dazu, was für die Early Access Phase keine schlechte Quote ist.
Die Online-Matches hingegen sind noch sehr verbesserungswürdig weil teilweise kaum Server vorhanden sind oder hin und wieder Verbindunsprobleme auftauchen.

Zusammengefast: Der Steam Workshop garantiert für langanhaltende Spielzeit wohingegen die Online-Matches teils öde oder nicht spielbar sind.




Pro:                                                                   

-Solide Grafik                                                
                                                                          
-Look größtenteils personalisierbar                
                                                                         
-Erfrischendes Gameplay                                

-Herunterladbare Level im Workshop


Kontra:

-Magere Story

-Eventuelle Steuerrunsproblme

-Unausgereifter Online-Mode

Endnote: 3+

14051277.review:
It's probably a good time to review now. The developers behind Nitornic Rush made Distance after a successful Kickstrater compaign, in which I was a backer. I played the game since pre-EarlyAccess beta and it's one of those titles that doesn't have a long-lasting attachment feature, yet immediately sinks in as being something unique and great.

The production quality of this indie racer made by 6 people is 100 times better than something like The Crew, which shows something... At the very least a clear ability to estimate the workload and project scope in regards to the team's resources. There is no question that the game will be delivered exactly as was promised, if not better, and completely bug-free with great performance. Because it already is. I have no qualms with recommending this even under Early Access because really it is complete. All features promised by Kickstrater campaign have been delivered in time and as advertised. It is strange to praise a company so much just for doing things how they have to be done, but lately so few have been doing so, that as sad as it is, Refract really do stand out as being exceptionally professional and honest about their goals. And having a solid vision to boot.

Now the actual game. It's a survival racer where you can drive on tracks, under tracks, on walls, on roofs, you can fly, jump, there are zero-gravity sections and generally a complete and glorious clusterfuck every time you spawn on a level. No signle race will be the same because at some point, someone will decide "Racing on track is 2lame4me" and jump on a nearest skyscraper, ride on it's wall to cut, screw up the jump-off, fall onto a lazer and cut off his front wheels (the car doesn't die from that, as long as you can get it to a next checkpoint where it will regenerate any missing parts, it will keep going until it overheats or smashes into something). After that they will make a best attempt to use side thrusters to turn and sprint thruster to get more airtime, overheat, explode and everyone will laugh hysterically.

This game is one of those LAN party games that becomes and instant must-have. It is full of hilarious moments. But if Goat Simulator, which is similar in that respect, only has funny moments, Distance posses a huge mechanical depth and complexity unparallelled by any racing game other than Simulators. If you can get past the flying controls and master the "EveryTHING is a race track" mechanic of switching between tracks, walls, ceilings, portals, all the while avoiding obstacles and performing tricks to get cooldown and boost more or get more flytime, you will find a very satisfying experience due to the amount of ways every track can be completed in. 

You can drive to next checkpoint. You can fly to it. You can jump to a wall, drive up, jump off, do a 180‘ flip to land on the part of the track above you and skip to the next checkpoint. You can fly off the track at any time and use building rooftops to skip track parts. And it's not cheating because it takes an enormous amount of skill and training to pull that off without meeting your demise and being reset far back. There is really nothing like this. Distance takes the "alternative route" of racing games to a completely new level.

Also a very advanced level editor, a ton of levels on Steam Workshop, incredible soundtrack, great graphics and atmosphere, fantastic production quality and a fair price. If you can find friends for a LAN party or organize a group to play in online multiplayer (because generally that part is pretty dead, if you don't organize and host, there are no random servers to join and race), you will have a blast. It is very difficult to properly master this game's 4-dimensional racing, but it's worthit and if you don't want, you don't have to do it. I had a blast taking 14 minutes to reach finish line, just because in those 14 minutes I discovered 34 ways to reach it. Also I love driving half a car. I mean look at my screenshots.

TL;DR:
Race
WTF I can FLY?
Вitch Ima fly past whole track and finish in 15 seconds!
*explodes and respawns*
Ok, Ima fly to the building, drive on it's wall and jump off 3 checkpoints later!
*Does it all*
I am so pro biаtches! *Accidently cuts off half a car while flying, with left thuster gone car spins out of the track*
FUCK! Boost! Fly! Next checkpoint! *Explodes from overheat and resets*
Ok screw this, I am driving on track...
...
...
What's that glowy thing over there? Can I get there? Oooh I can...

10/10 would explode again.

Distance, уникальная игра в своем жанре, если вы хотите просто покататься, то можете проходить мимо, игра хардкорная, интересная, стильная, она затягивает на долго, цель игры не только добраться до финиша, но и выжить, многие сравнивают с The Crew, я же не играл спорить не стану, но в Distance, есть что то особенное, чего нет во многих гонках, что делает ее, весьма необычной (пока не поиграете не поймете).
В игре очень классная, стильная музыка, дизайн и трансфомация уровней впечатляет, множество ловушек, которые с первого и даже с 10-го раза не сразу пройдешь, прийдется много раз врезаться, разбиваться, погибать одним словом.
Игра многими аспектами, напоминает Трон, что подчеркивает стиль игры.
Помимо езды, на трассе, можно еще и летать, но не безконечно, в машине есть шкала перегрева, так что при длительном полете, будет перегрев и соответсвенно взрыв.
Очень много моментов в игре, где надо все схватывать на лету, иначе все сначала, либо с чекпоинта.
Хоть игра и Бета, выглядит и играется, как готовая игра.
Помимо основных карт, есть еще карты созданные игроками из Мастерской, в данный момент их уже очень много, что погрузит вас на десятки часов игры, в некоторые я уже сыграл и что приятно удивило, некоторые любительские карты, намного харкорнее основных. Помимо загрузки карт, вы можете сразу в игре попробовать создать свою, пофантазировать, сделать карту, на свой вкус.
Что косается кооператива и игры по сети в целом, вы можете с легкостью создать сервак, как отрытым, так и запароленным, но что бы сыграть с кем либо, вам для начала надо будет открыть порты ( для тез, у кого роутер). Играть с друзьями в коопе, интересно, весело и увлекательно, так что если вы решили с кем то погонять, не пожалеете.
Отдельно хочу добавить, про ловушки,есть около 8-ми видов разнообразных ловушек, один из которых лазеры, когда вы попадает по лазер, двигающий под опеределенным углом, вашу машину разрезает, под этим углом, но это не значит что нужно начинать сначала, вы можете доехать, на двух боковых колесах, либо на двух передних, без задней части машины и т.д. В этом игра приятно удивила, также если вам не хочется так ездить, можно ее просто взорвать кнопкой Т.
Из минуса в игре, как по мне только один, нужно привыкнуть к управлению.
В целом игра, стоит своих денег, хотите хардкор, отлчиную музыку и необычные уровни трасс, тогда Добро пожаловать в Distance.
9/10.

13937141.review: Think Trackmania + Wipeout; I can't love this game enough.

13934872.review:
[h1]What is it?[/h1]
A futuristic racing speed/style game very much in the style of Space Haste and Megarace and other one-time futuristic racing classics, but without opponents and set in a dark, neon vibe.  Atmospherically, this is the best sci-fi racer I've played.  The game offers a single player story campaign, arcade racing mode, multiplayer and a fully fledged Level Editor in which you can build your own tracks.  The Steam Workshop is already integrated, offering an infinite resource of game content far beyond what is already offered in the game itself.  Best of all, you can specify any random phrase or word in the editor - and a track, with scenery and such as in the campaign will be added for you.  While it IS just as easy as typing a word and racing the resultant track, there is some sophistication built in: using certain words in your 'phrase' will add more sprint sections, particular effects, or more flight etc.  It's utterly brilliant and you don't have to be a boffin in order to use it (well, I used it - 'nuff said...).  There is also a full-blown track editor too if you really do want to craft your own by hand.

[h1]How difficult is the racing?[/h1]
The racing part has absolute precision controls and difficulty in the single-player campaign curves gradually.  There have been past similar titles where you can find yourself bouncing from one wall to the other, but not this one - it's lovely to play.  Jumps and flips are taught by button-prompts on-screen.  Flight sections can be a fair bit tricky however.  Straight flight is easy enough, but the roll mechanics of the vehicle are very strange and I find it very tricky to fly around corners without rolling uncontrollably and spiralling to death.  It takes some skill to play these parts, but practise does pay off and reaching the end of the campaign feels like a genuine achievement. Until then, expect a challenge - especially with gravity being a thing when you're not sure which way up you're facing!  Falling to crash UPWARDS is often the only time I realise I'm completely flipped.  It's crazy and it's silly - but above all it's fun.  Gamepad ninjas will blaze through it, and then roll around the floor laughing at the rest of us with our 50+ attempts to get through that maddening flippy dodgy section without burning up.  

The game offers full controller support, including racing wheels and gamepads.  However, while the game can be played with a wheel, the best experience is experienced either with keyboard or gamepad for lighting-fast reaction play.

A word of warning: if you suffer from any photo-sensitive condition like photo-sensitive epilepsy, this game might not be for you because there is a lot of flashing neon.  Watch the trailer videos first and judge for yourself.


[h1]About that Early Access thing...[/h1]
The single-player campaign is rather short at the moment and, on its own, is not enough to warrant a typical AAA full game price.  However, there is a ton of content already in the Steam Workshop (some 700 new tracks the last time I looked) and these are seamlessly integrated with the game's 'Arcade' mode, plus the infinite possibilities of randomly seeded tracks, you'll never be bored.  As far as multiplayer goes, it seems really popular but check the game forums (I don't play multiplayer so I can't offer comment on this).  As a single-player product though, Steam reviews are giving an "overwhelmingly positive" for a very good reason: it really IS a great game already.  If you enjoy Wipeout-style games and not troubled by a lack of AI racers, then this should definitely be in your collection - it's worthy even as an Early Access title.

Highly recommended!

13932107.review:
While I never played Nitronic Rush, I did play Rush 2049 back nearly 15 years ago (fairly sure both on the Dreamcast and N64) which I guess heavily inspired Nitronic Rush. Rush 2049 back in the day felt really enjoyable and worth playing a lot of.  Stunt Mode in Distance feels exactly how I remember stunt mode in Rush 2049 feeling (which to be fair it probably feels a lot smoother in this, but its been nearly 15 years). As for the race tracks defualtly in the game they feel challenging, easy to complete, but hard to master. Even though there is not a lot of courses built in yes, because they are challenging courses with a lot of parts to master I can see spending a lot of time enjoying playing the same tracks over just to get that little bit better each time.

With that said, it is definitly early access, "Story"/ "Adventure" mode right now is just a handfull of tracks that you complete with no AI drivers to compete against, no ghost to race against, heck it doesn't even tell you your time at the end when you complete a track it just goes straight into the next one.

To sum up, its definitly not finished yet, it has about 11 longer tracks, 7ish short challenge tracks, and 7ish stun arenas, but currently 366 user created tracks. The courses are highly repeatable because they have a high challenge and learning curve, while user created tracks will be hit and miss, there is definitly a lot to try from.

Would I recommend this game? While the tracks feel a bit empty without an option to race your ghost, I would definitly recommend this game, specially if you liked Rush 2049 or Nitronic Rush. This game is great to play by yourself and even better to play with friends. Obviously its a lot better with friends, but unlike games like Mario Party or Smash Brothers  that pretty much require friends to be enjoyable, it is still really good even if you have no one to play with.

Now to download some user generated tracks to see how they feel.

DISTANCE IS FINALLY HERE!!! PRAISE THE SUN!!!

Distance, the most innovative racing game on the market. The immaculate child of Tron, F-Zero, and dubstep put together. Ever since I got hooked Nitronic Rush (the game's free predecessor coded entirely out of C++), I have been waiting for a true sequel or at least multiplayer of some sort. Then I heard about the Kickstarter for Distance Alpha and I was ONE DAY LATE!!! The game has been in development ever since the last Nitronic Rush update in 2012, maybe even before that. And now they release this game as Early Access? Hah! This Indie game is more full and complete-looking than many AAA titles on the market today! Distance is practically the only game I bought on steam for full price, because I think it is worth the full $20. 
(Note: in the world of $60 AAA games like CoD, $20 for a multiplayer game like this is pretty darn good)

Gameplay

Distance is "racing" game but most of the time your objective is to simply survive the track. Fall off the beaten path, and it is up to you to get back on. Your car has boosters, rotational thrusters and even wings, but that doesn't make it easy. You are constantly riding on walls, doing tricks off jumps, keeping track of gravity, and avoiding evil robotic obstacles. These include but are not limited to: giant buzz saws, rollers, spikey rollers, lasers that cut your car in half, robots that fly ahead of you and land in your way, walls that pop up from the ground, and my personal favorite: the lamp post. 
The faster you ride on a wall, the more you stick to it. When you make a checkpoint, your overheat-meter goes down and your car is regenerated if it got cut by a laser. You can also reduce your overheating by landing tricks.


The game supports singleplayer and online multiplayer (an upgrade from Nitronic Rush), sports a user-friendly level editor, and even allows splitscreen with gamepads (a nice touch). Downloading community levels is easy via Steam Workshop. There are the normal racing game modes, and some different ones like "tag", and "speed and style" where doing tricks will reduce your overall time.

Flavor

Distance would be nowhere NEAR what it is today without its awesome, intense flavor! The setting is very Tron-inspired. As you ride down the colorful circuit-y roads which twist and turn through the cybernetic cityscape, you can't help but admire the fact that everything is flashy and genuinely cool. Even some community level creators add a different flavor to the game with their levels; they will thrill you with all manner of trickery. Many things that light up in the game pulses with the intense beat. Which leads me to another topic: 

The Music. Oh God the music is amazing. It falls in that dubstep/techno genre. It blends SO WELL with the visuals of the game. And lemme tell you something: I hate dubstep, techno, or whatever it is with a PASSION. But for some reason the music in Distance, its just different. I can't explain it... but it sounds great.

Distance, by the way, is appropriate and available for all ages. There is no language, gore (obviously), or even words spoken by a person. The community level designers are clean. You don't even need a mouse to play.

I love Distance. It should be clear to you by now. PLEASE BUY IT!! The one downfall of this game, (mainly because it is in early access) is that it lacks a full player base, sometimes I cannot find a multiplayer game at all. It needs more players to survive. I feel this game can become a prime example to the gaming community, of how Indie games should be developed, put on Early Access, and released. That is why I recommend Distance to every gamer.

TL;DR: Buy Distance.

13865572.review:
Think Trackmania, Portal and Tron all mashed together. I absolutely love it! I loved Nitronic Rush but thought it felt a bit old. Then I got Distance, problem solved. Beatiful graphics and an epic soundtrack together with the lumo/electro/whateveritis lighting give it the most amazing atmosphere. And make it trippy as hell. Seriously, wow.

The simple mechanic of the jumping and the directional thrusters to let you do tricks and twist the car in the air add so much more to this and put it ahead of all the other racing games I've tried. There is nothing else like in this game when you are moving at high speed and rapidly jumping and flipping to get onto the next piece of track.

The obstacles can vary in function, which is nice considering there are only 3 or 4 types (saw blade, laser, barrier, but some can move, some can appear only when you're nearby, some can be different sizes, etc, the variety works here). Furthermore these obstabcles have a signifigant impact on you, hitting a sawblade on the side can send you spinning off the track, skimming too close to a laser will chop off a piece of your car leaving you with half a car, etc.

Then there's replayability, so much of it, really. Many of the levels have multiple ways to get to the finish, some are marked 'detour' some you have to discover by keen viewing or complete accident, some are quick, some are harder/longer, some are simply an alternate. The currently released official levels don't show this as clearly but this game is in beta so don't judge. This brings us to another feature, the built in level editor. This gives the community a chance to make their own levels and if you look at the workshop page you will see... so many levels. And they are all great! They also make brilliant use of the whole 'multiple ways to get to the end' idea and have created some awesome looking tracks.

Pros:
Beatiful Graphics
Awesome soundtrack
Slick controls (I would reccomend a controller though)
Tracks with multiple paths -> Replayability for dauys
Community levels -> Even more replayability (did I mention that these community levels are actually brilliant?)

Cons:
Keyboard controls are iffy and take some getting used to, even if you normally play keyboard and mouse
The whole 'early access' thing, aside from community levels, it does feel a little incomplete (but that's because it's in Beta still).

Overall, for $20 I would not hesitate for a second to try this game. If anyone wants to try before you buy kinda thing, look for 'Nitronic Rush', it was essentially the prototype for this game, but it's free and will give you a feel for the control system, the jumping and twisting, the flying, and the trippy tracks. Really, if you like racing games and want something different, or if you enjoy games like trackmania, give this a go. It's fantastic.

A brilliant, beautiful, yet chaotic, survival-racing game. I've never had so much fun in a game that involved just driving before. 13748906.review:
Distance is an indie game like no other, taking racing and platforming to the next level. Made by some of the same creators of Nitronic Rush, who graduated from Digipen, these dedicated developers work every day with lots of passion on this outstanding game. I've honestly never been more hooked on a game such as this one, thanks to it's amazing gameplay, community, build-in speechlessly-powerful level editor, and random track generation system, you are in for lots of replay value with over 2000 community workshop level submissions and it's "trackmogrify" mode which allows you to enter any seed you want, and a track is generated based on what you put in (modifiers can be used to alter the difficulty, length, etc.). You are able to customize your car by changing the car colors, but unfortunetly, no custom cars are possible due to complications with leaderboard compatability, hitboxes giving different physics (which can give different leaderboard results and can screw with the top times.). Good news, there is confirmed one new vehicle model for all players in the works, and another, backer-exclusive vehicle, to be in the game prior to launch (these new car models will have the same hitboxes as to avoid messing with leaderboard times being screwed with). For the level editor, it is one of the easiest-to-learn, easiest-to-use, most powerful editor you will ever get your hands on. You can change many settings of any object available such as, but not limited to: Colors, emit colors, lights, rotation axis and speed (animator component, axisrotation if supported, or rigidbody if supported), spline road mannipulation, simples (can change bumpmap strength, emit texture, texture scales, togglable collisions, transparency, colors, reflect settings, etc.), particles (also very powerful with many settings such as texture, amount, colors, speed, acceleration, gravity, lifetime, offset, etc.), event triggers, addable components (a system where you can add special properties to any object that allows extra effects and spiciness to your map), and many other features that are too many to mention on here. A couple other major features of the game are Arcade mode, and Adventure mode. Arcade mode currently has a couple gamemodes like Sprint, Stunt (currently getting a big revamp as of 6/14/17), Reverse Tag, Challenge and Trackmogrify. Sprint and Reverse Tag are the most popular gamemodes. Sprint mode is straight-forward where you must get from point A, to point B in as little as time as possible. NOTE: Unlike most racing games, Distance does not bind you to the track against your will. Your car has 4 abilities: Boost, Jump, Fly, and Grip. These abilities allow you to move off the track and drive along the walls of buildings and any other piece of environment to carve your own path to the exit. Some players may tell you "Skipping is back and no one should do it", that is not true by any means. The game's core mechanics set the stage for skipping tracks, and the devs themselves encourage skipping if possible (Not telling you how to play, you can choose to not skip if you want. But you'll find that the global leaderboards will always have its top times be made by skipping). It is a big part of the game that some players don't realize, and it should be a known thing to everyone. Reverse tag mode is exacly what it says on the tin. One player has the tag bubble, and everyone is trying to get it. First player to 3 minutes is the winner. Challange mode is basically like sprint, except no checkpoints, and no respawning, and short tough tracks. Stunt mode is where you must rack up the most points by performing the best/most tricks out of anyone within a time limit. The last gamemode is Adventure mode. Although it is currently short and unfinished, when this game exits early access this year (the current goal is this year, and they are damn determined to get it done this year. They have even hired recently 3 community members to help finish adventure mode while the original devs work on the other things). Adventure 2.0 will be published as one giant update instead of small incrimental updates.

To wrap it all up, i'm going to compile a list of all the things mentioned above:
____________________________________________________________________

Gamemodes:
- Adventure, Sprint, Challange, Stunt, Trackmogrify, Reverse Tag

Level Editor:
- Build-in powerful editor that is easy to use/learn (the same editor the devs use to make their levels)
- Simples 2.0, Particles, Spline roads, Event triggers, Components, Buildings, Teleporters, Biodomes, Customizable skybox/fog/ambient colors/lighting, and lots more!

Customization:
- Car hull color, glow color, hull2 color, and sparkle color
- 2 new vehicles are confirmed to be added before release (one a public car, the other a backer-only car) Both cars will use the same hitbox as the original to avoid screwing with the leaderboard times with different physics

Replayability:
- Over 2000 workshop level submissions
- Trackmogrify allows random track generation simply by entering a seed and watching it generate!

Replay system:
- Watch/race against ghosts offline in any any track that has been played!

Adventure 2.0:
- Massive update containing a completely new adventure experience, all new/updated music, tons of new level editor assets and components
- Near-release before Distance leaves early access

Community:
- We have a discord server available where a majority of our community hangs around. Come join us! (look at survivethedistance.com or in the steam discussions for the invite link)

Updates:
- This is a passion project by the devs. There are updates to the game and that ill persist post-release for a good while. This game has been in development for 5 years, and been in Early Access for ~3 years. Please give it time, this is an indie team and they are working hard every day to not rush this project and give us the best-quality product they can. Updates are being made. (Some take longer than others, it's just the way it is) Just take a look at the change logs when an update is made, or you can follow the devs on their twitter. Alternativly you can join the Distance discord and keep up-to-date there.
____________________________________________

Hope you find this review helpful, and i am proud to be with such an amazing community and follow the greatest devs on EA. Truly excels at being an Early Access title and feels like a finished product as is. But will not leave EA until it is good and ready.

13715058.review: Distance - это аркадная гонка, находящаяся в раннем доступе. Игру можно обозвать Трекманией в стиле Трона, и вы будите правы. По количеству драйва обе игры идут бок в бок. Однако если в Трекмании у вас есть только вы и ваш скилл, то в Distance у вас в придачу идет и сама машина, которая способна прыгать, летать и ускоряться. Езда по стенам, полеты, прыжки, лазеры с пилами - вот что ждет вас почти в каждом заезде Distance. Возможности машины так же позволяют вернуться на трассу без нажатия кнопки рестарта, к примеру полет, если вы вылетели за трасу после неудачного столкновения (если у вас конечно не сильно большой перегрев, иначе быстрее будет рестартнуться). Так же повреждения влияют на машину, и даже после серьезных повреждений (к примеру, вас распелило поперек лазером) игра не возвращает вас на контрольный пункт, а позволяет ехать дальше до следующего, где машина полностью востановляется. Нравиться так же звуковое сопровождение. Графика... не могу сказать про качество на максимальных, ибо мой компьютер тянет толко средние настройки, но и на них игра выглядит прекрасно. Если у вас есть лишние деньги, не пожалейте на эту игру, она их стоит

13709732.review:
To start off, I'd like to point out that I do not like most racing games, and I'd also like to point out that Distance is not most racing games. Distance puts you in control of a vehicle that can fly with wings, has jets on all sides, can wall ride, jump, flip, and do anything in between. The controls feel fantastic, the music is amazing, the enviorments are immersive, huge and explorable. 

There is an adventure mode that acts like the tutorial and tells the story of the game (which is actually quite good, especially when you realize it's being told through a race track), however the real fun begins when you enter the challenge maps of the game. The developers respect player skill and are not afraid to give you a real challenge. Add in community levels and steam workshop, and you'll have replayability and new maps forever. 

I can't love this game enough, if you feel on the edge about it, I'd highly reccomend trying out Nitronic Rush. It is free and it is the predecessor to Distance. It functions relatively the same as Distance, and will give you a feel for what you can expect from Distance. However, keep in mind that Distance is much more polished, detailed and has a lot of improvements.

13707775.review:
Pros:
[list]
    [*] The Car has Reaction Control System (RCS) much like you'd find on a spaceship to adjuct attitude or rotation while making a jump
    [*] It has a flight system that works well in game
    [*] Electo-Magnet under the car keeps it attached to the walls/surfaces you drive on
    [*] Tron-like look, and simulation feeling
    [*] Obstacles that actually obstruct your driving.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
    [*] Aside from community levels, the tracks/obstacles feel the same
    [*] The game is still early in development and lacks content
    [*] Car feels like something out of a new line of hotwheels (Potential Toy-line?)
    [*] When you race, you can 95% of the time just spam the speed-boost making the drive button useless.
[/list]

All in all 9/10 fun racing game, AMAZING mechanics and feel complete aside from content. Gives you more than most of these racing games, aslong as you like the sci-fi look/feel of this game you won't be dissapointed.

I've played a fair few early access games in 2014, and many of them make me hate to see the words 'EARLY ACCESS GAME' on a store page. Distance is a pleasing diversion from this norm, for beta the game has excellent flow and re-playability, not based on a catalouge of features, but simply wanting to do it better each time. Add to the visually dynamic led-neon-futureworld theme a soundtrack that sounds like something Deadmau5 produced and the result is a game that's going to blow the minds of our friendly nieghbourhood stoner gamers. 13602008.review:
I've waited to get this game ever since I saw it on the Greenlight, and this game is what you see. A great spiritual sequel to Nitronic Rush with nothing missing and much added. 

I will note this though: If you've maxed out your settings but get lag, real-time reflections cause lots of lag for me. Turning it off DOESN'T remove reflections, you just get premapped reflections instead. Some levels are also laggier than others. For my GTX 750 Ti SC, changing the render distance to medium gave me a solid framerate of ~40 FPS. Higher distances drop me to ~25-30FPS on levels like Corruption.


EDIT: I still do like this game, but, the updates are very infrequent and PR is a bit quiet. I understand that the game can't be done overnight, but, I'd like to see more updates. I've lost interest in the meantime. If it updates, I'll always come back to it though.

13587490.review: This game is an awesome survival-racing game set in a virtual, computer like world. It is a spiritual succesor to Nitronic Rush (which is free game that you can play if you aren't sure about buying this game). Your goal is to race to the finish line as fast as possible while avoiding death traps like buzz saws, lasers, or a variety of other deadly things. It also has local and online multiplayer. It is a very fun game, which I highly recommend! 8.5/10

13523075.review:
This is so incredibly fun! As some of you know this is from a concept that was created in college by the guys, it was called nitronic rush. After what they have achieved from there to Distance is particularly amazing! 

[h1] My first thoughts [/h1]

I had in my mind that this was early access (just released as early access on december the 10th). As soon as i got into playing the visuals are spot on, the gameplay is extremely fun and addicting and the overall concept is great. Yes, then i discovered the mechanics: Boosting, jumping, flying and wall jumping; crazy stuff like that!

[h1] THE POTENTIAL [/h1]

I can't even begin to explain the potential this game has, at the moment it actually is decently polished but not many official levels and progression pointers and goals, i'd imagine that to be fun. But there is the community making levels and there is a powerful level editor, it's nice that it has that. There is the Adventure mode which is short at the moment (and there isn't a story to it really). Arcade mode which has various gamemodes in it to play your community levels and official levels. 

[h1] So, do i reccomend this game? [/h1]

Yes, i do. If you'd like to support it at it's current state i'd definetley reccomend for you to purchase it. It also has multiplayer and a friendly community which is great! 

[b]SIMILAR GAMES:[/b] Trackmania, LittleBigPlanet Karting.

13517507.review:
May not be the racing game you've been looking for to put years of commitment into, but, at the same time, it is. Believe it when it says "Survival Racing". I can't wait to see more of this game. Great concept, amazing execution, loads of content thanks to the in game level creator, and plenty of overall content to keep you coming back somewhat consistently at the least. The best game I could compare it to would be San Francisco Rush 2049, Cruisin Exotica/USA, or even Hydro Thunder. It is absolutely amazing, even if you're not into racing games, this is one you could really sink time into.
To play the game, all you need to do is play the tutorial and pay attention. To win, you need patience. There is no learning curve to this game; it is a cliff. You just have to throw yourself off the edge over and over again until you learn where the pull chord is, only to drift into lava or get grabbed by a passing airplanes turbine. Even so, it is fun in its own right.

13501771.review:
Personal note (23/07/2017): New particle-, material-, animation- & trigger system make the editor now Turing complete! The developers have stepped up their amazing game even more!
Personal note (18/03/2016): One of the few steam games that you always get back to and never get bored of.
Personal note (23/12/2015): Most underrated game on steam.
---------------------------------

This unique racing game is a lot of fun! I played the story mode, uploaded my own level ('[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=360234452]Damnation[/url]'), started multiplayer and instantly met friendly players whom I played hours with!

[u][h1]Pros[/h1][/u]
[list]
[*] [b]Level Editor[/b] (Easy to handle; getting started tutorial; comfort tools like '[i]move along the track[/i]' or '[i]flip[/i]' makes it easy to decorate a track.)
[*] [b]Workshop[/b] with a lot (and by that I mean 'freaking grains of sand at a beach' lot!) of user created levels.
[*] [b]Cool driving mechanics[/b] like deployable wings for flying capability, deployable jet thrusters and hydraulic jumping to manoeuvre in zero gravity fields or to twist the car around for wall/ceiling rides.)
[*] [b]Kickstarter project[/b] with already unlocked goals which will be implemented when the game is out of beta: [url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1857884659/distance-a-next-generation-arcade-racer]Click[/url]
Those are for example: [strike][i]Replay/Spectate Modes[/i] (With fast forward/play/pause and driving against your Ghost.),
Cinematic camera angles/free camera and [i]Random Track Generation Mode[/i] (create vast number of unique tracks at the click of a button with parameters for tweaking and capability to share specific seeds so you can show discovered tracks to friends. You are even able to post-edit and workshop-up those!)[/strike] [b]EDIT:[/b] [u]Strikethroughs are implemented![/u]
[*] [b]Various Modes[/b] like [i]Challenge, Sprint, Stunt, Speed & Style, Free Roam[/i]..
[*] [b]Multiplayer[/b] create and host server lobbies with a push of a button!
[*] [b]Great audio[/b] which makes the tracks colors pulse with the beat! (You can redirect the game to use your custom audio files!)
[*] [b]Nice, friendly and funny community[/b]
[*] [b]Support for various platforms and controller.[/b]

[*] Small team of devs who  are really confident to make a much more polished and professional game sequel to Nitronic Rush. They have key developers from Nitronic Rush in their team and bring much experience with them.
[*] Great forum moderators who take every suggestion thread into consideration and give constructive criticism. There is also a thread with many already suggested ideas listed: [url=http://survivethedistance.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=797]Click[/url]
Many of those got green light from the devs.
[*] Moderators and some devs are playing the game nonstop themself and checking out on the workshop levels, too!
[/list]

[u][h1]Cons[/h1][/u]
[list]
[*] Not a fan of the [i]Unity Engine[/i], but I start to like it when thinking about what Distance accomplished with it.
[*] [strike][b]Beta status[/b] is missing many promised features and is short on many Multiplayer Host options like kick/ban.[/strike]
Also, Adventure Mode & everything is incomplete and subject to change etc..
[*] Not being able to import custom content (audio, textures, models, scripts) to the level editor yet. (But there're simple geometric objects like cubes you can create objects with, group them and save them as "costum object".)
[*] Multiplayer is sometimes dead. No servers or anything. People come to live when it is getting midnight in europe.
[/list]
[b][u]As you can see this game is pretty much worth a buy![/u][/b]

[strike]The next stable update will have better physics, better handling and a great cockpiet view!! I already tested it on the experimental build.[/strike] [b]EDIT:[/b] [u]Strikethroughs are implemented![/u]

13476200.review:
If Nitronic Rush was Narbacular Drop, then this is Portal... 2.

Everything about Nitronic Rush has been given a staggering upgrade. The controls are dialed-in just right, the level layouts have very obviously been playtested extensively. I've played the game for less than two hours  and completed most of the currently standing content. Now this isn't a bad thing, I spent a huge amount of time playing Nitronic Rush, so that counts as experience. The new player will not be able to breeze through what's there anywhere near as quickly. And on top of that, the game is still in beta so there's clearly lots more planned. There are still a few minor things that need polish/explanation, mostly on the UI side of things. But the game underneath is absolutely incredible.

Missing out on this game is doing yourself a disservice. Don't make that mistake.

13416942.review:
Distance is quite easily the best Early Access game I have played in the last two years.
There is one simple reason behind this: IT WORKS!

[b]TLDR OR SEE MY VIDEO BELOW [/b]: Distance is a fast paced time trial racer, it has a few different modes available and is opened up to Single player, multiplayer and split screen LAN multiplayer.

There are plenty of unique and interesting official maps to keep you busy, but if you set the best times on these there is the extensive community workshop with over 200+ tracks (from date of writing) available to download separately (or all at once).

Compete against friends or the global community to try and dominate the leaderboards.

[b] ------ FULL REVIEW ------ [/b]

[b]Adventure Mode:[/b]
The game sports an adventure mode where you race your car through the official maps in as quick a time as possible while avoiding all the crazy lasers, buzz saws and twisting and winding roads while preventing your car from overheating by quickly getting through the next checkpoint.

Although there isn't a story per se the tracks are highly immersive and draw you into what can only be classified as a dystopian city scape. Throughout the adventure you seem to move from a potentially busy vibrant city into a dark lost society. If you put your imagination to it I am sure you can come up with some interesting scenarios as to what happened to this world!

[b]Arcade:[/b]
Arcade mode is where it really gets interesting. There are a few modes to choose from:

[b]Sprint:[/b] Basically get to the end of the track as quickly as possible to get your name on the global scoreboards. Go through checkpoints to prevent the car from overheating. Reset if you screw up too badly and push yourself to the limit to gain the fastest time possible! (this mode counts towards global leaderboards).

[b]Stunt:[/b] Try to do as many flips, flights and wall rides as possible within the time limit to gain the greatest score. This is played in an arena mode with plenty of ramps and heights to get the maximum amount of flips in before that inevitable landing, just be sure to land upright or the subsequent landing may be more of an explosion!

[b]Reverse Tag:[/b] There is an orb which must be collected. Each player will compete to steal the orb from the other player. Whoever can keep the orb for the longest time will win. This is played in an arena style map which has plenty of cheeky little areas to try and trip your competitors up.


[b]Workshop:[/b]
From the date of writing there are over 200 community created tracks to try out. There are different tracks designed for each individual mode. Each track varies in length and difficulty with some sprints taking less than a minute, to first time tries clocking in at over 10 minutes.

One problem with the workshop currently is everyone must have downloaded the community maps themselves, they don't just download from the host. There is however a quick solution to this on the workshop with a "subscribe to all mods" tool which allows you to instantly subscribe to all the tracks available.

[b]Track Editor:[/b]
The game ships with its own in game track editor which provides all the tools you need to create some really exciting / wacky tracks which you can then upload to the Steam workshop and let others race and rate. There is massive room for some truly exciting and unique track experiences.

[b]Leaderboards:[/b]
The leaderboards are what help to make this game what it is. You can see times set by the top 1000 in the global community but also filter down to personal best times and friends. 
If like me you want to be at the top of your friends leaderboards you should definitely give this game a try!

[b]Controller:[/b]
The front of Steam says the game has partial controller support although while using my Xbox controller it seemed to work 100% fine, I was able to re-bind keys however I liked, vibration function works no problems.

If you prefer to use the keyboard then this is fine too, again it has 100% re-bind capabilities.

--------- [b] CONCLUSION ---------[/b]

As mentioned at the start this is the best Early Access I have played in a long time. It works flawlessly without any crashes and very few if any bugs. One issue I have noticed is when watching another person finish a race it can get stuck playing the same loop, however this isn't game breaking and when they finish / the timer runs out the game will continue as usual.

One small problem with the community maps is every person wanting to race online must have individually downloaded the maps. They don't download from the host. There is however a quick solution to this on the workshop with a "subscribe to all mods" tool which allows you to instantly subscribe to all the tracks available.

The game is still in beta and already I would say 8.5/10 I can't give it more because the adventure mode is not yet finished and the issues with online downloading of maps. But it is well on its way to becoming a fantastic game which could give hours of fun and frustration!


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uxq5m4A3hVk

13380524.review:
Distance is one of those few racing games that feel really unique. 
There is normal racing, wall jumping, no gravity, flying & jumping. 
These are all ways for you to finish the different tracks (And there are a lot due to a good community), many tracks have more than one way to finish the race, and sometimes one of the options might be better, other times it's the same or just up to your skill. 

The game offer a few different game modes, spring which is normal racing, go from start to end, you can respawn if you fail and so on. The other is challenge, it's like sprint but shorter and no respawn, so prepare to fail quite a lot. There is also stunt, the least attractive game mode this far, where you are just suppose to do different stunts to gather a high score. There is also a multiplayer only game mod with the name "Tag" or something like that.

Tag works like the classic child game where one or more are chasing the others trying to "tag" them, however here it's the other way around, everyone is chasing the one with the forcefield, and you win when you've held the "tag" for three minutes. Quite fun. 

The car is customizable when it comes to colours, I do hope they add more customization though, since it's always a plus. But for a early access game this game works really well! It never crashes unless you've tabbet it for quite some time. 

All maps have a high score screen where you are not only competing against your old record, but also against all other players who play this game. I would love if they added something like Trials where you can see how the different players have been driving, because sometimes you do suspect cheating.

I really recommend this, one of my best buys this year!

13378507.review:
I have decided to rewrite my review from scratch and delete the older one as I have now played more of the game and can give a better account of my experience. 

The good:

I love the setting of the game. I like the Tron-esque visuals, the throbbing lights that dance to the rhythm of the beat, and the accompanying soundtrack. Overall, the atmosphere is done well and delivers on what you see in the screenshots. 

The handling of the cars are also pretty good, and a keyboard is a viable alternative (some even say a keyboard is better than a controller in this game). The main driving controls are easy to learn, though it may take some time to fully grasp the controls to do 90- and 180-degree flips, as well as the controls for the flying sections. 

Level editors. I have not explored this myself yet but I have played a number of user created tracks and it seems like a pretty good and functional feature. 

The not so good:

Multiplayer is “broken” in the sense that the game condones “cheating”. Some people may like this, but I don’t. Basically, all the top racers and top time in the leaderboards are set by people who fly far off the racing track and find their own shortcuts (through buildings etc). I personally hope that the developers can consider adding a separate mode that somehow mandates you cannot leave the track (via checkpoints for example). 

Game isn’t properly optimized well at the moment, though the developers acknowledge this and have come on record to say it will be improved. Still, be wary that you may need to turn down quite a number of settings on a card that exceeds the recommended requirements and even then not get 60fps all the time (I have a GTX 750 SC for reference). Performance in multiplayer is much worse than single player.

The adventure mode at present has zero story to it. It is a glorified tutorial at best. I find it hard to believe there will be a story by the time v1.0 releases since the devs say more levels are to be added, but in the 45 mins or so of content that there already is, there is nothing like that. Still, adventure mode is a must to grasp the basics of the game to move on into multiplayer.

The difficulty is kind of high at present, and it may turn off many people. It would be good if the developers can allow the community to rate tracks with different difficulties, especially those that are user created. Would be also nice for the developers to create some “normal” racing maps that don’t have so many outrageously difficult sections!

There are other broken multiplayer features. If you join a lobby with a user created track, the game just tells you that you have a missing level, but doesn’t prompt you to download it. Also, if you finish a race early, you may have to wait for minutes. Would be nice if there is only a 30 or 60 seconds window from the time the winner finishes before moving on. 

There are a few others things that should be in I believe. A single player mode that allows you to race against CPU AI (currently, you can only do speedruns in single player). Also, randomized obstacle placements would be nice. 

---------------------------------------

Bottomline, I would say that overall I am not too happy with my purchase. Yes, this is in Early Access, but I don’t see how they can change so much of the game. If this game sounds interesting to you fundamentally, then sure, go get it. But if you are like me, expecting a more “normalish” arcade experience, I suggest you stay away.

13370159.review:
Distance est une petite merveille !

Moi qui d'ordinaire n'est pas un grand fan des jeux de courses automobiles, je dois dire que j'ai beaucoup aimé y jouer (Et je prendrais plaisir à continuer).

Le gameplay est dynamique, et demande une bonne concentration (obstacles, changement gravitationnel, séquence de vol...). Au départ, la maîtrise complète du véhicule peut être compliqué. Mais quand on commence comprendre comment ça fonctionne, on prend un réel plaisir à manoeuvrer ce petit bijou.

Les contrôles permettent de "freiner", et le boost qui est disponible à une durée limité par un système de surcharge.
Mais des anneaux présent à espace régulier sur les circuit, ou faire des figures pendant les sauts, les vols, ou les zones sans gravité, permettent de réinitialiser la surcharge pour pouvoir recommencer à utiliser le boost sans attendre. Et c'est la que réside le défi. Il est possible de passer l'intégralité d'un circuit avec le boost activé si tous les aspects du gameplay sont maîtrisés, ce qui est completement jouissif.

Côté graphique, le jeux est propre, épuré, sans prétention, et c'est ce qui le rend agréable et fluide.
J'ai eu quelques drop à 40 fps pendant une dizaine de secondes à certains moments (Je joue en 120), mais le reste du temps, tout tourne parfaitement bien.

La bande son correspond parfaitement avec le style, et l'atmosphère du jeu. Et le mélange de toute ces choses rends l'expèrience vraiment sympathique.

Il y a tout de même quelques soucis, mais il s'agit d'un accès anticipé, et c'est pour ça qu'on pardonne volontier les écarts.

Dans l'immédiat, le seul bémol pour moi, c'est le temps qu'on mets pour terminer le mode aventure ( un peu moins d'une heure ) mais un petit message nous dit qu'il viendra à être compléter dans le futur. Et les nombreux mode disponibles, ainsi que la possibilité de créer des circuits, ou d'éssayer ceux que d'autres on fait, rend l'expérience presque illimité. (Je n'ai pas encore éssayé autre choses que le mode aventure)

Un jeu que je ne regrette pas d'avoir acheté !
