13338668.review:
EDIT: I'm editing this review to say this truly is one of the best racing games I've played in a [i]looooooong[/i] time.  This may even be my favorite racer of 2014 (Although, to be fair, there weren't too many racers in 2014). The track editor seems really confusing to me, but apparently not to others because the tracks on workshop are ridiculous. Also, 3 hours may not seem like a lot of time for this game, but considering the short "campaign," most of it is workshop levels. Of course, keep in mind this is still an EA game and there are bugs (like being able to take advantage of flight and skip entire portions of track) but overall this is a fun, refreshing game. 

Disclaimer: I came into the game with absolutely no expectations. I had never heard of the studio or the previous game.

Summary: Distance is a game that's reminicent of a combination of Trackmania and the Hotwheels stunt games. Even in this state, it's very polished. My one complaint thus far is the lack of content, however, like Trackmania, this game offers a full fledged track editor even this early in development. If you like survival racing games but you're concerned of the shortness of the campaign, wait until the full launch. If you like the aformented but enjoy creating content yourself/playing other player's content, just get this now.

Gameplay: The gameplay consists of survival racing, where you manuever your car around obstacles and flip the car to reach other surfaces. Very fast paced and fluid. Only complaint thus far is sometimes it felt like the car flipped too slowly, but it's minor. Also want to note the attention to detail here. When a lazer cuts the car in half, it actually feels like that half is missing and the car is considerably harder to drive.

Graphics: Game looks pretty nice even now. There are more graphical options than most AAA titles that come to PC. Optimization is okay right now. On a 760, 3770, and 8GB of RAM, I'm getting 30-60 fps.

Story: There is a story, but frankly I skipped the cutscenes.

13337990.review:
[h1] Ladies and gentlemen, this is what an Early Access game should look like. [/h1]

I bought [b] Distance [/b] because I wanted to play a polished version of [b] Nitronic Rush [/b] (which is its predecessor), but now, the question is, did I get that? The answer is... yes. Not only did I get it, I got far beyond my expectations. This game is [b] Nitronic Rush 2.0 [/b] and hot dang, is it worth the money. It's stunning visuals and flawless gameplay alone make it worth the money. After the disaster that was last game I bought that happened to be Early Access (StarForge), I was a little paranoid, but once I swallowed my fears and picked this up I realized that this is a shining example of an Early Access game done right. While in its current state it may not have the most content (The actual campaign itself only lasted me about 45 minutes) doesn't mean it isn't worth the buy. The game itself in its current build is incredibly stable and beautifully optimized. I was able to run it on ultra while managing to stay at a constant 60 FPS with no problems, which is rare for an Early Access title. Now most importantly, the gameplay. The gameplay itself is incredibly enjoyable. Anyone who has played and enjoyed [b] Nitronic Rush [/b] will agree. Basically its parkour cars. Carkour? I don't know. Anyway, driving in a long Tron esc environment with everything out to get you is amazing. It goes as far as standard-y obstacle-y road blocks, to giant, glowing CIRCULAR SAWS, to laser beams all trying to kill you in one happy package. Speaking of the laser beams, they are by far the most enticing obstacles I've ever seen. Whenever you come into contact with one your vehicle will get cut accordingly. Not even joking. It's like Metal Gear Solid Revengeance: Car edition. Whenever I saw one I always had a little debate in my mind, "should I just risk it and get cut in half just so I could look awesome driving a now cut in half car?" (the answer was almost always yes). This made the game enjoyable and added quite a bit of variety. There is even a bit where there is zero gravity, which for me was a magical experience to be able to just admire the graphics while I float through space. This game is worth every penny. Get it.

Review summed up:

Is really good. Throw money here now.
11/10

13336280.review:
This game is really, really fun. I'm not big into racing games, but watching the trailer wowed me enough to buy this one without hesitation, and I don't regret it. I was psyched to see the game run perfectly on my Nvidia Surround setup without any tweaking, and this made the experience all the more immersive.

I started with Adventure mode which moves you through the levels, learning the controls a bit at a time. For the most part, they're very easy to pick up on, and extremely fun to put into action. You can boost your car for added speed, jump over obstacles, and even sprout "wings" and start flying, for limited distances. You're also able to flip the car 90 or 180 degrees onto other tracks. All of this while racing at breakneck speeds on a psychedelic course full of deadly lasers, blades, and other obstacles. Checkpoints cool your car down and save your progress, and there are some other cool effects that I won't spoil. The game kept me constantly surprised and I was on the edge of my seat, thrilled after surviving obstacle after obstacle, going faster than ever. It's seriously exhilerating to play. The soundtrack only adds to this - driving beats that match the style and pace of the game perfectly. I would like to find out where I could buy the soundtrack, though I was able to find a previous album for the original game on the artist's Bandcamp page. Really excellent music!

The one downside that I've found to this game is that some of the flips you have to do are pretty unforgiving. I thought I was doing well with them in one particularly flip-heavy track, only to reach a point where I died dozens of times trying to get it right. Gravity was just not allowing me to reach the other side of the track before falling into oblivion, and I think it's because I had lost my speed from earlier in the track, so continuing from the checkpoint wasn't working. I had to back way up and speed up from there, and then I made it. Throughout the levels, there are a few particularly difficult moments like this, and while I've gotten better at them, they can still take you out of the exhileration and into frustration, if only until you get past them. But just like any game, you learn a bit more every time your car explodes, and mastering those techniques and pulling it off feels really, really good. I would boil it down to this - if you think you would enjoy the survival part of "survival racing", than this game is for you. If the thought of watching your car explode over and over while you lose any chance of beating your best time sounds annoying, you may want to look elsewhere. But you'd be missing out!

Not all of the traps are a bother. The lasers and blades are awesome. Not too hard to avoid with some deft maneuvering, and even if you do get sliced, it's pretty cool when your car is cut in half but you still make it through the checkpoint (and your car regenerates). Great concept, and it adds to the excitement of the racing by making you think, how the hell did I just survive that?

I've started on the time trials and those have been fun too. There are also a few other modes, plus custom levels that others have built, and that you can build yourself. I look forward to checking those out. For $16, I feel this game is a steal. Definitely has a lot of replay value and would be a fun game to share when friends come over. I'm happy to see that the devs plan to release this on PS4 next year. It's definitely worthy of a wide audience.

13328842.review:
*WILL BE UPDATED AT FULL RELEASE*

Distance is simply one of the best games on Early Access. The sequel to Nitronic Rush is fast, intense, and a joy to play.

The graphics in this game are glorious. The tron-like style is perfect for this type of game and the amount of color on the screen is a treat for your eyes. The cars look great, with the ability to edit the car's color and glow - making each unique to the certain player when playing online. The graphics are also optimized well, making it run on lower-end machines. 

Distance at it's core is a survival racing game. Throughout the levels, you can do things like jump, boost, twist and fly. The levels have a directed path, but with the ability to fly - it adds an extra element of exploration and freedom. The game as of now has a strong amount of game modes. Adventure is Distance's story mode, it's short and doesn't really have a clear story; the levels are well designed and are fun. It's more so of a tutorial the first few levels which is good for those who have no clue what they are doing. In these levels, there are ramps, lasers, twisting roads, sawblades, and other things there to kill and confuse you. It requires a solid amount of skill, the boost has the ability to overheat and flying requires boost to actually use. It's a nice balance that doesn't feel restrictive. The sense of speed is fantastic, speeding past 3 lasers then twisting, dodging a pole and then flying over the sawblades just making it towards the regeneration checkpoint is exhilarating. There are also a bunch of other game modes as well - Sprint (time trial), Speed and Style (Time + Tricks), Challenge (Mini Challenge Levels), and Stunt (Tricks); there is also a reverse tag mode that I have yet to play. The amount of game modes are fresh and give players more to play. Lastly, is the integration of Steam Workshop. The community have already made some fantastic levels, one highlight is the replica of Rainbow Road from Mario Kart. The amount of levels and the quality of those are only going to grow. It's a match made in heaven. 

The audio is solid. It's sharp and clear. Where the game's sound shine though is the music. It immerses you in the game and only boosts the intense nature of the game. 

The controls are extremely smooth and responsive. I personally use a gamepad. If you do choose to use a gamepad, try using the triggers for both boost and jump as things can get awkward sometimes. 

With the amount of developer-made levels, gamemodes, online play, and community levels - there is tons to do already. The best part is, the game is going to keep on growing. If you live fast, survival racing games, you must get your hands on this. At $22 (CDN), it's a steal. 

PROS
+Fast
+Challenging
+Plays Great
+Optimized
+Responsive Controls
+Steam Workshop
+Gamemodes
+Little Latency (Online)
+Great Music
+Colorful and Beautiful
+Friendly Community
+Accessible Level Editor

CONS
-No Story (As of yet)
-Difficulty might be tough for some
-Glitches



GRAPHICS: 9.5/10
GAMEPLAY: 9.5/10
AUDIO: 9/10
CONTROLS: 8.5/10
REPLAY VALUE: 10/10

DISTANCE: 9.3/10
Recommendation: Buy it at full price.
One Word Description: "Exhilarating"

Wow, this is such a cool more-than-just-an-arcade-style-racing game! 
I only just dipped a toe in, so will revise my review once i've clocked an unhealthy amount of hours in it :D
Great music!
Some of the best transitions between physics environments (or however to word that) i've seen in a long time ... flying over to a wall and then riding that ... so unique.

Wow. Not very far in...about 3-4 hours. But when I know I have found a badass game, I know.

Imagine those fast paced old school games of dodging obstacles moving at high speeds.
Now add in jumping.
Add 4 pivot jets to control airborne movement.
Add wings for flight, dogrolling and all.
Now add gravity.
Now add gravity in not just in 1 direction.
Now add other people.

This game has the best kind of video game progression. You gain skill.
You start with fundemental basics. Die alot. Suck at controls.
You learn. Now you are boosting and dodging good now.
You overheat if you hold down boost too long.
Now you learn that doing tricks (barrel rolls, backflips/frontflips) reduces the cooldown of your boost.
Later slow driving. All of this adds more and more and more the more you play. 

You'll amaze yourself at what you can do after 5 hours of play compared to the first hour.

Insane fun. Easy to get in games, easy to leave. Short, sick, ****in A.

Like many, I had played Nitronic Rush, a game developed by the creators of Distance as a college project. And, like many, I fell in love with the sense of speed and control, as well as the impressive attention to quality these unpaid students had shown. If you are not sure about purchasing Distance, I urge you to try Nitronic Rush first. Now on to the review, which will be in simple slices from this point on:

Gameplay:
+Great sense of speed
+Wow factor very high
+Ability to be stylish
+Extremely hectic but fun and skill based multiplayer
-Occasional Gravity quips, but mostly as solid as nitronic rush

Graphics:
+Stunning enviornments
+Great in motion or a still screenshot
+Stylized world portrays the mood of the adventure mode well. Speaking of which...

Story:
+A visual adventure with great portrayal  of mood
+Still in beta, so improvements and overall increase in narrative are likely
+Music conveys most of the message

Music:
+I love it
+You want more explanation? Okay
+Electronica, progressive house, and dubstep fused together.
+Sound good?
+You bet

Lasting appeal:
+Workshop support for hundreds of levels
+Still in beta, expect more content!
-As of now, lacking enough to keep you busy for more than a couple days. Will improve with time most likely

Overall, team Nitronic (Now known as Refract Studios) is raising the standard for the racing genre.
Much like Sonic the Hedgehog gave the platformer genre a faster, fresher experience to the platformer genre, Distance is the new way to experience the high speed thrills of a racing game.
The Distance Beta gets a whopping
9/10 for Pre Release
And a predicted
10/10 GoTY for 2015 racing enthusiasts.

13322988.review:
Quality of early access game:
Very high, the devs keep adding content and have the game already very polished from the get-go so you don't feel ripped off that it took them forever to finish the game.
This game has full workshop support!

Glitches:
To be honest, it already feels like a finished game, it just has a few glitches here or there that are mostly User interface.
There IS currently a very obnoxious part of the game where you have to go to the workshop > collections > all collections and subscribe to all of them so the people hosting the multiplayer games can host pretty much anything.
This is the result of the fact that downloading host maps in-game is currently not possible.

Have you played Nitronic Rush?
Yes? 
Then this is a better, faster, more polished version of that with multiplayer, fun new gametypes and the best damn level editor you've ever used.

Haven't played Nitronic Rush?
Distance is an (currently as of writing this) unfinished early access racing game by the digipen grads that made Nitronic Rush as their capstone project.

Gameplay: 
You drive a car that seems to be a mix of an electronic sports car and a jet pack, as the car itself can not only fly but also has small thrusters on every section of the vehicle which are 100% necessary as the roads will end suddenly and this forces the player to literally jump, spin, and twist to another track section. The controls are tight and feel satisfying when you pull off a trick or make a perfect landing.
It's about going fast and avoiding MANY obstacles, which can range from pretty much anything and everything. If you get hit by a laser the game will remove parts of your vehicle realistic, and you can keep going to try and rebuild at the next checkpoint, it's often hilarious!

Graphics:
wow, just wow. The game is absolutely beautiful. I haven't seen such amazing reflection (specular) mapping on anything in video games in, ever. The game has some CRAZY filters and lighting that results in areas having feeling to them. I.E. a VIBRANT red area that is very in your face with it's obstacles will make you tense up and concentrate as you dodge as much as you can. While a cool blue zone, even if it has more obstacles, might make the game feel a bit more relaxed.
Even in multiplayer the game is very atmospheric, allowing creators of custom maps to be extremely creative.

Story?
There IS a story, it's very abstract. Not as in it's trying to be artsy, instead it goes for a more vague, mysterious and atmospheric feel. Without spoiling anything, I think you'll enjoy the story if you like video games that don't shove the story down your throat. Do keep in mind, as it is early access, the story is not currently complete and only has about ten levels. Which will actually take you a good hour or so to complete them all, much longer if it's your first time playing it. 

Multiplayer: 
Yes, it has multiplayer. Currently players cannot collide with each-other. Instead every player shows up as a real-time ghost, which surprisingly doesn't actually make the game less fun.
There are a few issues here or there unfortunately, as the physics for the game are connected to the frames-per-second, you may collide with walls or pieces of track even though you thought you landed just fine. Do keep in mind this has happened to me only two times in the over a hundred multiplayer races I’ve driven.
The other game modes are pretty fun too, reverse tag is just a big game of keep-away, It's pretty fun, and results in some silly moments.

Difficulty:
This game is has a very subtle difficulty curve. It starts off easy and explains mechanics as you go by, then it gets surprisingly difficult. When you finally get used to the difficulty of the game it semi-mellows out to the point of making it easier but still challenging. Once you get good at it, you'll start trying new shortcuts and attempt tricks to skip parts of tracks. The custom maps however range from incredibly easy, to insane in how difficult they are. If you get a large amount of them and play with some people (or friends if you have those) you'll have a blast.

Conclusion:
Distance is fun, REALLY fun. It breaks many of the assumptions we have for racing games and makes the game feel fresh and new with it's style and feel of originality. It's very atmospheric, and that personally is very appealing. The addition of multiplayer and custom map support is genius and makes the game feel fresh almost indefinitely. It may not be finished but it sure feels like a complete game at this point. 

9.5/10 One of my new favorite games. Can't wait for them to finish it!


P.S. If you want to have a demo for this game, Nitronic Rush is the best way to do that, it's free; just Google it.

Took a gamble on this, being that it's early access, but I was absolutely blown away by how complete the game felt.
[Gameplay]
+Hyper-fast racing, very similar to Track Mania with San Francisco Rush: 2049 mixed in
+Tons of different track options. You could be driving one second, flying the next, then flipping sideways to wall ride
+You will die often, and the spawn system is quick enough to keep you from getting bored

[PC Options]
+This is clearly a PC game, with full blown graphics settings options, high framerate, and controller support too
+Custom tracks galore, there are tons already and the game isn't even released yet

As a spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush, one of my favourite racing/driving games, I imagine it will be great when it's finished. Heck, it's great right now.

The story isn't done yet, but some of the elements I've seen in its current state are very promising. 

The level design in this is pretty good so far, but I feel most of the levels are tutorial-level of difficulty. It would be good to see the next levels added have a higher difficulty.

I've tested this with an xbox controller, and keyboard/mouse. Both seem to do the job well, but I do hope they add mouse support for menus sometime soon.

The graphics in this game look pretty amazing in their current state.

The soundtrack in this game is great, and if it is going to be in any way similar to nitronic Rush, it can only get better.

This game supports the workshop, so once more people good with game design get on board  in the community you can be sure there won't be a shortage of levels to play.

While this is an early access game, I do feel that the developers have proven themselves to be very competent and not just in it for a money grab. They dd private betas beforehand, and have already developed Nitronic Rush. I'm looking forward to the final product.

Distance. Named so, because that is the challange. Getting from point A to B. But really, so much more than that. Sure, you could say that time is the challange, or that it's other players in multiplayer, but really, it's yourself.

This game... I don't even know where to start. It's AMAZING. Most car-based games I've played are limited to racing, and driving on the GROUND. In this game, what even IS the ground? Sure, there's gravity, (most of the time) but you can drive freely on any flat or flat-ish surface you can get to. This game has NO invisible walls, no limits.

Most games in Early Access are unfinished shadows of what they could be, lacking most gameplay, and just a proof of concept. This game is in a state that they could release it from beta, and it could be considered finished. Years of work have been put into this game, and I'm glad to have played it before it offically came out on steam.
 
The game has a level editor, and while it IS a bit tricky to use, it's limitless with what you can do. It has Workshop support, which means you have 100's more levels than the developers could make in the time they have. Already I've seen some pretty cool levels.  I've seen levels that look like Tron, and levels that looks like natural mountions. 

My SINGLE complaint is the sorting system for the levels. They should have a way to sort from most recently updates, by name, and a few other things.

Over all, 10/10. This is NO exaggeration.

The most satisfying driving experience I’ve ever had in a game. The movements and stunts are fluid and quick to respond to input. The levels are creative and atmospheric, and definitely one of the most fun driving games I’ve played in a long time. One of the first games I’ve gone back to beat previous time records on. 13313050.review:
[b] Distance is a supurb experimental racing game sure to hook you instantly and not let go [/b]

I have been following this game for years anxiously waiting for the release, and Im happy to say it even [u]  exceeded even MY expectations [/u]

[b] Design [/b]
Everything about the visuals is absolutely BEAUTIFUL and it is no understatement to say that you will be sitting there in awh at points in the campagin. Even the lowest graphic settings makes the game look pretty good. The visuals are also very very optimized, guaranteed to run on almost any machine, which seems to be quite rare with these Early Access Games. Very tron inspired and im a sucker for those kind of aesthetics.

[b] Sound [/b]
Crisp and clear. I was suprised at the amazing sound quality. From the woosh of passing large objects to the crashing sound effects everything about the sounds are just awesome.

[b] Music [/b]
One of the games HUGE strong points. The music fits perfectly with everything. From the high octane Drum&Bass tracks to the chilled out electro you'll defenitley find yourself bobbing your head to the beat. Amazing soundtrack (If only they separately sold it)

[b] Gameplay [/b]
I personally play with a gamepad but keyboard and mouse feels excellent with little to no complaints. However it's prefered to play the game with a controller/gamepad to get the full feel of the controls. With it everything feels so much smoother and I also recomend using the advanced controls for more finer flips tricks and stunts! Wonderful controls

[b] Multiplayer [/b]
The "Distance" community is some of the best I've run into. I havent encountered a single problem with the people. The multiplayer gamemodes consist of a simple racing mode, to reverse tag (my personal favorite) and a challenge/stunt mode. All of which you can sink hours into, and theres even more gamemodes to come!

[b] Level Editor / Steam Workshop [/b]
Possibly the coolest part of this game. The level editor is so easy to pick up and learn and you can just upload to the workshop with a press of a button. And getting maps is even eaiser!

[b] Overall thoughts [/b]
A MUST BUY. You have a unique racer combined with an explosive soundtrack, breath taking visuals, a friendly community, and a wonderful level editor. What more could you want?!

13309491.review:
I've been following this game since they started the kickstarter a while back, which is actually the first and only game I've helped kickstart. I've played from the alpha stage up to now, and the game has shown significant progress. I know a lot of people are hesitant to purchase early access games, but trust me, Refract absolutely know what they are doing with Distance. They have been putting out consistent updates and improvements to the alpha and beta stages over the past year or two, and it is easy to tell that they are very passionate about this game. They also are very supportive of the community, evidenced by the fact they acknowledge and support the user created levels in the workshop. 

If I hadn't helped kickstarted this game, I would definitely purchase early access. I really trust Refract with creating a quality game, and I can tell you with certainty that this won't be an early access game that crashes and burns like a lot of others out there.

Also, if you're not sure you like arcade racing games like this, you should download Nitronic Rush, which Distance is the sequel to.  It has very similar mechanics, an awesome soundtrack, and is free! Go try it out!

Was ist Distance?
 
Kurzgefasst Distance ist ein Solides Arcade Rennspiel wo man auch verschiedenden Strecken (Denk Editor und Steam Workshop gibs nahzu unendlich davon) versucht schnellst möglich in Ziel zu gelengen.


Was ist daran Neu ?

Wie man ins Ziel kommt, man kann an Wänden und Decken Fahren, Springen, Fliegen (ist etwas langsamer als fahren) oder in Antigravitation abschnitten mit den Schubdüsen navigieren. Je nach Strecke können die Element wie Springen und Fliegen Ganz oder Tempörer deaktiviert werden je nachdem wie sich der Mapersteller entscheidet.

Steuerung

Die Std. Steureung ist die Tastatur (Tastenbelegung kann frei gewählt werden) oder man verwendet ein Gamepad

13302681.review:
Il s'agit d'un jeu de voiture de course dans un monde numérique. Les graphismes, épurés, sont très jolis, et le jeu est très fluide. Logique, car la richesse des textures n'est représentée qu'en style "néon" comme tron. Les circuits rappellent un peu Trackmania, mais avec des obstacles mortels en plus. La voiture est capable de planer, mais pour un temps limité. De même, le boost est limité dans le temps, et une surchauffe prolongée se solde par l'explosion du véhicule.

Le mode aventure propose une difficulté croissante à chaque circuit qui se succède, et fait découvrir de nouvelles commandes. Sur les circuits les plus simples, la prise en main est relativement aisée. Cependant, à mesure que l'on progresse, l'intuitif cède le pas à la difficulté de maîtriser le véhicule. Surtout qu'à certains endroits, on a du mal à se repérer, et savoir par où passer. En outre, il m'est pour ma part encore difficile de faire effectuer une rotation du véhicule sur le côté, pour pousuivre sur un mur vertical qui devient alors la suite du circuit (la caméra effectue une rotation d'elle-même pour se retrouver en vue classique). Etant donner qu'une touche permet d'accélérer, une autre le boost, une pour sauter, et si l'on rappuie dessus planer, sans compter celles pour effectuer une rotation sur le côté, sans oublier de maintenir celle pour tourner à droite ou à gauche en même temps, s'avère un exercice délicat, et se tromper de combinaison de touches est sanctionné par un cuisant échec. La principale difficulté du titre me semble se trouver à ce niveau.

En conclusion, le jeu semble prometteur, et la dextérité du joueur à trouver les bonnes enchaînements des boutons de la manette mise à rude épreuve. Je pense que cela nécessite un apprentissage qui pourrait en dégoûter plus d'un. Il s'agit tout de même d'un titre à suivre. A voir avec le multijoueur que je n'ai pas encore testé (apprentissage des combinaisons de touches en cours ! ) ;)

13301287.review:
Okay so I've edited this review about four times since the game was launched.

I want to preface this by saying that I bought access to this game back in 2014, when it was in Alpha.

Now, as you'll undoubtedly see from reading other reviews, the game was supposed to be released a long time ago, and even a 2014 release would have been a little bit late. 

However, I'd say that it's been well worth the wait for these three reasons:

1. The devs are receptive and communicate regularly on the official Discord. This in and of itself blows my mind, because I myself have actually spoken to the devs on many different occasions, which to me is like talking with celebrities.

2. The level editor. I cannot stress this point enough: There is a large community of people in this game who create quality content on a regular basis. If you go through the workshop for this game, you'll see what I mean. 

3. New features. Over the lifetime of this game, features have been suggested and not only implemented, but implemented well. From its' early beta to now, we have seen the introduction of a complex particle system, retexturable simple objects such as cubes, cones, triangles etc., an animator feature, and most recently customizable skyboxes. 

Even if you're not a racing fan, I highly recommend checking this game out. There's a lot of love that's been poured into it by the devs and the community over a long period of time, and it's being actively worked on. 

Putting aside the innovative mechanics, great soundtrack, splitscreen functionality and online P2P multiplayer, for $20 ($10 on a sale) this game is a steal, and I can honestly say one of my favorite games of all time.

13301043.review:
Distance is the perfect blend between a racing and a platforming experience. It reminds me of the classic Trackmania which I loved. It is really addictive trying to master a track by shaving off fractions of a second on every corner or just doing crazy stunts while avoiding over-the-top obstacles. Here is my experience with the Beta...

[b]Driving:[/b] Responsive, arcade controls for driving, jumping and flying. The game works well with a gamepad and provides sensible layouts for many controllers. It would be nice to have a button to reset the camera though. I like the way the car handles mid-air maneuvering. Sometimes collisions with obstacles can feel a little bit off. I also wish there were more obstacles that you can interact with, like the lasers - how about destructible surfaces or gravity fields?

[b]Aesthetics:[/b] The world looks like it was partly inspired by things like Tron, but feels much more gritty. It features impressive lighting effects and a great soundtrack. You can get an amazing sense of speed through the visual and sound effects, combined with the track design.

[b]Story Mode:[/b] A good way to get accustomed to the controls and obstacles, as it has a very nice learning curve. It sets the mood with some awesome set-piece moments that don't feel tacked on.

[b]Tracks:[/b] The track you choose determines if you are playing a race against the clock (Sprint), a hardcore platformer (Challenge), a Tony Hawk-like playground (Stunt) or all at once (Speed & Style - my favorite). The various tracks often allow multiple paths which require some skilled driving and creativity while making split-second decisions. If you get off-track, there is usually a way to recover. The ability to make your own tracks in the editor or download community ones gives this game longevity. 

[b]Multiplayer:[/b] I have not tried the different multiplayer modes yet but I am eager to get into it now that the game is on Early Access.

13300546.review:
Anyone who's played the free game titled Nitronic Rush will feel right at home with Distance.  In fact, Distance is being developed as the spiritual successor (sequal) to Nitronic Rush.  And what a fantastic sequal it is.  Here are my opinions on the game as a Kickstarter backer (beta).

Pros:
-Superb graphics/environment.  The theme of the levels is fantastic (almost Tron-esque), and the music goes with the environment very well.  Light will pulse along with the music, and the overfall feeling is just fabulous.
-Excellent handling.  The cars handle beautifully, and really are easy to drive but hard to master.  Mechanics such as boosting (which has a heating system a la Motorstorm), jumping, and flying are all implemented very well.  The levels often utilize these too, creating for a unique driving expirience.
-Challenge.  Distance is fun for just your average racer, but it has a suprising depth for speedrunners.
-Level editor.  Have not used this much personally, but you can see by other people's fantastic creations that it works well.

Cons:
-Content.  The game's in beta, so I can't be too harsh here.  However, at the time of writing this you can complete the story in an hour or so.  
-Level editor.  While very robust, it's not particularly easy to use.  Tutorials can be found on Youtube; they help.

If you enjoy racing games, challenging games, or speedrunning games I strongly recommend picking this up.  I have been anxiously awaiting this game since it was announced and it's been anything but dissapointing.

13295917.review:
Distance is a fast, challenging, and beautiful racing game built by former members of Team Nitronic (Creators of Nitronic Rush).  Distance is a more polished game in every respect, with excellent music, art style, sense of speed, great multiplayer, and steam workshop integration. It is a rare game that is exactly what you see in the trailer.

The level editor deserves special praise for being the one of the most powerful and well-designed level editors I've ever used. There are others that are easier (Trackmania's block-based editor, for example) and there are a few that are more full-featured, but the Distance editor is basically all you could need. I have a few tracks on the Distance workshop and they were made completely in the editor.

There are some minor bugs and missing features (mouse support on the main menu would be great!) but they honestly don't take too much from the experience. I used to have some problems with getting network games up but that hasn't been an issue recently.

The guys at Refract are incredibly engaged with the fans (check their twitter) and have sent emails out pretty regularly since the first day of the Kickstarter; while it's generally good to be wary of titles on Early Access, Refract have already built an excellent game and you are definitely getting your money's worth at $20.

13294968.review:
Below you'll find a video and a written impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TDWTdKTGUlk

Distance features high quality visuals and audio, with a great sound track. The game is essentially an arcade racer that focuses on avoiding obstacles and quick reflexes. It has a lot of very interesting ideas and mechanics, including flight (yeah, your car can fly), interesting play on gravity (drive on walls and ceiling), and some environmental hazards that are quite unique in how they can affect your performance.

The game excels at giving the player the sensation of speed, but also keeps him/her on their toes as the tracks are always littered with piles of hazards. When you first jump into Distance, some parts of the game may get frustrating at first, and your first flight will probably end in tragedy. There is a learning curve, but if you can get over that hump, this game can feel incredibly satisfying as you learn to needle thread through obstacles, and flipping your car just at the right moment, you'll find that "holy shit" moment more than once.

My only real complaint is how the game handles gravity some times. As mentioned previously, you can flip your car to drive on ceilings and walls, but the game some times doesn't know what to do with the car if you don't jump or flip exactly as the game wants you to. Instead of making a landing that looked perfectly reasonable, you fly off into the nether, then your car blows up... I hope the developers can make some adjustments in the future and tweak the gravity to be more consistent and user friendly.

Distance is in Early Access, but unlike many in the same program Distance feels very complete. It already features a full and robust options and graphics settings, level editor with over 150 user made maps available already, local and online multiplayer, and multiple ways to play the campaign maps. Distance has raised the bar of what gamers can expect from early access games, and this is a good thing.

Overall Distance is a very enjoyable arcade racer that will have you pulling your hair out one minute, and in the next, your nose will be touching the screen with focus and determination. It's a hell of a ride. 

Pros:
- Great visuals and audio
- Fast and visceral gameplay
- Challenging
- Tons of interesting ideas
- Feels extremely complete for an early access (Beta 3297)

Cons:
- Gravity feels wonky at times
- Can be frustrating at first

13293355.review:
Absolutely fantastic. I loved Nitronic Rush and Team Nitronic (now Refract Studios) have definitely lived up to, and gone way past the fun and excitement of it with Distance. I've been in since the beta, and so far I've loved every bit of it.

While this game is in early access, I highly recommend it even if the game never updates again (which it will by the way, Refract are cool guys)

First, the level editor: Steam Workshop support and a built in level editor is a game changer for any game, and this one especially. The editors advanced features reminds me of such things as Autodesk Maya, but can be simplified down to the Portal 2 in-game map creator. Tracks in the editor snap together and can be automatically resized. They act like splines and the track automatically is generated along them, so you do not have to worry about that at all. Everything is very easy yet advanced at the same time which will make some really brilliant levels (and has already infact).

Multiplayer: This was the most requested feature from Nitronic Rush, and they've implemented it right down to the core of the game. It is done extremely well and I couldn't ask for anything more (well, maybe auto downloading of workshop levels to clients who dont have). It's really fun with mates or strangers on any of the modes: sprint, speed and style, challenge and reverse tag (shame they removed the football gamemode though).

Atmosphere: The atmosphere of the game is clear from the start and I think it works really well. There's less of the really bright colours from Nitronic and the announcer is gone (for now at least). The world is dark and gloomy but mixed with flashing lights and exciting music makes for an interesting yet enjoyable experience. The soundtrack itself is incredible, Torcht and the team really have outdone themselves this time, it's much better than Nitronic Rush's music (and for the record, I loved Nitronic Rush's music).

There are only a few things that I think should be worked. The first is optional realtime portals, since right now they work like a static 360* image wrapped around it - but don't get me wrong they look great and aren't noticeable at high speeds, of course this should be off by default and as an advanced graphics option like realtime reflections since they would require a beefy GPU. Another thing would be mod support for custom gamemode types. My biggest issue currently is no mouse support at all, not even for menus - but I'm sure it's planned (we are in Early Access right now, after all), but these are more like feature requests than actual issues - and I'm certain Refract has more up their sleeve for us, so we'll see.

Conclusion: Get this game if you love any of these:
A. Arcade racers
B. Splitscreen games
C. Sci-Fi games
D. Racers
E. Playing tag with your friends
F. Games with an amazing soundtrack
G. Calm driving
H. Exciting driving
I. Polished games
J. Multiplayer racing with friends
K. Multiplayer racing with not friends
L. Nitronic Rush
M. Ex-DigiPen students
N. Refract Studios

Okay I'll stop now, but seriously, get this game - you will not regret it.

13292420.review:
Ah Distance... Digne successeur de Nitronic Rush ?

Crowdfundé à hauteur de 161,981 $ sur Kickstarter en Novembre 2012, les ingrédients de base sont simple pour ce jeu de course et survie : une ambiance futuriste à la fois classieuse et légèrement psychédélique à la Tron, une soundtrack électro de haute volée mais surtout un gameplay aux petits oignons. Car outre le level design audacieux des circuits, c’est dans les capacités de votre véhicule que Distance a séduit le joueur pas plus accroc que ça aux jeux de voiture que je suis. 

Parlons donc des contrôles, tout d’abord, le jeu se joue impérativement à la manette, je déconseille fortement de jouer au clavier, vous allez vite comprendre pourquoi.

En effet, dans Distance, votre voiture, si on peut encore l’appeler comme ça, peut se booster, faire des bonts, voler, ou encore effectuer vrilles et autres manoeuvres improbables grâce aux propulseurs situés sur le dessus de la carrosserie. Si vous gardez le boost ou que vous volez trop longtemps, le véhicule finit par surchauffer puis exploser, et pour récupérer de l’énergie, il vous faudra régulièrement passer les checkpoints ou faire des figures de style.

Ajoutez à cela l’adhésivité de l’ensemble des surfaces planes du jeu, on se retrouve avec des circuits totalement WTF, et, pour avoir testé, je peux vous dire que sur écran géant le tout rend extrêmement bien. J’ai d’ailleurs hâte de voir ce que ça donne en 3D.

Bref côté Gameplay, et pour un jeu de course arcade comme celui ci on parle donc vraiment de l’essentiel, Distance est une vraie réussite. Les contrôles à la manette répondent parfaitement bien, l’impression de vitesse est là et les sensations aussi. 

Mais qu’en est il du reste ?

Le jeu propose plusieurs modes de course en solo et un mode aventure, pour le moment celui-ci s’apparente plutôt à un long tutorial avec quelques passages d’ambiance très réussi mais n’apportant pas d’éléments scénaristiques explicites. Cela va sans dire, ce mode n’est pas encore terminé, et Refract nous annonce quelque chose de relativement bien travaillé avec des circuits ouverts permettant au joueurs de choisir différents chemins afin de joindre course et exploration. Sur le papier c’est tentant, mais pour l’instant je n’ai pas été vraiment convaincu par l’aspect exploration de Distance. Bien que son monde soit immersif et mystérieux avec ses zones infectées visuellement très impressionnantes, on ne se sent jamais vraiment dans un monde ouvert favorisant l’exploration mais plutôt un grand circuit à plusieurs chemins plus ou moins rapides.

Pour l’heure donc, le mode aventure de Distance est un excellent tutorial voué à se transformer en une véritable expérience solo dotée d’un scénario. Il faudra donc attendre pour juger réellement cette partie du jeu.

Quoi d’autre alors ?

Si vous possédez 2 manettes réjouissez-vous ! Distance peut se jouer en Écran partagé ! Une forme de multijoueurs qui tend à disparaitre sur PC, la présence de cette fonctionnalité est donc vraiment appréciable, surtout quand on veut mettre une taule à un pote en live.

Côté multijoueurs en ligne, Distance se distingue par ses quelques modes très sympathiques dont voici un rapide détail :
Tout d’abord Sprint : Probablement le mode le plus populaire, arriver au bout du circuit en premier, respawn autorisé aux checkpoints et collisions activées.
Stunt : Comme le titre l’indique, sur ces circuits spéciaux le joueur au score de cascade le plus élevé à la fin de la partie gagne.
On a aussi du Reverse Tag : Probablement mon préféré, dans ce mode vous jouez littéralement au loup à l’envers. Le premier à rester en possession de la balle pendant un temps donné gagne le partie. Les autres joueurs peuvent évidemment récupérer la balle en passant à côté du porteur.
Et enfin Challenge : Dans ce mode pour les hommes les vrais, pas de respawn, uniquement des petits circuits très difficiles, et bien évidemment le meilleur temps gagne.

Malheureusement pour le moment le jeu étant en early access, il n’y a pas beaucoup de joueurs ni de serveurs en ligne, mais ça viendra j'ai confiance ; de plus jusqu’içi la communauté a l’air très accueillante et m’a un peu rappelé Trackmania dans ses premières heures.

Pour finir abordons un point qui pour moi fait vraiment la force de Distance et me donne envie d’y repasser régulièrement : l’éditeur de niveau. N’étant personnellement pas un grand architecte de circuit, je prend surtout mon pied à tester les circuits de la communauté, et je peux vous dire qu’on a des mecs extrêmement bons, le niveau de certains circuits dépassent aisément le pack de base crée par Refract livré avec le jeu. Tout cela étant géré et classé par l’excellent Steam Workshop, télécharger les meilleurs niveaux de la communauté est simple comme bonjour. Ah et évidemment tous ces circuits se connectent automatiquement au leaderboards du jeu, enregistrant tous les temps des joueurs de Distance sur Steam… Bref, le paradis si vous êtes du genre compétiteur dans l’âme.

Alors est-ce que je recommande Distance, bien sûr que oui, foncez, le jeu en vaut la chandelle.

13292091.review: Amazing racing game with tron-like graphics. It is a very fast paced racing game, where a second can be the difference between literally life and death. Your car can be damaged-sliced in half, dented, and more. Graphically wise, it can be quite pretty with neon lights all over. When played with friends or online the gameplay is amazing,  the competition fierce, but even when you lag behind you will be cheered on by the willing and watching crowd. Adventure mode is a nice introduction to the game. It also has an amazing level editor that is easy to use, allowing you to create hundreds of maps-just look at the workshop to see some creations. Music is one of the things that truly fits this type of game, think techno-beat meets trons daft punk, makes you want to hit the nitro for even longer.

13292033.review: Distance the first game to ever have wings on a car for a decent reason. So for one I am loving this game to bits so far. Its got a learning curve but its not too nasty and its FAST!. So far the game shows real promise as a early access games. Tons of graphics options, Customisation of vehicles, Steam workshop on day 1 for new tracks, leaderboards ect. But the thing i the love the most about this game so far is that its like a survival game mixed with burnout  with tron as the theme and you wont get the full idea till you watch one of the trailers. Fly off the track, fly back on with your power. Get cut in half!, get to the next checkpoint to regenerate. Multiplayer is good fun too and seems easy to set up and to connect. so yeah so far I ******** love it! Grab it if you have a racing itch cause its brilliant. I was looking for a game to replace the long dead blur and its not quite the same but I dont care one bit. I like this one more!

13291856.review:
(This is a review in progress.)

A great sequel to the free Nitronic Rush, (Which I also recommend, if you haven't played it, it's free!) even in Early Access it has a lot of content to play with, as well as improved mechanics that still stay true to the original. For those who haven't played Nitronic Rush, you effectively "drive" an anti-virus into the heart of a city that's infected in order to cleanse it. As for Distance, it looks like things are much more corrupt. The Adventure Mode hasn't been finished yet, so I'm not sure how that concludes at the moment, but it's really exciting to play a survival racing game.

Pros:
Improved Mechanics
Huge boost in aesthetic details.
Nice level-editor
Multiplayer

Cons:
I've yet to find any! As always, this is early access, so players might come across some bugs here and there, but I've personally only ever come across one where I fell through the world due to a clipping error, but I've not had any problems since.

13291749.review:
I loved Nitronic Rush, so I could easily recommend this game. This also makes me a bit bias, so stating this outright. If you wish for a Demo, search for Nitronic Rush. Over all it is a well-polished game with little to no bugs, and only increases in its polish and content.
-----
Distance is a survival racer; Get to the objective as fast as possible with minimal deaths. 
Go upside down, dodge lasers, and do it in style doing flips and tricks using small rockets inside the car, along with wings to fly through the map. By default these are controlled with the sticks on gamepads or wasd with the arrow keys.

Multiplayer, co-op, a rocking sound track and Steam workshop make this game all the better, with new songs being added all the time and a massive dedicated community of map makers who have been around since the map editor was a hidden asset in the original game.

Current complaints are no mouse compatibility for menus, and as of the time of writing, the campaign is missing quite a few levels, a bit of a steep learning curve for the level editor in my opinion and an inability to sort levels in menus when using the level selector, but both are easily fixable as the beta continues. In terms of difference from Nitronic Rush, flying is bound to space when in air, which I’m not a fan of personally but it's preference (and can be changed in menu).

The Developers have been very open with the backers through this process and have been providing plenty of updates to keep backers of the original Kickstarter up to date, I personally believe they will finish the project and it will be fantastic.

13291718.review: Amazing. Backed from the start so I am biased, but this is a fabulous and immersive racing game with great multiplayer elements that are clever and fun like I have never seen in any other racing game. If you liked Nitronic Rush (Free game), then you would be doing yourself a disservice if you didn't get Distance.

13291676.review:
My Let's Play - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUKOjyZNUZk

Quick Impressions: Initially the game feels kind of slow even when you have that blur-thing happening. But the first few stages are tutorials getting you accustomed to the game. Even though the game never actually gets any faster, the obstacles thrown in front of you creates a very real feeling of speed. Looking back at my LP, it does seem slow, but when I was playing, it was hectic.

There is a nice magnetic grip to the car. It's not way overpowered, it's tuned very nicely and helps with all of the crazy go-nuts car flipping to perpendicular roadways. I've already seen some speed runs and I'm excited to see what comes of it.

There are already UGC for the levels!  http://steamcommunity.com/app/233610/workshop/ Which is NUTS!  Really cool that there is so much UGC on day one when the game launches.  Easily has to be some kind of record. I toyed around with the level editor at the end of my LP and I have no idea what I'm doing, but it seems fairly simple after you get the hotkeys situated in your head.

Lastly, I want to mention that there is a very real kernel of a story present in Distance.  Which is kind of odd, because you usually don't expect stories in racing games.  But something is definitely up.

All told this game is precision racing.

Excellent job from the Nitronic Rush guys!

13291511.review:
I started playing racing games during the glory days of Carmageddon and "FZR2000" ;) and i have remained unimpressed ever since NFS Underground.
It's hard for a racing game to impress nowadays... Why ? well we kinda seen it all... haven't we ?
I mean.. what could they possibly do to impress us ?

Well Distance did it...
The game features a fresh take on the trackmania recipe with pleasant Tron-ish graphics.
The soundtrack is ok but considering the way the actual game plays ...perhaps something a bit more "strong" would have been better.
You don't get to chose from X number of cars and have only one which is slightly customizable...a color here and a accent there. Strangely i never felt the need to change my car and i never felt like the game would benefit from a larger variety of vehicles.

So what is this game all about ?
Driving as fast as you can and avoiding all obstacles as swiftly and as elegantly as you can.
The game features several game modes such as Sprint, Stunt, Speed and Style, Challenge etc...
When it comes to multiplayer we have either split screen (up to 4 players, only one can use keyboard the rest have to use controllers, and in 2 player mode you can chose vertical or horizontal split screen) And then we have the online component for up to 6 players.
The game includes a full and very complete level editor and steam workshop support (for which you can already download over 100 tracks). Obviously this can ad a ton of replay value, and if you fancy yourself a hot-shot designer maybe you will make the next "epic track".
There is even a single player campaign which is used as a tutorial and introduction to this futuristic high tech world (full of sharp/pointy/blunt death-traps that are in your way!).
During this campaign you will learn how to barrel roll, fly, hover and glide in zero gravity.
The games main mechanic is the boost. There is no recharge time for it like in most games but you do need to be careful not to overheat or else you go BooM! There are some gates which will either partly or fully cool and regenerate your car for all the damage taken up to that point.
Something i really liked was the way the HUD is done, it is mostly integrated into the game elements, which dose lots for the overall feel of the game. There are some who do not like this aspect because at times the HUD is not visible. In my opinion this is not a big deal because a game such as this should be played by.. "feel" if that makes any sens...
Another design element i really appreciate is the way vibration is done for the 360 controller. This is used to GRADUALLY warn you about how overheated your car is. This means that you can keep your eyes on the track and off your rear bumper. 
When it comes to the ugly "early access" tag i would go as far as to say that Distance dose not really need it. The single player campaign is not complete and the mouse is not functional in all menus... but these are all the early access "scars" i could find in my time with the game.
I can go on and on about Distance but i don't wanna bore you to much so let's wrap-it up.

"The Good"
-The Track Editor- is not exactly user friendly but its a very complete tool
-The Graphics- although graphics are a rather subjective topic in my opinion
-Gameplay- rock solid, pure gaming, no nonsense
-HUD Design- this is the way a HUD should be done in modern games, yes it has some issues, but its a big step forward from the classic and outdated designs.

"The Bad"
-Only 6 players in online multiplayer...How Could You ?!

"The Meh"
-Soundtrack- I believe there are much better options for a game that plays like this...but again this is a subjective topic by nature.

What else is there to say ? 
Drop the clutch, boost to max, juke the spikes and i'll see you at the finish line...if you get there ;)
For a clearer view you can watch my first impressions video :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MCy1uIvL5o&list=PLPu1MBLqtny7rnijEzJ3bPSEMepog_rOK

13291510.review:
[h1]Intro[/h1]
 Distance is a racing game where your main goal is to survive and to get to the end of the level. It’s just you and the track. There are no opponents that can run you off the road, but there [i]are[/i] many obstacles. But is it interesting enough to keep you going ?
 
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
 When you first start you’re put into the seat of a futuristic racing car where you have to race across tracks and just survive. Just. Survive.
But this is not just an ordinary car. Your car can, besides racing at insane speeds, also turn mid-air, fly, boost and jump. It’s quite spectacular to see your car appear, especially with the HUD being projected on the car itself. There’s no true HUD, because the car will show you all the vital information: the direction you need to go to, your boost meter, your speed-o-meter and a timer. The timer allows you to set a high score and I guess that’s the true goal of the game: repeating a level over and over again and hoping that you get better and beat your previous high score(s).

 All of this is done while you complete random tracks. At the end of the track you’re being teleported to a new one where the whole process begins anew. Except that it gets more difficult with each new track. You’re gradually introduced to new gameplay mechanics and after about 10 tracks or so you should know exactly what to do when an object appears out of thin air or when a new part of the track suddenly appears beside or above you. That still doesn’t make it an easy game. On the contrary; it’s a hard game and you have to choose when and how long you want to boost and you have to perfect your flight and trick abilities at the same time. You’ll frequently crash and burn.
That’s partly thanks to the game itself (well, the game designers really), because it doesn’t always let you fly whenever you want to. For me personally it was very confusing because I had no idea when I could or couldn’t use it. Whenever I was about to drop down a track I just pressed the button and hoped that it would work. Unfortunately this didn’t work more than half of the time. When you’re playing a game where the goal is to get to the end of the track as quick as possible then you don’t want to have worry about if you’re being able to fly or not whenever you’re about to crash. It’s a small design flaw in my eyes. You either let people know that they will be able to fly during a track or you don’t. You can’t just change things up halfway through a track. But enough about that for now; it’s still an Early Access title and we must have faith that things can still change. And obviously I understand that the developers want to add an extra layer of difficulty to the game this way.

 I haven’t yet talked about some of the things that will appear on the track so I’ll try to spend a minute talking about that. The game starts with introducing ramps and other basic/common things you find in most race games. After a while, huge, sharp rotating blades can be seen cutting into the tracks as well as laserbeams moving around trying to cut your car in half (which really does happen and you can then decide to either try and get to the next checkpoint or you can reset to the last one). Not much later you’ll also encounter blocks appearing out of thin air, rotating fans and spikes coming in from all sides. Plenty of stuff to keep you on your toes, as you can see.

 The game has an Adventure Mode and an Arcade Mode. Adventure Mode is the single-player mode that I was just talking about where you follow a story (yes, there’s a story). Arcade Mode lets you play solo, split screen or online.  Solo gives you different choices than split screen and online so there’s plenty to do. I haven’t yet tried any of the modes except for Adventure Mode but unfortunately that one is incomplete and still being worked on. I’ve seen glimpses of the story but I’m not quite sure that I understand what it’s all about. Maybe soon.
 
[h1]Graphics & Audio[/h1]
 Graphically Distance is pretty impressive with dark lighting and a dark atmosphere in general, only brightened by colorful neon colors that appear on the tracks and specific objects (now I think about it; it’s shown on pretty much anything that can kill you). It has a cool Tron-like vibe but unfortunately the game uses a lot of basic geometry. Levels are kinda boring and the car itself doesn’t have much detail. I get that it’s futuristic but a little more variety in the tracks would’ve brought the game to life. But, since I don’t know if it’s part of the story I can’t properly talk about it I guess. So again, maybe we’ll know when the game finally releases somewhere next year.
 The audio consists of sci-fi music with a somewhat frantic tempo. It fits the game completely so this is all good. Sounds like your car crashing and beams and blades closing in also sound great. No, the sound department is just fine.
 
[h1]Length/Replayability[/h1]
 Since this is an Early Access title the game isn’t yet complete. Still, the Adventure Mode can take you anywhere between 1,5-3 hours I think. After that you will probably have seen it all until the next part of the game releases.
But, of course, you can always spend some time with the Editor to create some new tracks yourself, or download custom made tracks from the Steam Workshop. That will add at least several hours extra to the total playtime.
 
[h1]Closing[/h1]
 Distance hasn’t entirely become the game that I initially expected. I don’t know exactly what I was expecting, but I think that I was expecting a game similar to WipeOut maybe. While it doesn’t even come close to being that game this game is good in its own right. Partly thanks to the fact that it tries to do something different. I honestly can’t think of a game that uses these kind of mechanics so that’s absolutely a good sign. While it can definitely use some more polish and maybe a few changes here and there I certainly like what I’ve been playing thus far. And who knows what more we can expect in the near future ? I for one am looking forward to the final release. For now I’ll rate this as follows:
 
[Rating: 76/100]

39503570.review:
Before I get into this review, let me just say that I recommend that you have a pretty good computer to play this game. My computer is good but it just barely stays around the 30FPS mark. Keep that in mind. 

Distance is a game that combines racing and parkour to make challenging but fun levels. There is a few problems here and there that I hope get fixed before the full release, but it's still a good game. 

I 100% (no) 110% recommend you play this with a controller. The keyboard controls are ok, but they are not great ether. If you use a controller, I also recommend you switch the boost and jump buttons to A for jump and X for boost. It's better in my opinion. 

The game is also technically endless with lots of levels being published to the games workshop everyday. I highly recommend you pick this up. 

Score: 9.3/10
